business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Paul Calvert) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Senator HILL (South Australia—Leader of the Government in the Senate) (2.01 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That:

subdebate.1.para: (a) the routine of business set out in standing order 57(1)(b) not be proceeded with today; and
(b) the routine of business shall instead be:
(i) postponement and rearrangement of business,
(ii) a motion relating to Iraq,
(iii) at approximately 5 pm, Senator Humphries' first speech,
(iv) at the conclusion of Senator Humphries' speech, debate to continue on a motion relating to Iraq, and
(v) at 7.20 pm, adjournment proposed.
Question agreed to.

subdebate.2.para: Senator FERRIS (South Australia) (2.02 p.m.)—by leave—At the request of Senator Brandis, I move:

motion.para: That the Economics Legislation Committee be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate today from 4.30 pm, to take evidence for the committee's inquiry into the provisions of the Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme Bill 2003 and a related bill.

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate—

quote.para: (a) condemns Iraq's refusal, over more than 12 years, to abide by 17 resolutions of the United Nations Security Council regarding the threat it poses to international peace and security;
(b) recognises:

(i) that Iraq's continued possession and pursuit of weapons of mass destruction, in defiance of its mandatory obligations under numerous resolutions of the United Nations Security Council, represents a real and unacceptable threat to international peace and security,
(ii) that Iraq's behaviour weakens the global prohibitions on the spread of weapons of mass destruction, with the potential to damage Australia's security, and

(iii) that, as more rogue states acquire them, the risk of weapons of mass destruction falling into the hands of terrorists multiplies, thereby presenting a real and direct threat to the security of Australia and the entire international community;
(c) abhors:
(i) Iraq's continued support for international terrorism, and
(ii) the institutionalised widespread and grave abuse of the human rights of the Iraqi people over many years;

(d) notes that United Nations Security Council resolutions adopted under Chapter VII of the United Nations charter, in particular resolutions 678, 687 and 1441, provide clear authority for the use of force against Iraq for the purposes of disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction and restoring international peace and security to the region;

(e) endorses the Government's decision to commit Australian Defence Force elements in the region to the international coalition of military forces prepared to enforce Iraq's compliance with its international obligations under successive resolutions of the United Nations Security Council, with a view to restoring international peace and security in the Middle East region;

(f) expresses its unequivocal support for the Australian service men and women, and other personnel serving with the international coalition, its full confidence in them and the hope that all will return safely to their homes;
(g) extends to the innocent people of Iraq its support and sympathy during the military action to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction and the reconstruction period that will follow; and
(h) notes that the Government is committed to helping the Iraqi people, including through humanitarian assistance, to build a new Iraq at peace with itself and its neighbours.

speech.para: This morning the Prime Minister announced that Australia has joined a coalition led by the United States which intends to disarm Iraq of its prohibited weapons of mass destruction. The government has now authorised our defence forces, which were predeployed in the gulf to acclimatise and contribute to the campaign to pressure Saddam Hussein into compliance, to take part in coalition operations. There is no more serious decision for any government than to commit its forces to military conflict abroad. Under our system, this decision lies with the executive of government—the cabinet. Nevertheless, it is appropriate that the parliament, at the first opportunity, have the chance to debate this motion. It is essential that the reasons for that decision be made plain to the representatives of the people and that they have a full opportunity to debate those reasons and record their views.

In 1991 the world judged that the Iraqi regime was a dangerous aggressor. In the interests of world peace and regional security, the community of nations required Iraq to surrender its offensive arsenal, its chemical and biological weapons and abandon its nuclear weapons program. Iraq agreed to comply. We have waited 12 years for it to action this commitment. On 8 November 2002 the United Nations Security Council passed resolution 1441, the 17th Security Council resolution on Iraq regarding the threat it poses to international peace and security. This resolution, which was adopted unanimously, gave Iraq a final opportunity to demonstrate immediate compliance with its disarmament obligations. Over the last four months, we have seen no evidence to suggest that Saddam Hussein is willing to comply with resolution 1441. He has offered up minor concessions but has not demonstrated that he is willing to declare or destroy Iraq's prohibited weapons programs. The government believe very strongly that Iraq's continued defiance of the community of nations presents a challenge which must be addressed.

It is inherently dangerous to allow a country such as Iraq to retain weapons of mass destruction, particularly in light of its past aggressive behaviour. If the world community fails to disarm Iraq, we fear other rogue states will be encouraged to believe that they too can have these most deadly of weapons and that the world will do nothing to stop them. As the possession of weapons of mass destruction spreads, so the danger of such weapons coming into the hands of terrorist groups multiplies. That is the ultimate nightmare which the world must take decisive and effective steps to prevent. Possession of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons by terrorists would constitute a direct, undeniable and lethal threat to Australia and its people.

The federal government's principal objective is the disarmament of Iraq. However, should military action be required to achieve this, it is axiomatic that such action will result in the removal of Saddam Hussein's regime. Early this morning, President Bush telephoned the Prime Minister and formally requested Australia's support and participation in a coalition of nations who are prepared to enforce the Security Council's resolutions by all necessary means. This request was subsequently considered and agreed to by the cabinet.

In a speech around midday today Australian Eastern Standard Time, President Bush delivered an ultimatum to the Iraqi leadership: Saddam Hussein and his sons must leave Iraq within 48 hours or face military conflict. Nobody wants a military conflict. The world has for years tried other means but to no avail. We cannot walk away from the threat that Iraq's continued possession of weapons of mass destruction constitutes to its region and the wider world.

In the final analysis, the absolute conviction of the government is that disarming Iraq is necessary for the long-term security of the world and is therefore manifestly in Australia's national interest. The events of the last four months, Iraq's history and 12 years of defiance have convinced the Prime Minister and the government that the only way to deal with this challenge is by force. Sadly, the government is not surprised that it should have come to this. Force has been the only language that Saddam Hussein's regime has ever understood.

For 12 years, Saddam Hussein has forced his nation to endure stringent economic sanctions and pariah status rather than give up his weapons of mass destruction. The presence of weapons inspectors has hindered and irritated him, but it has never stopped his weapons programs. Even during the first four years of weapons inspections, when the inspectors perceived they were making real progress, Iraq continued to develop and successfully conceal biological weapons. Luckily, a series of defectors blew the whistle on some of Iraq's prohibited weapons programs, forcing the Iraqi regime to reveal one of the most sophisticated and expansive offensive biological programs in the world. We cannot always expect to be so lucky. Inspectors were ordered out of Iraq before they could finish dismantling the program. The available intelligence indicates that, since the departure of inspectors in 1998, Saddam has continued to work on his chemical and biological capabilities and maintained his nuclear aspirations.

Even under the threat of force he has only engaged reluctantly in token, piecemeal destruction of weapons and he continues to deny the existence of weapons programs. Even with over 200,000 coalition troops massed at his borders, he quibbles about how interviews are to be conducted with his scientists and how many of the reconnaissance aircraft supporting the inspectors can fly at any one time. After 12 years he does not believe that the international community has the will to act. He has made a terrible error of judgment.

For 12 years, the international community has been trying to get him to relinquish his prohibited weapons programs, as required by the cease-fire which ended the Gulf War. Australia has been an active participant in this process. During those 12 years, there has rarely been a time when Australian defence personnel have not been deployed in the gulf—in 1990 to enforce sanctions, in 1991 for Operation Desert Storm, in 1998 to support Operation Desert Fox and, throughout, an almost continuous presence with the Multinational Interdiction Force. Now we join with the coalition in an attempt to bring this longstanding conflict to an end, once and for all.

This will be difficult. Saddam Hussein is married to his weapons of mass destruction. He will never give them up willingly. Militarism and aggression are the foundations of his regime. If you doubt this, consider his actions against Iraqi Kurds and the Shia majority, particularly the Marsh Arabs; the estimated 400,000 combatants and civilians who lost their lives in the war that followed his invasion of Iran; and the 100,000 killed when he invaded Kuwait. Since Saddam Hussein came to power in 1979, more than one million people have died in the internal conflict and wars he has generated. Intelligence analysis tells us that Saddam Hussein considers these weapons programs to be essential both for internal repression and to fulfil his regional ambitions. No doubt he looks to a time when the world will be distracted by other events and he can use this arsenal to bully and coerce his neighbours and to dominate the Middle East.

Iraq's continued defiance represents a threat to the delicate balance which supports nonproliferation. It is no idle speculation that other countries in the region, perceiving this threat, might decide that their own security requires that they develop a significant chemical, biological or even possibly nuclear arsenal to deter attack from Iraq. Moreover, other rogue states would be tempted to ignore the international conventions on arms control, which Australia and others have so painstakingly built over the last 30 years, and would feel they could get away with developing similar weapons programs. This is proliferation. We know the lessons of history: the more nations that have these weapons the more likely they are to be used. That is why we fear proliferation. And we are very concerned about the potential for the proliferation of these weapons in our own region.

That these weapons may become commonplace in the arsenals of sovereign states is frightening enough, but it would be a nightmare for the international community if they were to find their way into the hands of terrorists. And we have every reason to be concerned about the expansion and increasing sophistication of international terrorist networks. We know as a matter of fact that terrorist networks such as al-Qaeda want to obtain weapons of mass destruction. They are actively seeking them. They desire them because of their potency. With such weapons at their disposal, terrorists could target entire cities or regions. Their victims would not number in the hundreds, or the thousands, but potentially millions. The Prime Minister has not claimed that Iraq has yet provided al-Qaeda with weapons or assistance on developing effective delivery systems. But, given Iraq's history, its preparedness to use these weapons on civilians as well as military targets, its links with other terrorist organisations, its tolerance of an al-Qaeda presence in Baghdad and al-Qaeda's desire, the Prime Minister and the government consider it imperative that the opportunity be removed.

Twelve years ago the community of nations determined that Iraq could not be permitted to develop and possess weapons of mass destruction. Today's security environment reinforces that judgment. Of course our alliance with the United States is also a factor—unapologetically so. The crucial long-term value of the US alliance should always be a factor in any major national security decision taken by Australia. America has given very strong leadership to the world on the issue of Iraq. The Security Council would not have become re-energised at the task of disarming Iraq had it not been for the United States. We support the American position because we share their concerns.

Alliances are two-way processes and, where we are in agreement, we should not leave it to the United States to do all the heavy lifting just because they are the superpower. To do so would undermine one of the most important relationships we have. In an increasingly globalised and borderless world, the relationship between Australia and the United States will become more and not less important.

Armed conflict is a terrible thing. Even though the Prime Minister's ultimate responsibility is for the security of the Australian people, he is conscious of the dangers military action will pose for Iraq's civilian population. But, when you put human suffering into the balance on this issue, there is a powerful case that human suffering will, in fact, be even greater if Saddam Hussein is left in power. Perhaps it is enough to note that, in 1991, the Security Council thought it necessary to pass resolution 688, which demands that the Iraqi regime cease its repression of its people. In April last year, the UN Commission on Human Rights adopted a resolution condemning:

quote.para: ... the systematic, widespread and extremely grave violations of human rights and of international humanitarian law by the Government of Iraq, resulting in an all-pervasive repression and oppression sustained by broad-based discrimination and widespread terror ...

speech.para: The regime's hallmarks are summary and arbitrary executions, the use of rape as a political tool, enforced disappearances, arbitrary arrest and detention, widespread and systematic torture, and maintaining of decrees prescribing cruel and inhuman punishment as the penalty for offences. The Prime Minister does not make these points for effect but to demonstrate that the short-term future for many, if not most, Iraqi civilians is neither secure nor peaceful, regardless of whether Iraq is subject to military action or not.

The government is, of course, deeply disappointed that the Security Council has been unable to maintain a unity of purpose on the issue of Iraq. The strong position taken last year, clearly articulated in resolution 1441, was that Iraq was being given one final chance to disarm, one final chance to show its immediate willingness to meet the terms of the cease-fire agreed in April 1991. The goal of 1441 was immediate and complete disarmament, not simply the return of weapons inspectors. That is merely an issue of process. A further resolution by the Security Council demonstrating that it was galvanised to take action might have, just might have, persuaded Saddam Hussein to take the steps necessary to achieve a peaceful solution to this conflict.

The position articulated by those opposed to action is fundamentally flawed. They recognise that the threat of military action has been the only way to elicit a positive response from Iraq. Yet they squander the leveraging power of a military force by clearly demonstrating they are never prepared to actually use it. This strategy not only is illogical but ignores the practical reality: it is not possible to keep our forces in the gulf on alert indefinitely.

The government does not accept that the only thing required to achieve complete and comprehensive disarmament is more time. If Iraq had cooperated actively and openly over the last four months, we would support a longer implementation timetable. That is not the case. The regime have continued to lie and obfuscate, making only token gestures of cooperation. They have not given the slightest indication that they intend to fully disarm and abandon their prohibited weapons programs.

We wanted the inspectors to do their job, but we have never accepted that they should have to play the role of detective. They have neither the skills nor the powers to fulfil this role effectively. Their presence inhibited Saddam's weapons programs, but the presence of inspectors alone could never have delivered total and complete disarmament in the face of Iraqi defiance and duplicity. (Extension of time granted) A peaceful path to disarmament could only have been achieved if the Iraqi regime had been truly committed to disarming and worked in active cooperation with the inspection teams. Iraq had to demonstrate it wanted to disarm. It was always a question of attitude.

We reject totally the argument put by France and by some other countries that the presence of inspectors will lead, over the passage of time, to disarmament. We cannot and will not ignore the experience of the last 12 years. We believe that the time has come to disarm Iraq, by force if necessary. We are participating in the US led coalition to achieve this objective.

It is important to understand that the decision taken by the government is in accordance with the legal authority for military action found in previous resolutions of the Security Council. We supported and would have preferred a further Security Council resolution specifying the need for such action. But we did so to maximise the diplomatic and moral pressure on Iraq, not because we considered a new resolution to be necessary for such action to be legitimate.

Our legal advice, provided by the head of the Office of International Law in the Attorney-General's Department and the senior legal adviser to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, is unequivocal. The existing United Nations Security Council resolutions already provide for the use of force to disarm Iraq and restore international peace and security to the area. This legal advice is consistent with that provided to the British government by its Attorney-General.

Security Council resolution 678, adopted in 1990, authorised the use of all necessary means not only to implement resolution 660, which demanded Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, but also to implement all subsequent relevant resolutions and to restore international peace and security in the area. Resolution 687, which provided the cease-fire terms for Iraq in April 1991, affirmed resolution 678. Security Council resolution 1441 confirms that Iraq has been and remains in material breach of its obligations—a point on which there is unanimous agreement, including by the Leader of the Opposition.

Iraq's past and continuing breaches of the cease-fire obligations negate the basis for the formal cease-fire. Iraq has, by its conduct, demonstrated that it did not and does not accept the terms of the cease-fire. Consequently, we have received legal advice that `the cease-fire is not effective and the authorisation for the use of force in Security Council 678 is reactivated'. It follows, so the Prime Minister and government are advised, that referring to the use of such force against Iraq as `unilateral' is wrong. Any informed analysis of the Security Council resolutions leads to this conclusion.

We note that the former Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade under the Keating government, Mr Michael Costello, has reached the same conclusion. The use of military force is already authorised by the United Nations. This advice is not new. Our deployment of forces to the gulf in 1998, in support of Operation Desert Fox, was undertaken on the same basis. The Clinton administration clearly understood and argued, as the Bush administration does now, that existing Security Council resolutions clearly allow for the use of military force.

talk.start.para: —Are you going to table the legal advice?

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —I table, for the benefit of honourable senators, Australian legal advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, legal advice provided to the British government by its Attorney-General and the transcript of an interview with Mr Michael Costello, former Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade under the Keating government. I hope that satisfies Senator Bolkus.

speech.para: Australia and the other members of the coalition are therefore still acting under the authority of the United Nations Security Council resolutions. We continue to regard the United Nations as the most important framework the world has to achieve a secure and peaceful world. Our commitment to the UN is perhaps personified by the 1,200 ADF personnel who are currently serving in the Blue Beret all around the world.

The government is extremely disappointed that the Security Council has been unable to demonstrate the necessary resolve to confront Iraq's continued defiance of the United Nations. We consider that it is critical for the United Nations to remain fully engaged on the issue of Iraq and take responsibility for coordinating the humanitarian and reconstruction support which will be required once the military conflict has been resolved. Just as we believe action against Saddam Hussein's regime is in our nation's best interest, so too we believe it is clearly in our interest to help rebuild a stable and prosperous Iraq. To that end, the government will make a significant contribution to that reconstruction effort.

talk.start.para: —What happened to democracy in all of this?
—Order! Senator Sherry and Senator Ian Macdonald, please come to order.

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —We hope that Iraq will be able to establish a government which has the support, and reflects the will, of its people. This is the only way to ensure that the wealth generated from its oil reserves, which belong to the people of Iraq, is directed to achieving their wellbeing and prosperity. Australia will do everything in its power to encourage the establishment of a representative government.

speech.para: The government also wants to reassure Australia's Islamic community that our actions in Iraq are not an attack on Islam—one of the world's great faiths. This reassurance has been given to, and accepted by, President Megawati of Indonesia—the leader of the world's largest Islamic country. The Prime Minister reminds all Australians that, regardless of their views on the conflict in Iraq, our Islamic community, especially those people who have family or cultural ties to the Middle East, will especially need our compassion and our support over coming weeks. All Australians should ensure that it is offered.

As the Prime Minister has said before, it is also crucial for the stability of the region to address the seemingly intractable Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israel has no stauncher ally than Australia in the pursuit of its right to exist and the right to secure and internationally recognised borders. Australia also strongly supports the establishment of a secure and independent state for the people of Palestine. Australia urges Prime Minister Sharon and Chairman Arafat to embrace the road map to peace developed by the United States in close cooperation with Russia, the European Union and the United Nations. The Australian government is committed to doing everything in its power to encourage and support the Israeli and Palestinian governments to negotiate a resolution to this bloody conflict which has cost too many lives—too many innocent lives—and casts a shadow across the entire region.

But there will be no stability, no security, for the nations of the Middle East, and particularly the gulf, until Iraq is disarmed of its weapons of mass destruction totally and permanently. The engagement of our defence forces will be limited to the period of the conflict and to those elements already deployed—that is, the transport ship HMAS Kanimbla, which departed from Sydney on 23 January with approximately 350 people embarked, including Army detachments providing air defence and amphibious cargo transport craft; the special forces task group, including a Special Air Services squadron from Perth and special forces combat support elements, including specialist troops to deal with the threat of weapons of mass destruction, drawn from the newly established Incident Response Regiment; CH-47 troop-lift helicopters; a quick reaction force drawn from the Sydney based 4RAR Commando Unit; a squadron of 14 FA18 Hornet fighter aircraft; three C130 Hercules transport aircraft; an air forward command element responsible for coordinating air operations with coalition partners; two P3 patrol aircraft currently in the gulf supporting the war on terror; a Navy clearance diving team capable of locating, rendering safe and disposing of mines; and HMAS Anzac and HMAS Darwin, which are already in the Middle East, policing UN sanctions on Iraq.

Although as part of the coalition Australian forces will be under the operational control of the coalition commander, they will remain under Australian national command at all times. Australian commanders are bound by Australian rules of engagement and separate Australian targeting directives. The government has been mindful to ensure that the ADF retains the capability to continue to service our current commitments, including our contribution to the UN force in East Timor and to respond to any short-notice contingencies that may arise.

The deployment, although modest in terms of the size of the total coalition force, is a sizeable commitment for Australia. The 2,000 ADF personnel and maritime, land and air assets currently deployed to the Middle East are not a token contribution. Every one of our service men and women is precious to their families, to their loved ones and to their nation. The government want to say to the men and women of our Defence Force who are deployed with the coalition forces that we have the greatest confidence in their abilities and their judgment. They may be part of the Australian deployment or deployed while on exchange duties with our friends and allies. Our nation admires their courage and salutes their commitment to duty. They belong to the most professional armed forces in the world, and we are proud of their reputation. Their government and their military commanders have spared no effort and no expense to try to prepare them for the terrible reality of active service.

We are under no illusion: their mission is a difficult one and inevitably involves danger. All agree that the Iraqi regime is one of the most repressive and cruel in the world. It is in open defiance of the United Nations Security Council. No-one wants Saddam Hussein to keep and expand his arsenal of prohibited weapons. The Prime Minister and the government believe passionately that the efforts of our forces are vital to ensure the long-term security of Australia and our world. The cause is just. The action is legitimate. We pray that our forces and their coalition partners will make quick progress and that soon they will be home, safe and sound, reunited with those they love.

I know that our defence personnel could not function without the support and understanding provided by their loved ones—their families, their friends. It will be a difficult time for those at home. Sometimes it can be more stressful for those who wait than for those who are in the thick of action.

We ask that all Australians, regardless of whether they support our participation in the coalition to disarm Iraq or not, show their support for those who have been ordered to undertake this mission. Give special thought to their loved ones. Do your best to support and look after them. We all have a right to protest and to register our concerns, but we ask that those who do protest or wish to register concerns direct such protests to the government, to our leadership, to those who are responsible for the decision, not to those who are given the responsibility of carrying out the orders of government.

This decision has been taken in a world environment changed forever by the events of 11 September 2001. The world faces new and previously unknown menaces. Old notions of aggression and responses to aggression do not necessarily fit our new circumstances. Yet one thing remains constant: the responsibility of governments to protect their citizens against possible future attacks, wherever they may come from. I commend the motion to the Senate.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —I move an amendment to the motion before the Senate moved by the Leader of the Government, Senator Hill. I move:

speech.para: Omit all words after “That”, substitute “the Senate—

quote.para: (a) insists that Iraq must disarm under the authority of the United Nations (UN);

(b) believes that in the absence of an agreed UN Security Council resolution authorising military action against Iraq, there is no basis for military action to disarm Iraq, including action involving the Australian Defence Force;
(c) insists that there should be no commitment of Australian troops to a war in Iraq outside the authority of the UN;
(d) concludes that Australian involvement in a war in Iraq without UN authorisation is not in Australia's national interests nor in the interests of maintaining international peace and security; and
(e) expresses its confidence in our service men and women and its full support for them and their families”.

speech.para: Australia should not be involved in this war. This war is wrong, and today is a black day for Australia. Yesterday, on a small island in the Atlantic Ocean, without the sanction of the United Nations, three nations made a decision to go to war against Iraq. Australia was not one of them. Mr Howard, in fact, was not invited to attend. Australia is being dragged to war by the decisions of others. This is a sad moment in our history. For the first time ever, we are ignoring the will of the international community and the United Nations. This is the first time that Australia has gone to war in such circumstances. We say, clearly and categorically, our troops should be brought home now. Mr Howard has dragged Australians into an avoidable war against their will and against the national interest.

The implications of this war will reverberate across the globe. It will make Australia less safe not more safe. Our natural inclination is for bipartisanship, so it takes an awful lot of provocation for us not to offer it. But the case for war has not been made. No credible link between Iraq and al-Qaeda has yet been established. It has not been established that Iraq's weapons pose an immediate threat to Australia and our allies. We believe that it is morally wrong to go to war when a peaceful solution is possible. Many thousands of innocent people may be killed by this war, and these are human beings not `collateral damage'.

We have a clear moral duty to disarm Saddam Hussein peacefully. Weapons inspection is working, and we need to give it more time. For example, as of today 70 out of 120 al-Samud missiles have been destroyed. The world has been told that the weapons inspections are working.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Kemp! Order, Minister! Senator Kemp, please come to order. The Leader of the Government in the Senate was heard in relative peace, with very few interjections. I would hope those on my right would extend the same courtesy to the Leader of the Opposition.
—Hans Blix, the man who was charged by the world community to find these weapons and remove their threat, told the Security Council on 7 March:

quote.para: The destruction undertaken constitutes a substantial measure of disarmament—indeed, the first since the middle of the 1990s. We are not watching the breaking of toothpicks. Lethal weapons are being destroyed.

speech.para: Yet, in the face of this clear, public destruction of weapons, Prime Minister Howard and President Bush continue to dodge the issue of why they find the inspection process insufficient. With more time and the unanimous resolve of the United Nations, I believe, and the opposition believe, that Iraq could be disarmed peacefully. But of course any chance of a peaceful solution has been ruined.

There is no doubt that Saddam Hussein is a brutal dictator who must be disarmed. The question, of course, is: how? Labor strongly endorsed the United Nations Security Council decision in November last year to restart the weapons inspections process. We believe Saddam Hussein must be disarmed, but that should only be done through the legitimacy and the authority of the United Nations. To go to war now will damage relations with the nations of our region and weaken our ability to work constructively with moderate Islamic countries to stop terrorism against Australians. The implications of this war and the undermining of the authority of the United Nations are going to reverberate around the world. This war will make Australia less safe.

Taking unilateral action without UN authority sets a dangerous precedent for rogue states such as Libya and North Korea. It will weaken international arms control measures. It will encourage other nations to consider starting pre-emptive wars. The decision of the government to commit Australians and Australian troops to this war was made months ago. We did not need the overnight farce of a phone call from President Bush to Prime Minister Howard. The Prime Minister should just front up to the Australian people—he should have fronted up to the Australian parliament today and told the truth—and tell the truth: that the decision to go to war was made months ago. It was made months ago. It did not require the so-called emergency cabinet meetings or the phone calls from President Bush.

Over the past few weeks and months, the Prime Minister has consistently failed to tell the truth about taking us to war. Of course, this has been exposed on a number of occasions. Take, for example, the leaked memo from Mr Downer and the High Commissioner for New Zealand when Mr Downer said the troops could not be withdrawn from the gulf. Take, for example, President Bush's admission in the White House, much to be embarrassment of Prime Minister Howard, that Australia had signed up to the `coalition of the willing'. Of course, ONA officer Wilkie exposed that there is no link between Iraq and al-Qaeda.

The fact is that the Prime Minister committed Australia to war 12 months ago and work began on Australia's commitment last July. But the Prime Minister has never seen fit to say that to Australian Defence Force personnel or to the people of Australia. In signing up to this war the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has surrendered our sovereignty. Australia should never go to war just because we get a telephone call from the President of the United States. I do not care what commitments Mr Howard has made to the United States President, because his overriding commitment must be to the people of Australia. That is the overriding commitment of the Australian Prime Minister. As far as the Labor Party are concerned, we would never allow our defence and foreign policies to be determined by another country, and we never have.

Saddam Hussein must be disarmed. As I have said, the question is how. Labor has said consistently that that should be done through the United Nations. The United Nations is not perfect but, without it, the world would revert to the law of the jungle. The Secretary-General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, clearly addressed the issue of the legitimacy of unilateral action against Iraq when he said on 12 March:

quote.para: If action is taken without the authority of the Security Council the legitimacy and support for any such action will be seriously impaired.

speech.para: The Prime Minister has not addressed that issue in any of his statements. Instead he backs President Bush's unilateral first strike because, of course, they were going to lose the vote in the Security Council. What I want to know—and I think my colleagues want to know this too—is this: if the Prime Minister and all his cohorts say that a second United Nations resolution is so unnecessary, why did they campaign for it? Why did they argue for it? Why did they press for it? Why did they coerce for it as strongly as they did?

Labor set two conditions for supporting a war without United Nations Security Council backing: first, that a link be established between the September 11 attacks and Iraq and, second, that Iraq's weapons of mass destruction posed an immediate threat to Australia and her allies. Of course, neither of those conditions has been met. They have not been met by the United States, they have not been met by the United Kingdom and they have not been met by the United Nations. And, most importantly, they have not been met in any of the public statements, at any stage, that have been made by the Australian Prime Minister, Mr Howard. As a result, Labor will only support action if it is authorised by the United Nations Security Council.

We maintain our strong belief in following the United Nations route, where we have a say as part of the international community. Mr Howard, on the other hand, has surrendered our sovereignty and our independence to the President of the United States. We deeply value the American alliance, but it should never be the plaything of one prime minister or of one political party. We note that article 1 of the ANZUS alliance commits both Australia and the United States of America to resolving international conflict through the United Nations. Unfortunately, Mr Howard has been sounding more and more like the governor of the 51st state of the United States. He has not been sounding like the Prime Minister of Australia.

We say that Australian troops should be brought home. We have also clearly indicated that we would never have deployed those troops in the first place. Mr Crean, on behalf of the opposition, has said that if he were Prime Minister today those troops would be brought home. But I want to be very clear about this in the Senate today. Labor will argue that the government's policy is grievously wrong, and we will do everything we can to see if we can influence the Prime Minister to change and reverse his decision. But our thoughts are with the men and women of the Australian Defence Force. Labor will back those Defence Force personnel 100 per cent and we will also condemn anyone who seeks to criticise them. Our argument is with the government; it is not with ADF personnel. The ADF personnel in the gulf are obeying orders, as they must do in a democracy. One of the lessons of the Vietnam War is that opposition to a war should be directed towards the government of the day and the government only. But we say that the Prime Minister is treating Australian troops dishonourably. He did not respect the members of the ADF or the Australian people enough to tell them the truth about the predeployment or the commitment of troops to an American pre-emptive strike.

It is very valid to compare the current situation with what occurred in the Gulf War in 1991. The then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, understood the importance of the United Nations. In his ministerial statement to parliament on 21 August 1990, Mr Hawke said:

quote.para: As a self-reliant country, in the years ahead we may need to depend more and more on the principles of the United Nations Charter to protect our interests. We are not sending ships to the Gulf region to serve our allies; we are going to protect the international rule of law which will be vital to our security however our alliances may develop in the future.

speech.para: That statement was strongly supported at the time by the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson. We should have heard the same from the Prime Minister of this country today in this parliament. The then Labor government understood the importance of an independent foreign policy. Then Prime Minister Hawke did not pre-empt the United Nations; he defended its principles. In contrast, Mr Howard has undermined 50 years of bipartisan support for the United Nations and he is undermining our long-term security interests. Even at this stage, it is not too late for us to choose the path of peace and collective security through the United Nations.

Like most Australians, I am appalled that we find ourselves on the precipice of war—a position that Mr Howard has allowed himself to be bullied into. I urge the Prime Minister to change his mind but, of course, he has been set on war from the start and I doubt that he is interested. (Extension of time granted) The Prime Minister has misled the Australian people. He has dragged them into a war against their wishes and against their interests. As far as the opposition are concerned, we are not starry-eyed about the United Nations. It is not the most perfect of organisations, but it does provide international authority and reflect the will of the international community. What happens from now on sets a precedent. The question is: from this time on, what is there to stop other countries—other countries outside the authority of the United Nations—using force and using what no doubt will become known as Gulf War II as their precedent? This war is wrong. This war is not in Australia's national interest. I urge the Senate to support the amendment that I have moved on behalf of the opposition to the motion moved by the government.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats express our opposition to the motion moved by the government. In amongst the sickening hypocrisy, duplicity, fabrication and sophistry of the Prime Minister's statement there was one thing from the Prime Minister today which the Democrats agree with, and that is that we must not direct our opposition and anger at the government's decision towards our troops or our defence personnel that are still in Australia. The Democrats strongly urge all Australians to express their opposition directly to the Howard government, the people responsible—his cabinet and his gutless bunch of backbenchers that have lined up behind him dancing to the US President's tune.

speech.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!
—It is about time you guys had some backbone and stood up for Australia.
—Senator Bartlett, I ask you to withdraw that unparliamentary remark.
—Which one? `Backbone'?
—You know the word I refer to.

—I am not sure which word, but I am willing to withdraw as you request. This is a clear indication that we have not one person amongst the coalition parties who is willing to stand up—stand up for Australia, stand up for the majority of the population and stand up against what many of them know is clearly wrong and clearly not in Australia's interests. In a Newspoll today, 71 per cent of Australians indicated they are opposed to war without United Nations sanction. This would have to be the first time in history that a government has deployed our troops in the face of such massive public opposition. The government is betraying our defence personnel by putting them in such an untenable position.

speech.para: It is the first time in history, undoubtedly, that Australia will have deployed troops without parliamentary support, because this motion authorising or supporting the deployment will not be supported by the Senate, in the same way that the Senate has already condemned the Prime Minister over a month ago for his appalling handling of this crucial issue. This would be the first time in history that Australia—which has a proud record of standing up and joining in support of many conflicts—has started a war and that we have been part of an aggressive invasion. That is a great shame for our nation.

The Democrats condemn the federal government's decision. We do not support the motion put forward by the Prime Minister and his representative in this place, Senator Hill. We support the amendment put forward by Senator Faulkner. To those we will add an amendment of our own that we believe will strengthen the statement of the Senate. I will speak to that amendment once I am sure it has been circulated. Australia is now one of a tiny number of rogue states starting an illegal war without justification and in the face of widespread global opposition. It is untenable for Australia to argue now about following international law, about following due precedent, about following due process or about working with the global community when we have so clearly walked away from the global community, walked away from the peace disarmament process and simply followed and been apologists for aggressive US militarism.

Despite the financial and other blackmail used by the United States against nations on the Security Council, that council would not pass a resolution authorising force. To provide a few bits of legal sophistry to suggest that it is supported by international law to deploy troops is to ignore the statements and debates made to the Security Council by global representatives, including the US ambassador. This is the level of deception and deceit that we are reduced to in the arguments of world leaders in the face of blatant commonsense. Resolution 1441 was quite clearly adopted as an alternative to military action. Even the US ambassador to the Security Council said upon its adoption that the resolution contained no `hidden triggers' and no `automaticity' with the use of force. It had no automatic authorisation for the use of force, and the United States ambassador made that clear at the time. It is that sort of doublespeak—going back and changing their position as if it is some sort of warped version of Nineteen Eighty-Four and just pretending that we have all forgotten what people said a month or two ago—that shows how tragic and appalling this debate is. It is no wonder that we are not able to argue credibly and win the support of the Australian people—let alone the global community—for this action, because they know that it does not stack up and is not consistent with the arguments put forward by the Prime Minister. His justifications have changed day after day as he has desperately tried to follow the ever-changing position of the United States administration.

Many, many experts in the Australian community—former defence chiefs, former heads of the defence department, former military chiefs with immense experience, former diplomats, members of the defence community, members of the security community and members of the veterans community—have displayed widespread opposition and condemnation of the approach and policy of this government. Today former Australian ambassador to the United Nations, our last ambassador to the Security Council, Richard Woolcott, called this war `a tragic culmination of a flawed policy', `a deception of the Australian people' and `an unnecessary military involvement'. He said:

quote.para: This is the worst and most damaging foreign policy decision in half a century or more. It is gross deceit to say this war is in Australia's national interest. Clearly it is not.

speech.para: The Democrats and the majority of the Australian community have consistently opposed this war for many reasons, including that it is not in Australia's national interest. We call on the Governor-General, Peter Hollingworth, to take the opportunity as commander-in-chief of the naval and military forces of the Commonwealth to refuse to sign the order for the commitment of troops. The Prime Minister has failed to answer the many questions about the legality and morality and human and economic costs of this war. The Democrats alone have put over 100 questions to the government about the Australian and United States approaches to Iraq, but they have given no answer. We have asked questions over many months about the US and UK role in originally arming Iraq and supporting Hussein. We have asked about how they intend to conduct this war, including why they still will not rule out the use of nuclear weapons and why our Prime Minister, despite a specific resolution of the Senate, refused to get a guarantee that nuclear weapons or chemical weapons would not be used by the attacking forces.

We have asked for their figures on the war budget—we know they are drawn up—but they refuse to answer these questions. The Prime Minister's speech to the Press Club last week was about defence of US militarism, not about Australia's security. He has repeatedly made the ridiculous claim that a UN resolution authorising force would bring about peace. Yet again today he has continued with his hypocrisy in pointing out the immense suffering of the Iraqi people at the hands of Saddam Hussein whilst ignoring his own record of deploying Australia's military forces and spending hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars trying to prevent the victims of that regime from seeking protection here in Australia. It is the height of hypocrisy that the Prime Minister argues that the Iraqi people are oppressed by this regime and gives examples of torture yet continues to try and prevent protection for the victims of that regime here in Australia. Even today, hundreds of Iraqis are in detention in Australia with continual psychological pressure being put on them to return to such a regime. That is the level of hypocrisy we have got.

talk.start.para: —Who are not refugees.

—We hear from the government benches that they are not refugees. Any suggestion that they are not going to be in a situation of immense danger is hypocritical. We have more human rights conventions than just refugee conventions, let alone the basic humanity of not sending people back to face certain suffering, torture and persecution. We are conducting that on them here, day after day, as we speak, in detention centres around Australia, trying to make their life so unbearable that they will choose death in Iraq rather than rotting to death in Australia. Yet this government dares to argue humanity as its justification.
—Where did you get this from?

—This is the truth, and we see it every day. You have shown a pathetic inability to tell the truth. People starve, suffer and literally go insane in our detention centres, until they get forced back to Iraq, yet you come in here and argue humanity. That sort of pathetic hypocrisy is the reason the Australian people do not believe you and do not trust you.

speech.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my right will come to order. Senator Bartlett, will you address your remarks through the chair.

—Any time the Prime Minister gets up, Mr President, and argues in favour of humanity, given his own record of inhumanity towards Iraqis fleeing suffering, he is not believed by the Australian people, and no wonder. That sort of hypocrisy is something that is impossible to stomach, and the Australian people in their millions today are feeling sick in their stomach about where this Prime Minister has led them. It is an absolute disgrace. He has failed to pursue every peaceful option. Even somebody like the Pope—who you people would love to grab hold of for your own political purposes—has quite blatantly said that peaceful options are still available and that we have a moral obligation to pursue peaceful options. But you will ignore that and go with the US militarists any day of the week and tie yourselves to their bootstraps, thinking that, somehow or other, that is in Australia's national interest. How pathetic can you get! Clearly, there are still options for peace, yet the Prime Minister has turned his back on these. He has turned his back on peace and signed Australia up, for the first time in our history, as an aggressor nation, launching an attack. It is a day of shame that we are put in this situation.

speech.para: It is also a major problem and of major significance that this government is clearly willing to act in breach of international law. We should not be surprised, because in recent times this government has clearly waived with disdain, and thumbed its nose at, UN conventions year after year, and it has come out and publicly attacked UN human rights bodies as having no say in what Australia does. So, in some ways, it is no surprise. It is the end outcome after you have allowed a government to get away with thumbing its nose at one particular UN convention, saying, `We're going to ignore that one; it doesn't matter.' Once it has set that precedent and said, `The UN's processes don't matter; the multilateral framework doesn't matter; international law and conventions don't matter,' this is the end outcome. You get nations saying, `We'll do what we want. We don't care what the conventions are, what the rules are and what the law is.' That is the situation that we have put ourselves in.

talk.start.para: —Like Iraq.

—Senator Boswell says, `Like Iraq.' Exactly! That is the situation that we are putting ourselves in. That is exactly why we are unable to hold our heads high and say that we will follow international law and conventions. We are now not able to validly criticise other nations that do not do so. It is clear that weapons inspections were working. It is clear that the United Nations resolution specifically authorised weapons inspectors to go and see if a peaceful disarmament were possible. But when they came back and said, `Yes, it's possible. Yes, we've got disarmament. Yes, we're moving forward,' it was the answer you did not want to hear, so you just ignore that and attack anyway. That is the most blatant example of how the real agenda all along was not disarmament.
—Saddam Hussein kicked them out, remember?

—Who is kicking them out now? The weapons inspectors are being kicked out of Iraq now by the United States. The United States went to Kofi Annan and said, `Get your people out.' It is the United States that has led to weapons inspectors being removed from Iraq. It is the United States directly, via their actions in the last 24 hours, that has led to the removal of weapons inspectors, despite the fact that those inspectors, authorised by the United Nations, have specifically said that they were making progress and that they believed that peaceful and complete disarmament could occur within months. It did not matter. The US did not care and did not want to wait. What a great reason for Australia to launch into war—that is, the US President got impatient. Pathetic!

speech.para: In addition, this conflict is likely to cost Australians billions of dollars. We will see the consequences of this come the budget in May when the funding that is needed for health, education and environment is not there because, on top of these millions of dollars wasted trying to keep Iraqi refugees out of the country, we are now spending millions more to go and kill civilians directly.

All Australians will pay in many ways. If it were only the financial cost, that would be the least of our problems. This decision has made Australia a less secure and less safe place for our children and for future generations. That is the great irresponsibility of this government's actions. Supposedly in the name of war on terror, despite no link between Saddam Hussein and the situation in Bali or September 11, undoubtedly we are now led into a situation where we will be a bigger terrorist target. We will have inflamed terrorist recruiting agents and organisations around the world, and our actions will lead to greater global instability and to a breakdown of the multilateral frameworks for dealing with issues of disarmament and global security. That is the outcome: a less secure planet, a less secure region, a less secure nation. Australians will be less secure and less safe. Brilliant policy! But George Bush likes it, so I guess that makes it all okay.

The other question is: where will it end? What happens next, if this is justified? We are now signed up lock, stock and barrel with the United States's foreign policy and military policy. As the defence white paper update released last month specifically showed, this government is not only willing but eager to continue to play a military combat role that is politically outside the United Nations multilateral framework and far beyond our own Asia-Pacific region.

The white paper acknowledges that the Australian government will now need to move towards cooperating, and developing its defence forces in a way where we can work more closely with the United States in their future military operations. So not only is today a potential disaster for Australia, but we may be signing ourselves up for the long term. Whatever nation is next in the sights of the absolute neoconservative hawks that are running the agenda in the US, we will be there—we will be in Iran, we will be in somewhere else in the Middle East. That is where we will be. Instead of playing a role in our region, with peacekeeping forces working cooperatively with other countries, addressing real security threats to our country, we are off on global pursuits with the United States and their new world order. That is what we have signed up to. That is what our Prime Minister has signed us up to. That is why this statement and this motion by the government are so abhorrent and will be strongly opposed by the Democrats.
In addition to the amendment moved by Senator Faulkner, which the Democrats support, I move:
At the end of the amendment, add:

quote.para: (f) is of the view that the decision of the Australian Government to commit Australian troops to an invasion of Iraq is clearly being done without the authorisation or support of the UN Security Council;
(g) condemns and opposes the decision of the Australian Cabinet and the President of the United States of America (Mr Bush) to commit troops to an imminent attack on Iraq;
(h) calls for the Australian troops to be withdrawn and returned home immediately; and

(i) calls on the Australian and the United States governments to continue the policy of containment and disarmament through weapons inspections under the existing UN Security Council authority, as proposed by the governments of France, Germany and Russia.

speech.para: The policy of containment and disarmament through weapons inspections under the existing United Nations Security Council authority was clearly working effectively without causing mass death. I believe this amendment will give added strength to the Senate's decision here. The option is still there for the government, if it had any backbone, to turn around, to step back from the brink and to stand up in Australia's interests rather than the interests of the military elite in the United States. Clearly we are not seeing that. This is a massive failure of the Prime Minister and the government to meet their responsibility to stand up in Australia's interests and ensure a secure future for Australians and future generations.

It is a tragedy. It is one that millions of Australians are appalled at as we speak. I urge all Australians to continue to voice their opposition firmly—as strongly as possible— but peacefully to all of those who are responsible for this travesty. We will all, as a nation, pay the consequences of it and we need to make sure that those that have inflicted this decision upon our nation pay the consequences themselves. It should not go unremarked or unpunished. It should be strongly opposed. The Democrats will continue to oppose it and we urge all others to do so, in whatever way possible.

We have a government now which we cannot even be confident will follow an act legally, given its willingness to breach international law. That is a severe situation for our nation to be in and it is a severe one for the Senate to consider, in terms of how it deals with the ongoing governance of this country, as the Senate has an important role to play. This issue will obviously be an ongoing one and the debate will continue. I urge all Australians to continue to participate in that debate.

talker.name: Boswell, Sen Ron
Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —From the polls today, it appears that the only ones that are going to get punished by the electorate—and severely punished—are the Democrats, who scored one per cent from the Australian population. I would have thought that that was real punishment, as they went head to head with One Nation, who also had one per cent. The Greens are streaking away, at eight per cent, making dog's meat out of them.

speech.para: The Prime Minister today announced the deployment of troops into Iraq. He brought that position to the party room, where it was endorsed unanimously. We are now debating that resolution, which has now been put as a motion before the parliament, as the Prime Minister said it would be, giving the people in the political parties, who represent other people, the right to debate that resolution. This is probably the most difficult decision that the Prime Minister, the government and the parliament have ever had to face. I have been here 20 years and it is the most difficult decision that I have seen. I have seen some very hard decisions having to be made, but this one is the most difficult. I certainly do not envy the Prime Minister having to make this decision. But I have said it before and I will say it again: the easiest thing to do in this world is to do nothing. It does not require any thought, you do not have to take any risk, you just have to switch your mind into neutral and hope that everything is going to turn out all right. But that is not the Australian way and it is not the coalition's way of doing things.

This is a courageous decision, not one that was taken because of popularity, but one that was taken against the polls. It was taken because the Prime Minister, the cabinet and the parties believed it was the right decision. We have tried to solve this situation that we have found ourselves in—the matter of Iraq—over the last three or four months. The coalition of Australia, Britain and America have bent over backwards to do everything possible to solve this diplomatically. We might well have done it if it had not been for the French, who have intervened. If they had only stuck with the things that they do well, like cooking, we probably would have been able to come to some diplomatic resolution.

The French have been very good at belting the hell out of the South Pacific by exploding bombs, but when it comes to war they have never been particularly successful. They have had to be rescued on two occasions by the Americans. As my friend and colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald said, they also had to rely on the Americans to get them out of Indochina, and I think he will say more on that when he speaks. Twice the Americans had to come in and save France and then later the French completely turned their backs and walked away—that is gratitude for you. The fact is, if you have the French saying that they will veto any proposal to disarm Iraq using military force, before the resolution even hits the table, you are giving the Iraqis comfort and sustenance and you are nurturing and sustaining their president, Mr Hussein. You are also saying to the smaller nations on the Security Council that there is no point taking a vote as it is just going to be vetoed. Why would anybody put their hand up in that situation? Perhaps if the French had not interfered, we would have seen more decisive action from the UN Security Council and a strong 18th resolution— we have already passed 17 resolutions. Then Saddam Hussein would have seen that the game was up and surrendered his weapons of mass destruction before the deployment of troops was necessary. That was a possibility before the French intervened and poured buckets over everyone; after that, there was no possibility of that outcome.

This conflict is nothing new. It began in 1989. I can remember speaking from the other side of the Senate when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. I remember the speeches well. The disarmament of Iraq that is going to take place over the next few days is supported and underpinned by no less than 17 United Nations resolutions dating back to the Gulf War in the 1990s. In 1991, when Saddam Hussein was in full retreat and his armies were surrendering to the press corps, television crews or anybody else they could find, Saddam Hussein agreed to disarm and to provide the United Nations with proof of disarmament. That agreement was covered by UN resolutions 678 and 687. Subsequently, there have been 17 UN resolutions to date, including the most recent and stringent resolution, resolution 1441. The Gulf War ended 12 years ago. We have had weapons inspectors in Iraq from time to time. They have continually been led on a wild goose chase around Iraq. We have seen very few results. We have seen Mr Butler, who was a weapons inspector, go in there and confidently proclaim that there were weapons of mass destruction and that they had to be found. The inspectors received no support and were, in fact, evicted from the country.

It is only when Saddam Hussein is directly under threat that he is prepared to act. He allows a dribble of information out as a public relations exercise, he obfuscates and he tries to hold the line. Kofi Annan, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, has said that without the pressure applied by the United States and Britain in recent times weapons inspectors would not have been allowed back into Iraq. How long are we expected to wait? It has now been 12 years. How long are we expected to stand by and watch people being exterminated in Iraq? Saddam Hussein has become an expert at brinkmanship. He is more interested in public relations than in actual disarmament. He cannot disarm; he cannot control his minorities unless he has those weapons of mass destruction. He has perfected the art of doing just enough to keep in front of the game and keep his corrupt regime afloat while continuing to defy the rest of the world over his possession of weapons of mass destruction.

There are 6,500 chemical bombs; 550 shells filled with mustard gas; 360 tonnes of bulk chemical warfare agents, including 1.5 tonnes of the deadly nerve agent VX; 3,000 tonnes of precursor chemicals, 300 tonnes of which could only be used for the production of VX gas; 8,500 litres of anthrax; 30,000 special munitions designed to carry biological agents and 650 kilograms of bacterial growth media for use in the production of anthrax which are unaccounted for. If that does not provide a threat to the whole of the world then people are just not concentrating. That is a massive storehouse of death. No-one has been able to find that material or account for it to date. Apart from the al-Samoud 2 missiles and some empty chemical warheads, nothing has been found. Where are all these missing items? Why has Saddam Hussein failed to give them up? Why have none of the inspectors been able to provide solid evidence of their decommissioning or destruction? We have not had any of those questions answered.

We have not heard what the Democrats or the opposition propose to do about this storehouse of death in Iraq—`Just wash it under the table; don't worry about it. If we don't worry about it, it won't happen.' My experience of life is that it will happen. I am a great believer in Murphy's law: it always happens, and at the worst possible time. Where are all of these missing items? No-one knows anything about them. We know that they were there—we have evidence of that—but we have no evidence that they were decommissioned or destroyed.

Every night Saddam Hussein appears on television as a smiling, benevolent dictator. He has people in Iraq so terrified that they have to give him some form of endorsement. There is no country in this world more oppressed than Iraq. Since he came to power, he has waged war on his neighbour Iran and has destroyed one million people, both Iranians and his own people the Iraqis. He has gassed his own minority groups, including the Kurdish people, and he has destroyed the marshlands and the marsh people. I understand that that was the most beautiful piece of Iraq, but he has put canals right through it and destroyed it. In addition, 200,000 people have disappeared from jails and have not been heard from again and four million people have chosen to flee the country. Yet we still stand by and say, after 12 years, that we will give him another go so that he can kill another million people, gas another Kurd or Arab minority and destroy 200,000 more people in his jails.

In the case of Kuwait, the world said, `Enough is enough,' and intervened. This is no benevolent dictator. This man has the worst record on human rights in the history of the world. Saddam Hussein has killed members of his own political party, not to mention his two sons-in-law. For those reasons alone we should want to remove Saddam Hussein, but there are more reasons. There are further implications that must be addressed. How does the world stop people like Saddam Hussein, who has such an atrocious record, if we continue to ignore them and give them 12 years to crib and cheat for a further time? What sanctions can be placed on dictators who go down this path of genocide, murder and rape if we are not able to discipline these evil people?

Since September 11 and the Bali bombings, we have recognised that we are living in a different world—a world where terrorism exists. We have learned the hard way, through losing so many young Australians in Bali, that terrorism must be addressed in all of its forms. We cannot allow terrorists and rogue states like Iraq to thumb their noses at the rest of the world by developing and producing chemical weapons and weapons of mass destruction. If the world fails to address the fact that rogue states like Iraq have weapons of mass destruction, we leave the door open for the proliferation of these devastating weapons in that country and in other countries throughout the world. It becomes only a matter of time before terrorists gain access to weapons of mass destruction. How does the world rein in North Korea or any other rogue state if the authority that we have is ignored and if no-one addresses problems like Iraq? We are setting ourselves on a road to destruction. It just gives some of these small rogue states the go-ahead. It gives them a tick instead of bringing them back into line.

The defence of Australia relies on the ANZUS treaty. We have a standing army of around 75,000 people in the Australian Defence Force—that includes the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. It is not a large army by world standards. In fact, it is quite a small army. We have defence obligations to America, as they have to us. This is not the only reason for supporting America, but it is a significant one. Defence can never be a one-way street. We hope that we will never have to call on the ANZUS treaty for the defence of our own nation, but we cannot have it both ways. We cannot just let the Americans do all of the hard yards and not pull our weight. Australia has always been and is always prepared to lift our share of the load.

Unlike Mr Crean, who cannot bring himself to recognise that we need to do our share of the work, in 1998 Labor's former leader Mr Beazley supported an ADF forward deployment to put more pressure on Saddam Hussein. He recognised the importance of putting more pressure on Hussein and was prepared to bring bipartisan support for military deployment. Mr Beazley was prepared to support Australia pulling its weight when it came to preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. I am sad to say that it is unlikely that we will secure bipartisan support for this action. It is the first time that we will send troops into war without bipartisan support. Our troops deserve the support of the Australian people. They do not make the political decisions—they just carry them out. We know they will carry out their duties with all the diligence and skill that has traditionally been expected of and delivered by members of the Australian armed forces.

The situation is this: massive amounts of bacteria, chemicals, munitions, anthrax and other agents in Iraq have never been found or accounted for. We have one of the worst violators of human rights running the country in Iraq. Terrorism is now a fact of life. Australia has felt it, and many Australian families have felt it personally. Can we as Australians accept the threat of weapons of mass destruction falling into the hands of terrorists? The answer must be a resounding no. We have obligations under the ANZUS treaty. There are compelling reasons why we must stand by our obligations and disarm Saddam Hussein. In the long term, we cannot accept this threat to our way of life. Appeasement has never been successful. It did not work in Chamberlain's time and it never will work with people like Saddam Hussein. Any sign of weakness allows him to procrastinate further—it gives him strength.

There is no-one in this parliament who will get any joy out of this decision today, but I know that in the long term it is the correct decision. It would have been easier for the Prime Minister to walk away from this, but he has faced the reality of a leader and put the best interests of Australia first. It must have been the hardest decision that he has made or that any Prime Minister has to make—to deploy people into a war zone. However, it is important that we support the Prime Minister. He made the right decision, and I certainly give him all my support.

talk.start.para: —The Labor Party opposes today's decision for Australia to go to war with Iraq. Labor will not support it because we believe it is wrong. We believe the decision diminishes Australia and all Australians. Many people in this chamber have argued that war is the option of last resort. What we have seen today is the taking of a option well before reaching the last resort. The rush to war on the USA timetable has rejected the chance to peacefully disarm Saddam Hussein. No-one in this chamber would argue that Saddam Hussein is anything but evil. He ought to be disarmed, and successive Australian governments of both persuasions have supported the efforts of the United Nations to do so. That has been a bipartisan position, I think, across all political parties and groups inside this chamber. There is no support for Saddam Hussein or for his regime, and there is no argument that he has been a brutal dictator who has wreaked havoc on his people, but that does not mean that we must wage war on the Iraqi people.

speech.para: By taking this decision today, the Australian government has supported the pre-emptive strike doctrine that the USA has been advocating in the last year or so. It will lead to greater international instability, at the cost of Australia's national interests. This does not further Australia's national interests; it diminishes them. The response in the region to our government's actions will ensure that Australia's position—its standing— and trust in Australia will be severely diminished. Many of our neighbours are deeply concerned about the Australian government's commitment to join the USA in acting outside of the United Nations in declaring war on Iraq.

The Howard government has given up on the view of Australia having its own national interest in favour of unflinching and uncritical support for US foreign policy. We do not have an Australian foreign policy anymore in relation to Iraq; we just have a US foreign policy. I think there was nothing more demeaning for the Prime Minister or for Australia than seeing John Howard waiting by the phone for the call from George Bush to tell him what he, the USA President, in concert with the Prime Minister of Britain and the leaders of Spain and Portugal, had determined about Australia's commitment to war. When Bush rang, Howard jumped—and Australia was at war. I think that is demeaning to Australia and Australians and sets a very bad precedent that will come back to haunt us in years to come.

This decision undermines international law and the role of the UN. It is interesting that so far I have seen only five of 190 UN members actually commit to the coalition of the willing. This is not a broad based international movement; this is a very small group of countries who have determined to support the USA in its action against Iraq in the face of overwhelming international opinion against such action. We are out of step with the majority of our international neighbours who have made a decision that they would rather support the United Nations as the means to resolve international disputes. They would rather support the multilateral resolution of disputes than endorse, as this decision does, the doctrine of pre-emptive strike, the doctrine that might is right and the position adopted by Australia that its relationship with the USA is the predominant determinant of its national interests. We say that Australia ought to determine its own national interests and have an independent foreign policy and that we should have pursued that in recent months.

Having failed to pursue an independent national foreign policy, we find ourselves answering George Bush's call for war in the affirmative. The Labor Party will have no part in it. The Labor Party believe that waging war on Iraq is wrong. We do not support it and we will oppose it. A peaceful solution was possible. The work of the weapons inspectors was proving to be effective, assisting in reducing the risk, and various commentators have assessed the risk from Iraq's weaponry as being significantly less than it was at the time of the Gulf War. We still believe that a peaceful solution is possible and, therefore, Labor cannot support this war.

Like most Australians, my thoughts turn to those who are now at risk due to this war. The people of Iraq, obviously, will be most at risk, and our thoughts go out to them.
