We hope that the casualties are minimal and that they suffer as little as possible. Our thoughts also turn to the troops of the coalition, especially the Australian troops, and their safety. The casualties of war and the people put at risk should be foremost in our minds. I suppose they are one of the major reasons why Labor does not support this action. In particular, our thoughts turn to the 2,000 ADF personnel who have already been deployed to the gulf—2,000 mainly young Australians whose lives have now been put at risk by this decision. This is the largest combat force since Vietnam, and it has been deployed to Iraq, a country that held very little political interest for this country until recent months.

In a previous debate on this issue I covered some of the strategic issues involved in this decision and I do not intend to canvass that ground again today. I want to concentrate on those ADF personnel who have been deployed. They are highly trained and highly capable personnel who, I am sure, will do Australia proud. I think all Australians join with us in wishing them well and hoping for their safe return. Certainly as Labor's defence spokesman, I offer them Labor support. I offer them our unflinching support that we will use all our endeavours to support them in whatever way we can. They will, as all Australians will, be affected by the severe political divide that has opened up in this country on this issue. You cannot get away from it. Many Australians oppose this war. The alternative government, the Australian Labor Party, opposes this war. The Australian Greens and the Australian Democrats oppose this war. There is huge opposition in Australia to the government's decision.

I do not underestimate the stress and the difficulty that places on Australian Defence Force personnel. They would much prefer to have bipartisan support for their actions. They would much prefer to be going to an action, such as in East Timor, where they had broad based public support. They would much prefer to be going in where they had UN endorsement for their actions. So they will be impacted by the political debate in Australia and that will make life harder for them. They remember the experiences of Vietnam. They have spoken to many veterans about it. I know it is uppermost in their minds.

Like all Australians, they share a range of political views on this conflict. The ADF personnel are no different to any other group of Australians. There are Labor voters and Liberal voters—even perhaps Green voters, Senator Brown—in the ADF. They share a range of political views about the morality and the legality of this deployment. They are, I know, concentrating on the issue of UN endorsement. While many are keen to exercise their skills and regard this as a good opportunity to do what they have trained for, they also understand the personal risks and the divisions that will occur in Australia as this debate plays out.

It is interesting that previously a lot of my colleagues have assumed that all in the military would be in favour of military action. It has been helpful that people like General Peter Gration, the former CDF, Admiral Alan Beaumont, also a former CDF, Admiral Mike Hudson, the former Chief of Navy, and Major General Peter Phillips from the RSL all signed a letter in September expressing their concern about the path the government was taking us down. I quote their response to our being involved in a non-UN endorsed action:

quote.para: It would constitute a failure of the duty of government to protect the integrity and ensure the security of our nation to commit any Australian forces in support of a US military offensive against Iraq without the backing of a specific UN security resolution.

speech.para: That is a very clear statement from former chiefs of the Defence Force reflecting their view about the government's decision to embark on a non-UN sanctioned military action, and that is a view that many in the ADF share. As I say, there is a range of opinion inside the ADF. I do not pretend to speak for them or say that they are of one mind, but they are very concerned about any decision to be involved in a military action that does not have UN sanction. It is an issue many of them have raised with me. It is a function of their involvement in previous UN actions, it is a function of the extremely good training we provide them with, which stresses the need to act in accordance with international law, and it is a function of their own integrity. There will be a great deal of concern about the government's decision to go ahead without UN sanction.

The divergence in political opinion in this country represents a huge challenge to the whole Australian community and the Australian political leadership. As the Labor Defence spokesman, I personally find it an enormous challenge, because we have to conduct this political debate in Australia without undermining the support for our troops who have been deployed into what will be a very dangerous war.

The Labor Party opposes the political decision to deploy those troops to war but supports the troops. That is not an easy thing to argue or articulate. But our argument is with the government. Our argument is with the decision by John Howard taken in June last year to sign up to the American military resolve to invade Iraq. We have been locked into this for a long time—we know that—but only today do we get the formal announcement. It is a challenge to make sure that the focus of the debate is on the political decision, is on the government and not on the Australian troops who are acting lawfully. The Australian troops have been deployed in accordance with Australian law by the elected government. Quite frankly, whatever this parliament decides, that remains true. I personally will not be voting for the government motion, but the fact remains that those troops have been deployed legally, and we support them.

I am reminded that I attended the final farewell of Australian troops at the so-called predeployment at Holdsworthy base in Sydney on 14 February. It was a farewell for the 4RAR Commandos and elements of the IRR. You could not meet a more impressive group of young men and women going off to represent Australia. They are incredibly skilled, intelligent and committed. They are a credit to Australia, a credit to the ADF and a credit to their families and friends. I had the opportunity to speak to them. There was obviously a great deal of anxiety and nervousness because they were soon to be deployed. Afterwards I got to speak to their families and a number of them came up to me and thanked me for the Labor Party's support for their position because I outlined that we continue to support the troops even though we oppose the deployment. A number of the parents in particular came and expressed their gratitude because they were concerned about the impact of this debate on their family members. They knew there was going to be huge debate in Australia over the war. They knew a lot of Australians were opposed to it and were concerned about their loved ones being the subject of that debate. I tried to reassure them that the debate was at a political level, that the debate was about the government decision. It was interesting that some of those family members actually opposed the war. Some of them said that they personally opposed the war but that they supported their son or daughter being legally deployed, as they were, by the government. It was an emotional and difficult experience for me but a valuable one.

The next day, like thousands of other Australians on 15 February, I attended the peace rally. With my family I attended the peace rally in Perth, where 10,000 people marched expressing their opposition to war and their support for peace. There were a lot of impressive young Australians at those rallies too, a lot of Australians who had made the commitment to support peace, to oppose war, to say that there is a better way of resolving conflict than bombing people. It was an honest expression of their view, which I shared. I had seen two sets of impressive young Australians on successive days—one at a farewell for the troops and one at a rally opposing the war. Some people might think I am a bit schizophrenic, but I think it reflected that I was proud of both groups of young Australians and proud of our society in that we can have these disagreements and debates. Some of the soldiers have made the point to me that one of the things they thought worth fighting for was democracy, that ability for our citizens to be able to freely express their point of view. That was a very difficult period for me, and I think it reflected the division and the complex nature of what we now confront as a community.

We want to support the Australian troops, but many of us do not want to support this war. We are going to have a very fierce political debate about this. Many of us are going to be not only vehemently opposed to the government's decision—will argue for its reversal, will argue for the withdrawal of troops—but also very strenuous in ensuring that the troops, the Australian Defence Force personnel, do not become the subject of that debate. They are deployed legally and in accordance with ADF procedures. We wish them well and we hope for their safe return. Certainly, from Labor's perspective, Graham Edwards and I will be doing all we can to ensure that we support them in every way possible, because they are acting under a legitimate decision of government. The deployment is legal.

I want to touch briefly on another issue that has been raised, because I think there has been some ill-informed debate about legality around the place. There is no doubt that there is a live debate about whether or not the decision to go to war is legal in terms of international law. That is a debate that is going to be held over the next few months and probably over the next 20 years, as international lawyers and others debate whether or not going into a war without UN sanction is legal. Labor's view is that our opposition to war is not based on legality; it is based on our judgment that this war is wrong. So nothing turns on it for me, but what does concern me is any suggestion that our troops are acting illegally, because that is not the case. They have been deployed legally by the elected government. They will operate under proper terms of engagement. They will operate within the terms of the Geneva convention and they have no greater risk to International Criminal Court prosecution or any other action than if they had been sent on a UN endorsed mission. That is the point I want to make clear both to the troops and to the Australian community: there are no greater legal risks associated for our troops as a result of this decision than had it been UN endorsed.

The argument again is with the government, whether the government has acted legally in joining this war. I suspect that is an issue that will get played out quite seriously over the coming months and years, because there is a very strong body of opinion which suggests that in joining a war without UN sanction we may be subject to the charge of involvement in an illegal war. But I wanted to make it clear that the troops are acting legally. They have no greater risk than if they had a UN sanction to the action and they have no greater risk as a result of our signing up to the International Criminal Court than they would have otherwise.

Some of the ill-informed comment that has been circulating in the last few days is very unhelpful and undermines the efforts of our troops. Our troops will act legally within their terms of engagement and, as always, the only risk to Australian service personnel serving in any action is if they do not comply with those proper terms of engagement and are guilty of some sort of war crime. That is the only occasion on which they would get into any difficulty. I think it is important that we recognise that.

I think it is a huge challenge for the Australian community to focus in on the debate about the war and not withdraw or diminish our support for the Australian troops. I certainly make that commitment because I am aware of their concern, and have concern for them, as to how this debate will impact on them and their ability to do their jobs. But Labor will oppose this war. I will oppose this war because it is wrong. It does not have UN sanction, it does not have international support and we have resorted to war when peaceful outcomes were still possible. For all those reasons it is wrong. It takes us down a very dangerous path. It sets a precedent of pre-emptive strike, of a recognition of might being right, that will come back to haunt the world and Australia in coming years.

We cannot turn our back on international law, on the UN's role, merely because it suits us to please a powerful ally. We have to take a stance based on Australia's national interest. We have not done that on this occasion, and that puts Australians at greater risk and will, I think, harm Australia for many years to come. We ought to oppose this war. I urge the government to pull back—there is still time. We ought not support a war on Iraq while peaceful solutions still remain open to us. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Let me begin by joining the rest of the Senate in expressing the Australian Greens' support for the Australian Defence Force personnel who have been deployed to Iraq by the Prime Minister without the authority of this parliament and without the backing of the Australian people. They are in the service of this great country. They are there because the Prime Minister has directed them, and the responsibility for any outcome is therefore firmly with the Prime Minister and not with those 2,000 Australians good and true. To that end, I foreshadow an amendment to the Labor amendment which would add:

speech.para: (f) calls on the Australian government to immediately return Australia's 2,000 Defence Force personnel home.

This Prime Minister will bear some responsibility for each drop of blood shed in Iraq in the coming months. This Prime Minister bears total responsibility for every drop of Australian blood shed on the sands of Iraq in the coming months. This Prime Minister has deployed Australian Defence Force personnel into the Iraq theatre of war at the behest of George W. Bush but without the imprimatur of the Australian people. The Prime Minister in his press conference today said on the one hand, `I speak for Australia,' and on the other, `I ask the Australian people to support me.' He cannot have it both ways, nor does he. This Prime Minister on this issue does not speak for Australia. He speaks from the office which Australians have given him but never on this issue. No Australian has voted for him to arrogate unto himself the power to deploy Australian troops into this illegal war. No Australian has been asked by the Prime Minister. There has been no reference to the Australian people and, worse, there has been no reference to the Australian parliament. He does not, and will not, have the vote of the people or this parliament for this involvement in a war which is not Australia's.

Those of us who listened to the Prime Minister this morning further heard him say, `In a democracy a government makes the decision.' Wrong, honourable Prime Minister. In a democracy, the power for the decision comes from the people and is rightfully with the parliament. But this Prime Minister has made a decision without the stamp of approval of that democratic system. If there is one thing the Greens will move to fix over the coming years it is this silence of the Constitution which the Prime Minister has abused to make this decision without the authority of the parliament. The fulcrum of democracy is the parliament; it is not the executive. The people's trust is in the parliament, not in the Prime Minister's office. The people elect members of parliament; they do not elect the Prime Minister. The parliament ought to give the assent to the deployment of Australian Defence Force personnel as under the Constitution in defence of this country or the states. Without that, the Prime Minister is usurping the spirit of the Constitution, and that is what he has done today.

Let us pause to reflect that there are no New Zealanders going to this war. There are no Canadians. There are no Japanese defence force personnel, nor any from China or France or Germany. Insofar as the Prime Minister makes out that he has made a decision which is in keeping with the community of nations he is deceiving himself, even if he cannot deceive this country. When he says that he does it with the imprimatur of law, again he is deceiving himself, if not this country. The actions of the Prime Minister in this matter, in refusing to bring forward legal authority until after the fatal decision has been made, speak for themselves. Of course, we can get a legal opinion to back almost everything but the fact remains that this deployment to Iraq does not have the imprimatur of the United Nations. It does not have the imprimatur of the Security Council. It would not have got the imprimatur of either the permanent members of the Security Council who can levy a veto—and three of the five would have—or the majority of the Security Council. This is a confined and restricted number of nations which, because it happens to include the most powerful nation on earth, has deceived itself into believing it therefore has the community of nations onside when patently it does not. A series of like nations to Australia around the world have had leaders with the wisdom of their national interest to not involve themselves at the behest of George W. Bush in the way that Prime Minister Howard has done.

What a world we are in in the year 2003, with massive advances in technology which have extended the potential for human existence on this planet in unimaginable ways compared with the lives of our forebears. But with that technology has come enormous power to change life on the planet. With that technology has come the ability to levy great evil as well as great good. The powerhouse of that technology is the rich countries of the world and foremost the United States of America. The weapons of mass destruction that are so much the key to this debate have largely emanated from that powerhouse and from other like countries from Russia through China, Italy and Britain—the wealthy countries of the world. There is a standard law here: if a weapon, a technology, becomes available to one person on this planet it will inevitably become available to all persons on this planet. If a weapon becomes available to governments on this planet it will become available to malefactors on this planet—to terrorists. There is behind these turbulent events of the moment a need for a rethink by the whole of humanity on this planet. There is a need for global governance, there is a need for global democracy and there is a need for global liberty which is governed by that democracy. The present circumstances underscore how this cannot be left with those who are wealthy, under the dictum that might is right.

Where are the cries from our leaders in this country, or in the United States, to put a bridle on these weapons of mass destruction? Where is the prohibition on laboratories around the world which are experimenting with biological, chemical or nuclear weaponry? They should be closed down, wherever they might be, because they work against the interests of humanity and life on this planet. Quite to the contrary, at the moment under President Bush there is more spending than ever before in history on weapons of mass destruction. Therefore, the threat to human life on this planet—and, indeed, all life on this planet—increases, under the very president who has today de facto declared war on a so-called rogue state because it has the future potential to misuse weapons of mass destruction, the technology for which was supplied by his own country just a decade or two back to the dictator he now wants to attack and put out of action.

If there is one thing that we must learn from this, it is that we have a global and collective responsibility—and President Bush, of any person on this planet, bears the greatest responsibility—to bring in a universal, democratic system and to upgrade the United Nations or move to a world parliament which can deal with nefarious technological misuse and the spending of billions of dollars on that misuse to line the pockets of some and to give inordinate power, through the threat of cruel misuse of these weapons, to some against the welfare of the rest. If there is one good thing to come out of these terrible events, it must be a reappraisal by humanity, by the six billion of us on the planet in 2003, of the rapid spread of technologies which threaten not just part or several of the nations of this world but everybody and everybody's future. And yet there is no mention of this in the speeches of President Bush.

The Australian people do not trust President Bush, and therefore they do not like the chain of command from President Bush to Prime Minister Howard, at his leave, and therefore to our Defence Force personnel. The Australian people have a great, wonderful, long-term relationship with the American people, but that is quite different from their feeling for this administration. In this country, President Bush is not trusted, he is not liked and he is not seen as being for the good or on the side of good. He is seen to be straying away from that and to be, himself, a nidus of great danger in international relations and for the peace of all the peoples on this planet. His speech today did nothing to assuage that feeling that many people in this country and around the world have about this president who is abusing the great power and honour of the office that he has taken to become the president of the most powerful country on the face of the planet in 2003.

This year, $1.5 trillion will be spent on arming, equipping and deploying offence forces. Just 10 per cent of that sum would supply all the necessities to ensure that everybody on this planet had a fulfilling existence. Where is the moral claim of a president whose nation will spend half that money this year—three-quarters of a trillion dollars—but cannot put 10 per cent of it across to meet the necessities of all the millions of people in this world who are undergoing cruel and terrible deprivation? This president has homed in, after years of inaction, on the Butcher of Baghdad, who was supplied with weapons by the Reagan government and supported—or, at least, there was a deathly silence from the Reagan government in the 1980s—in the use of those weapons. Can President Bush not see, from his Christian standpoint, that to put this money, these billions of dollars, into armaments but not to give it to children who do not have clean water, to mothers who want to feed their babies or to people who simply want shelter, clothes and a job is a direct act of unchristianity?

Today when the President, having said that America is a country of peace—in defiance of that spending—ended his speech with `God bless America', he again showed the arrogance and the small-mindedness that he has in his pre-eminent position as an arbiter of what goes on in this world. He has usurped the United Nations and arrogated unto himself the power, through sheer firepower, to do what he and his coterie want to do in the world in their sectional interests— which God does not serve. Whatever else can be said about God, it is not the priority or the prerogative of the United States, or the President of the United States. It is an entity which gives life to everybody on this planet, is shared by everybody on this planet and has the right of protection of everybody on this planet—and has the obligation to see that none on the planet are discriminated against in the way that President Bush would have it.

Today, the Prime Minister of this country, following through on a series of adventures—most notably the Tampa affair—determined that he could read the mood of this nation. But he has misread it. I can tell him that, if he picked up the phone and answered the calls going to his office today and made himself aware of the tears being shed by people ringing their politicians right around the country, he would understand the depth of feeling against what he has done.

This Prime Minister has taken office, but not on this issue. This is a Prime Minister who is `Mr 22 per cent' in today's poll. Seventy-one cent of the Australian people are against what he is doing and 22 per cent are in favour. And he has asked the Australian people to get behind him! I ask the Prime Minister: is it not your job to get behind the Australian people? Who has primacy in this country—the people or the unelected Prime Minister? He is elected to this parliament as a representative, but not into that position, and he was never given that power and that authority to deploy Australians into this war, which is not Australia's war.

Throughout these trying times, the Greens will continue at every opportunity not only to support the Australian men and women who find themselves deployed to this war, but to get them home—hence our amendment to the motion. They should be brought home immediately. I expect that, until that day arrives, many people in this country—including people who voted for this Prime Minister—will not be able to rest. It is a dastardly decision that this Prime Minister has made. It is wrong in principle. It is against the interests of this nation, no matter how much and how often he says the contrary is the case. Above all, it has made those men and women in the defence forces subject to all manner of risks in the coming period which they should never have been put in a position of having to endure.

We live in a difficult and trying world. The potential for destruction is unprecedented. But until we have leadership that is prepared to make this a fairer world, we cannot expect it to become a more settled world. Until we have leadership that will put butter before guns, we are in a more dangerous and less happy world. If we are going to export democracy and liberty we should exercise it at home. It is no good having democratic leaders at home who are dictators abroad. We live on a globalising planet; we live in an age of globalisation. That does not just mean economic globalisation. In fact, it means economic globalisation least of all. This is globalisation of human history, human advancement and the search for security and happiness in the future. You do not get that by the invention of—and spending of money on—more and more weapons of mass destruction, when there are so many people in need on this planet. Today, the Prime Minister has made an egregious mistake out of his own hubris. We will do everything we can in coming times to rescue what we can from the results of that mistake. (Time expired)

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The motion before the Senate requires us to consider matters that go to the heart of international peace and security. The motion relates to matters that will have a profound effect on the shape of the world in which we live now and in the future. I note that a number of today's headlines cannot resist characterising the latest developments as `the moment of truth'. But the real truth is that, despite some last-minute cosmetic hyperactivity which falls far short of the immediate and complete cooperation required unanimously by the Security Council a little more than three months ago, Iraq continues to defy the international community, just it is has done for the last 12 years.

speech.para: Today's decision by the government to commit Australian forces to the operational control of the coalition field commander, in support of military action in the gulf region, has not been an easy or popular one. Indeed, the easy decision would have been to capitulate to the siren calls of several permanent Security Council members who in recent times have called for Saddam Hussein to be given more time to cooperate with UN inspectors. But history is replete with examples of how the soft option can make matters infinitely worse. Today's decision is not some knee-jerk falling into line with US wishes. Whilst the American alliance is fundamentally important, it is not and should not be determinative of Australia's interests. The duly elected government of the Commonwealth, alone, should make that decision, and it has.

It is also critically important to understand that such action has only been taken as a last resort after diplomacy and other efforts have failed. The government believes in the primacy of international law and the pivotal role of the United Nations. On no fewer than 17 occasions, the Security Council has considered the question of Iraq and its continued failure to comply with its disarmament obligations. As recently as November last year, the Security Council, including France, solemnly concluded that Iraq was in material breach of its Security Council obligations and should be given one last opportunity of full compliance.

As the legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department, made public today, makes it clear, those actions are firmly based in international law. It also makes it clear that the Security Council has already endorsed the use of force. In the eloquent words of Professor Ruth Wedgwood, reported in the Financial Times of 14 March:

quote.para: Resolution 687 is the mother of all resolutions setting out the requirements for a post Gulf War Iraq. This 1991 resolution requires in perpetuity that Iraq gives up its weapons of mass destruction and permits verification. Resolution 687 designates Iraq's acceptance of this requirement as a continuing condition of the Gulf War ceasefire. Teeth are also supplied by resolution 678 authorising the Allies to expel Iraq from Kuwait and to use force in supporting all “subsequent relevant resolutions” needed to restore regional peace and security. Resolution 1441 explicitly recalls Resolution 678 which authorised “all necessary measures” to restore peace and security in the region.

speech.para: It is also important to appreciate the role of the UNMOVIC inspectors. We do not start with a clean slate where certain allegations have been made that Iraq is in possession of weapons of mass destruction and it is then up to the inspectors to locate such weapons or prove beyond reasonable doubt that they exist. On the contrary, the UN has already established that Iraq is in possession of 6,500 chemical munitions with the potential content of 1,000 tonnes of chemical agents; 8,500 litres of anthrax; 650 kilograms of bacterial growth media, which could be used to make 5,000 litres of anthrax; 360 tonnes of bulk chemical agents; 1.5 tonnes of VX; and 3,000 tonnes of precursor chemicals. The onus is therefore on Iraq to demonstrate that it has destroyed or no longer possesses such weapons. This it has manifestly failed to do. Indeed, Dr Blix noted in his most recent report, of 7 March, to the Security Council that Iraq knows the names of people involved with the destruction of materials from proscribed programs and therefore should have records that it could hand over to UNMOVIC, but it has chosen not to do so.

It is worth considering what has occurred since France and other Security Council nations supported resolution 1441. Has Iraq made any genuine attempts to cooperate and fulfil its international obligations? The short answer is no. On several occasions it has deliberately waited until the last moment before making gestures designed to please those who no longer want to hold Iraq to those obligations. To pretend, as France does, that the UN inspectors need more time is to ignore the reality that the inspectors will never be in a position to make definitive judgments without the full cooperation of Iraq. Indeed, its grudging cooperation to date has only been brought about by the forward deployment of troops, not because of any change of heart on the part of Saddam Hussein.

France, through its opportunistic spoiling role, has done the UN a grave disservice. Against this background it is difficult not to conclude that France is driven more by a desire to retrieve lost imperial ambitions while preserving its Iraqi oil interests than by any genuine desire to bring Iraq to account. It ought to be clear to anyone who has studied the events of the past several months that France has deliberately gone out of its way to ensure that there is no incentive for other members of the Security Council to support any second resolution. In these circumstances, the Australian government believes that it is untenable to leave forces in place and hope that Iraq will have a change of heart. Even more so, if one were to adopt the approach of the Labor Party and, of course, the Greens, and bring the troops home now, all such prospects would disappear, as anyone who has seriously studied recent events must appreciate. Many other countries share Australia's concern about the growing threat posed by Iraq's pursuit of weapons of mass destruction and few, if any, argue that Iraq is cooperating as it is required to do.

It is very much in Australia's interest that the UN should as much as possible be the focal point for the resolution of international disputes. Indeed, the Security Council has a very specific responsibility in this regard. Failure of the UN system to follow through on the enforcement of its own resolutions should not mean that the UN is permanently sidelined. Indeed, those who have learnt the lessons of the failure of the League of Nations ought to appreciate that these are fragile vehicles through which we express international community views. If they are ignored or treated as political playthings then they lose their relevance and, as a result, we need then to start the process all over again. So it is very much in Australia's interests that the UN should as much as possible remain relevant. It is therefore pleasing to note that the United States and the United Kingdom both accept that, despite the attempts of others to render the Security Council irrelevant in resolving the current crisis, the UN still has a very important role to play in the postwar reconstruction of Iraq.

Australia's distance from the gulf region has led some to argue that Australia could decline to actively participate in military action in the region whilst at the same time expressing support and solidarity for our allies. This would not be a responsible attitude to burden sharing, let alone would it be in Australia's interests. We all aspire to live in a world of peace and security. It is our permanent hope that the world will be a better place once Saddam Hussein has been disarmed and the prospects of weapons of mass destruction falling into the hands of terrorists have thereby been significantly reduced. In reading President Bush's statement of today, I note that he uses a very telling phrase:

quote.para: Instead of drifting along toward tragedy, we will set a course toward safety.

speech.para: It is very easy to lampoon these objectives and characterise the Americans as hell-bent on pursuing their own interests without for a moment considering the very significant benefits that the world derives from having a superpower that is genuinely acting in the best interests of the international community.

One only had to listen to Senator Brown's rabid diatribe of anti-Americanism to realise that not only is he trying to personalise the debate and demonise the President but he is at all times trying to distract attention from the merits of the argument. At no time do we hear any positive alternatives other than that of moral leadership being required. When, of course, the Prime Minister of Australia or the President of the United States shows moral leadership and puts, as Mr Blair has done, a very courageous position forward—knowing, in Mr Blair's situation, that very many members of his own party are opposed—one has to say that that is a high degree of moral courage and admirable political leadership. And yet, the Greens and their fellow travellers would simply demean and decry those attempts without suggesting any other alternative.

It is simply not good enough to ignore the current realities. We are not dealing here with adversaries who are prepared to be reasonable. We are not dealing with someone who has been misunderstood or is in a desperately poor situation and has no choice but to respond in ways that are unacceptable to us. The fact is that by every assessment Saddam Hussein is not only a tyrant of the greatest magnitude but someone who is acting maliciously towards his own people, let alone towards the rest of the world. When someone has been given 17 opportunities to comply—not only voluntarily but also under the threat of force—and still refuses to do so, it is simply preposterous to argue that somehow more time will bring them to their senses. It ought to be abundantly clear to anyone who has an open mind on the subject that Saddam Hussein is not susceptible to any sort of logic or persuasion.

It is very easy to attribute base motives to other players, but does anyone seriously doubt that Australia's fundamental values and beliefs are not closely aligned with those of our major allies in this dispute? It is certainly not in our interest to see such value systems overthrown by militant fundamentalists who will resort to the use of chemical and biological weapons, and any other means by which to wreak maximum havoc upon the West. If there were a lesson to be learned from September 11, I would have thought it was that you have to be prepared. In this new world of uncertainty you cannot simply wait until you are attacked before you take action. Quite clearly, the Americans have a fairly high degree of preparedness, yet they were totally unable to do anything to anticipate that sort of catastrophic attack on their value system—let alone, of course, on the thousands of people who died as a result of that act. I think that tells us that if you were simply to wait until such time as Saddam Hussein decided to change his mind, or until other terrorists were to acquire weapons of mass destruction or chemical and biological weapons, you would be a sitting target. That is not the responsibility of a government; a government's responsibility is to do its very best to anticipate and pre-empt any reasonable apprehension of danger. That is what we are doing in this instance. It is of no consolation at all to wait until you are directly attacked and then wonder after the event why you did not take action. That is what royal commissions are all about—the benefit of hindsight and asking, `Why didn't you do these things?' We are doing them now, when it can make a very real difference.

In these circumstances Australia is determined to play its part in helping to make the world a safer place for all its inhabitants, despite the natural aversion and apprehension of many in the community to embarking upon military activity, especially when our own country is not directly and immediately under threat. I believe the Australian public does understand that the Prime Minister and the government are motivated only by a desire to act in the country's best interests and to achieve an outcome that not only will be of benefit to the rest of the world but particularly will assist in alleviating the suffering of those who have experienced the most extreme violence and invasion at the hands of the Iraqi regime. Much careful thought and reflection have gone into this decision, and I believe that the Australian community will very much appreciate that it is not the result of any capricious action on the part of the government but rather a reflection of a deep desire to do the right thing in the best interests of us all.

talker.name: Ludwig, Sen Joe
Senator LUDWIG
talker.role: Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Faulkner. Clearly this government has decided unilaterally and without bipartisan support that the time for diplomacy is over. I find it difficult to accept that diplomacy can end simply because a non-military solution has not been found or the effort to find a better way has not been made. I have heard no suggestion from this government that Dr Blix was not doing his job or was not doing it well. There was certainly no suggestion by Dr Blix that he had finished his job. I hope that the other side of politics gets sick and tired of us saying that Australia should not be involved in this war against Iraq. The war is wrong and prosecuting it is clearly not in our national interest. There is a better way to disarm Iraq. As I said the last time this matter was before the Senate, Labor believes that, in the absence of an agreed UN Security Council resolution authorising military action against Iraq, there is no basis for military action to disarm Iraq. The war is wrong. This government has provided no justification for its action. Do not confuse this with any debate about us not being supportive of our alliance. As I said clearly last time, I support the alliance with the US. However, it does not mean that you follow them blindly on every issue; it does mean that you can be critical and supportive at the same time.

speech.para: Let us be clear that this government committed our troops not now but, in truth, many months ago. However, Mr Howard has only bothered to tell us today that our troops will participate in action against Iraq. I make it absolutely plain that my views about the troops themselves remain clear—I remain, as always, committed to them. The Australian government has directed actions in respect of this war, and as far as I am concerned the troops are acting appropriately and in accordance with the government's wishes. But that does not stop this from being a silly and reckless act by this government. My argument is against the actions taken by this government in respect of the pre-emptive war against Iraq.

The common agreement in this parliament on the debate about Iraq is in regard to Iraq's disarmament. Nobody disagrees that Iraq should disarm. We all agree that resolution 1441 issued by the United Nations Security Council should be adhered to, along with previous existing resolutions 687 and 1154. In themselves, those resolutions do not authorise individual member states to use force against Iraq, but they do contemplate further consideration of appropriate action by the Security Council. The Labor Party disagrees with the position taken by the Howard government when presenting their arguments to the public—a position which could only be taken to incite fear and mistrust in the community. Yesterday, the Prime Minister indicated during his media conference that it was likely Australia would enter into a conflict with Iraq. He said that Australia was morally correct and legally obliged to participate in military conflict to disarm Iraq, irrespective of a mandate being issued by the UN Security Council. In citing his reasons for moving forward without further debate, the Prime Minister said he based his decision on the assumption of what he believed to be in the best interests of the Australian people. I think he has got it very wrong.

The Howard government believe the UN lacks the collective will to force Iraq to disarm. They also believe that Iraq's weapons, both biological and chemical, could be used by terrorist organisations against other countries. The Prime Minister's statement has something for everyone. He even attempted to put forward the idea that there is a moral case for Australia to invade Iraq on human rights grounds and that the Iraqi people have been suffering under the force of a dictator, so it is time we stepped in to correct the problem. There we have strong words that are full of sentiment but not the real reason that Mr Howard has supported the coalition of the willing.

The UN is clearly capable of acting to address these issues. Many people throughout the world have suffered and continue to suffer at the hands of dictators, but we do not see Mr Howard stepping in on all occasions. This is not the real reason that the government have chosen to enter into a conflict. It is unbelievable and aimed at trying to win support from those people who have true human rights as a priority. If the Howard government are going to use that as a reason, they should at least be sincere and constant in their comments. For the past four months, the Howard government have tried to frighten, intimidate and coerce the general public into believing that it is in Australia's best interests to seriously consider the need to enter into a conflict specifically designed to disarm Iraq. The Prime Minister has chosen to ignore the efforts of the United Nations and to forge ahead. When the Howard government predeployed our troops, the Prime Minister sent a clear message to the Australian people that he would do what he thought best irrespective of possible diplomatic solutions, irrespective of what was good for Australia and without bipartisan support.

Without a further resolution by the United States, the Howard government has, firstly, willingly sent 2,000 Australian troops to war; secondly, actively undermined attempts by the United Nations to negotiate a peaceful solution; thirdly, ignored the pledge its predecessors made in 1945 to support the efforts of the United Nations to maintain peace and ignored concerns expressed by the Australian public, dismissing their comments and stance as ignorant and misinformed; and, finally, condemned many innocent people in Iraq.

The world has trusted the United Nations with maintaining peace and security. The United Nations has deployed a total of 54 peacekeeping forces and observer missions. It has been able to restore calm in areas of contention to allow the negotiating process to go forward while saving millions of people from becoming casualties of conflict. In Iraq, the peacekeepers did not fail; they were making progress. I believe it is immoral to go to war when Iraq could have been disarmed peacefully. Australians chose to become a member of the United Nations. We have a solid and proud history representing the interests of the United Nations in our peacekeeping duties. Australia pledged to follow the dictates of the United Nations when we became a member back in the 1940s. In doing so, Australia did not say, `Only if we like what you're saying at the time,' or `If it is politically expedient, we will ignore it,' but that is what we are doing at the present time.

The Labor Party has been clear on the subject of supporting the United Nations in its efforts to have Iraq disarm peacefully. Nobody wants to go to war. Labor has been consistent on the situation in Iraq since last April. The Labor Party has clearly articulated its position. Iraq is a matter which must be prosecuted through the UN Security Council. Over the past several months, the government has made vague references in an attempt to link Iraq with the tragedies of 9-11 and the Bali bombing. When called upon to expand on those views, the government has back-pedalled, cited national security or ignored the request altogether. The government has simply failed to make the case for war and failed to make any of those connections. This government is not intent on maintaining peace; this government is intent on stirring up fear and mistrust within our community. The Howard government is clearly wrong in respect of Iraq.

The United Nations Security Council was dealing with Iraq diplomatically on the basis of the continuation of a policy of containment based on an enhanced weapons inspectorate and continued sanctions against the importation of proscribed military components. If containment is not an option, then it is a matter for the UN Security Council to determine what form of collective action, including military action, is appropriate in achieving the disarmament of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. The government says, however, that it can proceed with a military attack on Iraq in the absence of the Security Council passing a second resolution containing the council's conclusions on whether or not Iraq has exercised its final opportunity to disarm as required by Security Council resolution 1441.

Labor fundamentally disagree with the government's approach to the UN process. Labor believe that a second Security Council resolution is fundamental to the authorisation of any military action against Iraq. In truth, without a sanction, it lacks moral legitimacy and international support. We do not believe it lies within the discretion of individual states to decide which resolutions should be militarily enforced and which should not. The difference between Labor and the government on this question goes to our disagreement on the importance it places on the processes within the United Nations.

The government chose to give lip-service to the UN process because, on the issue of Iraq, the government has seen the UN as being politically useful in providing it with the potential international legal cover behind which it has hidden since last September. As of last week, the Prime Minister, the foreign minister and the Attorney-General began saying explicitly that Australia required no further legal fortification other than the existing Security Council resolution 1441 to proceed with military action against Iraq. In other words, for the government, the path to war is now clear and, for the government, that path appears now to be a unilateral one or at least one with a coalition of what are regarded as the willing. But the coalition is not made up of a huge community of international identities. It includes Portugal, Spain, the United States and Australia. Their actions are not endorsed by the United Nations Security Council.

The political significance of the last week is that Prime Minister Howard has signalled that he has now dispensed with the United Nations. He clearly states that he believes the UN does not have the capacity to deal with Iraq. Prior to September last year, the Howard government advocated a unilateral solution. It even accused Labor of appeasement for suggesting that the war was a matter for the UN. Subsequent to September last year, in response to domestic opinion poll reactions to its policies, it advocated a UN multilateral solution. In January this year the Howard government predeployed troops to the gulf while still hiding behind the camouflage statement that no final decision on military action had been taken nor had Australia finally signed up as a fully-fledged member of President Bush's coalition of the willing. Mr Howard now appears to be finally and formally telling the Australian people of the decision he privately took nearly nine months ago when in Washington—namely, that Australia would be in this war with or without the United Nations.

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate my support for our troops. I think they have a difficult enough time without any suggestion that they do not have our support. Clearly, they have our support. War is an option of last resort. However, it does not seem to me that we have arrived at a position without any options. The repercussions of this decision by Australia will reverberate around the region. The position Australia has adopted causes me great concern for peace and security within our region. We are out of step with the international community on this issue. The international community have not joined in this action. As I have said, only four countries have taken the unilateral step and that is not representative of the wider community feeling about this issue. The international position is one of looking for options. The last resort has not been reached.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in response to Senator Hill's motion in the Senate today. Within 48 hours Australia will be at war with Iraq— that is, real war. The lives of our 2,000 troops serving in the gulf region will be in peril, along with the lives of other allied forces and millions of Iraqis. One Nation believes that a referendum should have been held for the Australian people prior to deciding whether or not to go to war. Let the people decide, not the executive government. Iraq has not committed any act of war against Australia, the USA or the UK. Under international law the provisions for self-defence are not met. In the last Gulf War, military intelligence reported that Iraq had invaded Kuwait. This time there is no aggression. Iraq has not invaded any country. In the last Gulf War, there were 33 countries acting as a coalition under United Nations authority. This time there will be only three countries involved in direct military combat.

speech.para: Australia's allies have not delivered convincing evidence against Saddam Hussein's regime and his weapons. Even the report presented to the UN Security Council by Colin Powell was called into question when parts of it turned out to be a 1991 thesis copied from the Internet by a British intelligence agency. Legal opinion is divided on whether there is any UN authority at all for the war. As a member of the International Criminal Court, could Australia's Defence Force personnel be tried at The Hague for war crimes if there are civilian casualties and possibly crimes against humanity? In my speech opposing the International Criminal Court legislation, I pointed out some of the perils which may actually come to pass. Let me add that we fully support, without exception, our brave men and women who have been deployed to the gulf region. Few politicians sitting here today would know what it is like to live inside a chemical or biological protective suit. Very few senators in this place would have spent any real time with our defence forces during their time as senators. To face the enemy on shifting sands and to kill another human being is a big ask. Let our prayers and our hearts be with our forces that have been deployed.

The war raises implications for Australia as a nation and for geopolitical stability across the globe. The Western alliance is rapidly deteriorating. So far, not a shot has been fired but the casualties are NATO and our Cold War allies France and Germany. Relations are badly strained. The future of the transatlantic alliance is in jeopardy. If the impending war ends with Saddam gone, there will be even greater American pre-eminence, along with greater contempt for multilateral institutional constraints on American power and even less willingness to consider the views of anyone except the few allies who stood with the US before and during the campaign. In other words, the results will be precisely those least desired by America's critics: the UN could go the way of the League of Nations, perhaps even to the point of America withdrawing, and the US, instead of being a mere policeman, would become the global policeman.

The firing of weapons is the ultimate challenge to national security. If Saddam Hussein had any intention of using biological or chemical weapons then an attack would make him utilise them. There is a lot of animosity towards the United States, Britain and Australia—the coalition of the willing. It would be naive to believe that terrorist groups or foreign armies would not be spurred into launching retaliatory attacks here on our own soil. The United States have planned to mobilise as many as 5,000 FBI agents to guard against terrorist attacks and monitor or arrest suspected militants. They are preparing for the worst and hoping for the best. Here in Australia we cannot afford to adopt the `she'll be right' attitude. Biological, chemical and nuclear weapons, as well as other abominations, may be unleashed upon the very soil we stand. Are we prepared to take this risk?

With most of the Western media now ensconced in relative safety in Jordan, Australians will not see the real war on TV or read about the real war in the newspapers. Anthony Cordesman, from the esteemed Center for Strategic and International Studies, has observed, `This is going to be a really hard reporting job, particularly because most US and UK reporting will be necessarily vague for security and psyops reasons, and there will be a flood of Iraqi and Arab exaggerated claims about how many military survive and how many civilians are killed.' Modern newscasts are edited so that nothing too unpleasant is shown to what are now often paying viewers. The world may see all kinds of footage about success, but there are not going to be many reporters embedded at Iraqi targets, and there may be exaggerated US, British and Australian claims. With all of the advances in technology, there is still no way to instantly measure or verify lethality and civilian casualties and the collateral damage. The real war is hidden from us.

While discussing the role of the media and this war in Iraq, I would like to comment on an incident which occurred last month. One Nation were the first to call for a referendum on the Iraq issue. We actually asked for that referendum in January, and I reiterated that call in my speech in this place on 4 February. I note that the Greens practically plagiarised a section of my speech and used it on ABC Radio and in various television interviews two weeks later. It makes you wonder what sort of accuracy we can expect from the media in reporting on this war, when they cannot even give credit where it is due.

There are many factors to consider as the troops take their place. I want to elaborate on some of these, as it seems that the media and the public will only be briefed on this aspect after the war commences. Allied ground troops attacking Baghdad from Kuwait will have to cross the mighty Euphrates and Tigris rivers, the muddy Mesopotamia region between them and a vast latticework of irrigation canals and farm paddies that Iraqi troops can flood at will. Saddam Hussein could blow up three dams around Baghdad and send a wall of water rushing down the southern approaches to the capital city, where he has entrenched his elite troops for a final stand. Anthony Cordesman from the Center for Strategic and International Studies has speculated that Saddam could flood southern Iraq by destroying the Lak al Milh dam, south-west of Baghdad, and two others on the Tigris and Euphrates.

Iraqi weapons of mass destruction and missiles are a wild card, and no-one likes to talk about it. Although the US and Britain think we have weapons that can take out most of their CBW systems and burn them or limit their effects, they know very well they largely failed to successfully hit such targets in the last war, and they underestimate the danger that they are. In the last Gulf War, allied troops were reportedly contaminated by sarin and VX nerve gases when allied bombs fell on Iraqi chemical weapons facilities. In the last Gulf War, coalition forces used depleted uranium radioactive weapons against Iraq's armed forces, particularly their armoured and mechanised units. Contamination as well as long-term incidences of cancers, congenital diseases and foetal deformities have plagued the Iraqi people.

A combination of factors has affected defence personnel and many now suffer from what is termed `Gulf War syndrome'. One Nation notes with interest that a Gulf War Veterans Health Study, conducted jointly by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and Monash University, was due for release last year and that has now been rescheduled, perhaps conveniently, for late March, well after this Gulf War commences. Will depleted uranium weapons be used again in this war? Will the government come clean and tell us of the implications for our men and women in the gulf?

This war is bigger than Iraq. There are wider implications for the failing world economy, which is now showing signs of regressing. The signs are similar to those that heralded the Great Depression of the 1930s—corporate collapses, company mergers, spiralling household debt, unprecedented margin trading and a speculative property boom. While many analysts believe the world economy may recover if there is a war, just as many see a massive collapse, particularly if oil hits $45 or $50 per barrel. Quite clearly, we are hedging our bets; a war will either provide great economic gain or colossal economic ruin.

The world community of nations is not with us, but against us. Other countries are not convinced that there are offensive threats, only perhaps deliberate deceptions. Saddam Hussein must not be allowed to go unchecked and unchallenged—but for the last 12 years he has been contained. It can be argued that this containment should continue and the UN inspectors allowed to do their work and dismantle his weapons of mass destruction. Equally, we could argue that Saddam must be disarmed—at any cost. Let us not forget, though, that the destruction of chemical weapons is a complex and lengthy process which cannot be achieved overnight. By way of example, the chemical weapons convention entered into force in 1997 and nations have until 2007 to eliminate their stockpiles. The convention's implementation is slow, particularly in Russia where financial resources are limited. Destruction sites need to be built and there must be stringent planning to protect the environment and the personnel involved in the destruction process. I would like to add that the US chemical weapons destruction facility at Pine Bluff, Arkansas was built in 1999 and will not complete destruction of US surplus chemical weapons until 2007.

If we go to war then we will get a reaction that may have long-term consequences. Whatever we do to others, we do unto ourselves. The risks of this war are tyranny, revolution and instability across the Middle East and danger for Australia. The consequences of real war are terrible. Opposition to this war comes not only from political parties and individuals but from veterans' organisations, religious groups, the intelligence community and even from within the ranks of the Defence Force itself. Will the government choose to ignore this opposition at its peril? Why won't the government allow people to have their say? What is the Prime Minister afraid of? In conclusion, there is no right way to do the wrong thing. A war on Iraq is not freedom's finest hour. It could well be the beginning of its own destruction.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Before I call Senator Humphries, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and, therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

—I stand here today with a sense of pride, of responsibility and of awe. Doubtless these feelings imbue every senator who enters this place for the first time. Although this is my first or maiden speech, it would strain credulity for me to claim to be a parliamentary maiden. I have served in the legislative assembly of this territory for almost 14 years, years of which I am very proud and which I hope will provide me with a backdrop of experience useful to my time in the Senate. Service at the second tier of Australian government is principally about the delivery of basic services such as health, education and the maintenance of public order to the community. But every state and territory parliamentarian thinks about national issues and the national interest. It is an honour, therefore, to be able to face those national issues on a day-to-day basis in this parliament. And so by the miracle of parliamentary convention my long-lost maidenhood is restored. In preparing my remarks today I went back to the maiden speeches of my two Liberal predecessors, Senator John Knight and Senator Margaret Reid. Senator Knight said in 1976, and I fully adopt these words today:

quote.para: I want to contribute to national policy and to debates on issues which go beyond my own electorate. However, my first responsibility is and must be to the electors of the Australian Capital Territory and their families. It is to them that I will give my attention first.

speech.para: These are illustrious footsteps in which to follow. Senator Knight was of course the first person to represent the people of the ACT in the Senate. In turn, Senator Reid was the territory's longest serving representative and rose to become the first woman to lead the Senate as its President. Indeed the ACT has long been in the habit of placing women in positions of leadership. Only once has the ACT electorate chosen a male chief minister at an election—unfortunately it wasn't me! I am conscious that with my election here I have ended a period in which, uniquely in Australia, half the electors of the territory were represented in the federal parliament exclusively by women.

It is my privilege to represent in this place a special community. Canberra is the child of Australian nationhood, the city that Federation built. It should and does encapsulate in its layout and institutions the achievements and aspirations of this country. It is a truly beautiful city. It is also—although some who see it only fleetingly do not appreciate this— an immensely livable city. All this, of course, is by design. Sir Thomas Denman, Governor-General in 1913, hoped that Canberra would eventually bear `some resemblance to the city beautiful of our dreams'. I believe that governments, planners, architects and gardeners in the succeeding 90 years have delivered on that goal.

The ACT has come a long way over the past 20 years or so as we have established our own system of government in the context of the Australian Federation. Many people will still remember the vigorous debates over many years about the ACT assuming responsibility for its own affairs. The inauguration of the Legislative Assembly for the ACT in 1989—with full executive powers—marked a significant point in our evolution. For the first time there was a separation between Commonwealth and ACT government responsibilities. On the whole, the system seems to have worked well, despite misgivings in some sectors of the community. In particular, the financial arrangements for the territory—a matter of considerable concern at the time of the self-government referendum in 1978—appear to be working satisfactorily. What works less satisfactorily is the delineation between the respective roles of the National Capital Authority and the legislative assembly. This has created, on occasions, a disjointed approach to the planning of Canberra—a matter that must be addressed.

I said earlier that I represent a special community. In saying this I do not mean to suggest that it is an artificial or elite community. In fact, the energies, the talents, the ambitions and the creativity of the people of this city are purely Australian in character, different only from the qualities exhibited by other Australians, perhaps, in the concentration in which they are encountered here. It follows that, if we are proud of Australia, we should be proud of Canberra, the showcase of a young nation. Canberra is the extraordinary achievement of ordinary people.

The test of these propositions came only very recently when Canberra was ravaged by a natural disaster on a scale not previously thought possible anywhere in urban Australia, much less in the national capital. The bushfire of 18 January and subsequent days was an extraordinary test of the character of this city. By any measure it passed that test, and in doing so gave rise to a new appraisal of the city and its inhabitants by those outside it. As Matt Price writing in the Australian on 20 January put it:

quote.para: Canberra is often accused of being a soulless place, too full of transitory types less interested in the local community than the large national institutions that give the compromise capital its bad reputation. The weekend put an end to that lie.

Practically everyone in Canberra knew someone whose property was lost or seriously under threat. They responded superbly. Stories abounded of suburban heroics; residents remaining in danger areas to tend absent neighbours' homes, endless offers of food, shelter and assistance for traumatised victims.
Death seemed almost inevitable but when confirmed there was barely time to comprehend this loss of life as fire raged through the night.

speech.para: The rest of Australia saw that Canberrans, when cut, did indeed bleed. It also saw that the finest Australian tradition of mateship was honoured in suburban courage and heroism all over the city. The stream of mattresses and blankets to the evacuation centres on that Saturday night was very moving. I heard of one elderly lady who gave away her late model car to a family that had lost theirs, but she was embarrassed by the fact that it had only six months registration on it left to run.

Of course, if it takes a major event such as a war to define a state, then the bushfire disaster in January could be considered to have been such an event for us. The intensity and speed of the fires themselves, the destruction they caused, the loss of four lives—all these things will leave a mark on the consciousness of this city. The bushfires, like no other event, have seen the people of the ACT draw together in an incredible spirit of community. And so I ask—no, Mr President, I demand— that honourable senators fix in their minds that image of this city, that image of a city afflicted but unbowed, when next they refer to it in far flung corners of this country. I hope that they think and talk of Canberra in the terms this city was conceived—that is, as a place to be proud of, as a repository of the best achievements in the Australian way of life. I take this as my task in this place, to defend that vision of the national capital. I know that it is commonplace for people, especially politicians, to use the term `Canberra' to refer to anything about the federal government that they disdain. But in doing so they can stigmatise and belittle those Australians who live here, many of whom work for the national government but have no more say in its decisions than those who criticise it.

The generosity of spirit towards this city which I ask for was abundantly evident among those who fought the fires and their aftermath. The emergency services of Canberra—professional and volunteer—were superb in circumstances no amount of training could have prepared them for. Whatever might be said about the causes of this disaster, let nothing detract from this fact: courage and selflessness abounded in Canberra on those terrible January days and, but for that, the destruction wrought in our streets would have been much, much greater.

Mr President, let me describe the contribution I want to make to the life of this country through membership of the Senate. Change is an immutable feature of our lives. Politics for me is thus an exercise in managing and directing change. If to be a conservative is to resist or defy change, then I am not a conservative. Indeed, the work of this government—work I want to carry forward—has been about managing and directing change in a modern Australia: change in the workplace; change in Australia's international competitiveness; change in access to quality health care; change in our education and welfare systems.

I am here to argue for the enduring relevance of Liberal values as tools in facing up to the problems of this nation and indeed our world: the values of independence, self-reliance, tolerance, the pursuit of excellence, choice, equality of opportunity and individual freedom. In turn I reject as bankrupt the socialist alternative. That alternative fails to appreciate that people who have no incentive to work and invest will not create wealth. It thinks that collectivism and standardisation in the workplace are a substitute for hard work and innovation. It sees government as a better solver of people's problems than they are themselves.

I am proud of the achievements of this nation, and I am proud of the role my party has played in shaping the kind of Australia whose citizens could bring forth those achievements. I have no truck with those who elevate Australia's shortcomings above our successes. Although I acknowledge the need to accommodate improvement and change, I refuse to be apologetic about the kind of country we are today.

I am particularly proud of the role my party has played in the building of Canberra. Almost every major institution and monument gracing this city has been the legacy of a decision of a coalition government. This was underscored when, after years of Labor chest-beating, it was in fact the government of Prime Minister John Howard that actually placed brick upon brick to build the National Museum of Australia. Long after the nitpicking has subsided, that important national symbol will stand testament to his and his government's commitment to Canberra and to preserving our heritage.

I come to take my place in the Senate with an agenda for what I hope to achieve. My agenda is unashamedly Canberra-centric. It can be summarised as valuing and building up the physical and human assets of this city in the service of a national interest. For example, it would be hard to overstate the importance of the Australian Public Service to the future of this city and, indeed, to the welfare of the Australian community generally.

The business of our Public Service is nation-building, nothing less. It has undergone many changes in recent years, but I believe its professionalism and worth have never stood at a higher level. A quality bureaucracy will be efficient, innovative, constantly in pursuit of best practice, and apolitical—a test our Public Service meets entirely. We must be prepared to nurture and develop this resource if we are to match the relentlessly growing expectations of Australians for service delivery from government.

The physical location of component parts of that Public Service is an issue that has long been of concern to Canberrans. Government functions should not be moved around the country for short-term political advantage. On the other hand, in pursuit of an efficient and innovative Public Service, it is difficult to argue against a departmental relocation that enhances the integrity of that department or agency's mission. But, if that test is not satisfied, this senator's voice will be insistent and clear.

Valuing the Public Service and valuing public servants are one and the same thing. We must never allow the market to put high-quality public servants beyond our reach, at any level. We should also honour those who have served in the Commonwealth bureaucracy. I am aware that the position of Commonwealth superannuants has deteriorated relative to other pension recipients in recent years, and I commit myself to doing something about that problem.

I have heard it said that, with the advent of the National Museum of Australia, the task of building Canberra is nearing completion. That view is nonsense. The work of creating a national capital like this is the work of many generations. Just as we have ambitions for the growth and development of Australia, so too we should have ambitions for the growth and development of its symbolic centre. That work will never be complete, whilst ever Australians remain a dynamic and forward looking people. National institutions need to be expanded to showcase the inexhaustible creativity and accomplishments of our countrymen, and new institutions, such as an air and space museum or a national centre for the performing arts, deserve consideration amongst our national treasures. The ACT also desperately needs a new convention centre.

There are other issues. The task of bedding down and taking advantage of Australia's steps towards tax reform a few years ago must not be overlooked. These reforms have the potential to invigorate Australian competitiveness as a range of other taxes disappear in the wake of the GST. We need to take determined strides to end the seemingly perpetual brawling and buck-passing around the long-range health policy of this country. When the Commonwealth and states slug it out on health funding issues, the only sure losers are the sick.

In education, vigilance over standards needs to be matched with an awareness of the increasing mobility of Australians, and the need therefore to find opportunities for children and adults to carry credit from previous study with them from state to state. And work beckons on a national savings strategy, to counter the fact that 99½ per cent of Australians' weekly income is spent and not saved.

Our relationship with Indigenous Australians commands our attention. This parliament, built on the traditional lands of the Ngunnawal people, has taken steps in recent years to create a legislative framework for recognising traditional land ownership rights. That process has, it seems to me, a great distance yet to go to shape a relationship of trust and respect with Aboriginal people that is vital to our society's future health.

Australia's security needs confront us all at present. As a democratic and affluent nation, Australia quite properly has a role to play in defence of the human rights of others elsewhere in this world. I am an internationalist. I reject the notion—suddenly very fashionable among the Australian Left—that human rights outside our region no longer have the compelling merit they once did.

I also hope to contribute to continuing the important work of this government in facing up to our massive environmental problems, such as growing salinity and greenhouse gas emissions. I know that the record of my party stands proudly on protection of the environment. It was coalition governments that established the first federal environment ministry, declared the Kakadu National Park, the Uluru National Park and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, enacted legislation to protect the Antarctic, and banned whaling. Perhaps my time here might also contribute in a small way to attacking the decline in trust as a given in so many public relationships. Charles Moore, writing in the Spectator last year, said this:

quote.para: Church, school, army, police, parliament, surgery, court, bank used all to be words that had only to be deployed to put the honest citizen's mind at ease. Now there is the implication that they all represent institutions with their own agendas (a characteristic coinage of modern debate), their own selfish interests, their own dirty secrets.

speech.para: He wrote about Britain, but his words could apply equally in this country. On the subject of trust, I put on record today my appreciation to the membership of the Liberal Party in the ACT for choosing, among a very strong field of candidates, to place their trust in me. It is, however, the citizens of Canberra whose trust I need to win. I am conscious that I sit here as an appointed, not an elected, senator. In setting out to win that trust, I will take as my model the energy and dedication to serving this community that my predecessor Margaret Reid exhibited over her years in this place—a magnificent example. I hope that my wife, Cathie, and my sons, Felix and Owain, will not begrudge me the many hours away from home that that commitment will represent.

I also want to thank sincerely the many friends and supporters who share some of the mission I have outlined today, some of whom are present in the gallery.
