I wish to thank especially Tim McGhie, who has now assisted in the preparation of all three ACT Liberal senators' maiden speeches over a quarter century. Finally, Mr President, I wish to thank you and honourable senators for allowing me to proceed with this speech today, accompanied by the usual courtesies, despite other important business pressing down on this place.

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of former senator Margaret Reid.

—As I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Hill today, I congratulate Senator Humphries on his first speech in this place. I am quite sure that, with the experience he has already had in the ACT parliament, we will see many more contributions by Senator Humphries and we certainly look forward to working with him in the future.

speech.para: In moving to support the motion by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, I could not help but reflect on a couple of the contributions already made by senators in this debate. I think particularly of the contribution by the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Bartlett. He made what I consider to be one of the worst speeches—one with an extreme point of view and filled with illogicality—that I have ever heard in this place. I could not but notice that one of the things he said was that we should give peace a chance and let the weapons inspectors do their work. The question which Senator Bartlett should really ask is: how long do you give a regime—how many years and how many months—to rid themselves, by peaceful means, of weapons of mass destruction? We are talking about a country which has had more than 12 years to comply with a United Nation's resolution. It was not until the United States put pressure on the Iraqi regime and Saddam Hussein, through putting a military force in the Persian Gulf, that Iraq let weapons inspectors back into Iraq. Since that time, we have seen incremental moves by Iraq—doing as little as possible—to try and satisfy the whims of the United Nations, which over the past 50 or so years has had some successes and some terrible failures.

It is the United Nations and the role of the Security Council and its member states that I want to discuss briefly now. Like at least two or three other members of this chamber, I had the opportunity to spend almost four months at the United Nations only a couple of years ago. That experience taught me that the United Nations does some things quite well. I can say that, since its inception, the effectiveness of the United Nations in attempting to maintain international peace and security has been challenged by the need to balance two of the key principles underpinning its existence in the international system—that is, how does the United Nations system balance the sovereign equality of nation states with the protection of human rights within those nation states? The challenge of balancing these principles again presented itself to the United Nations on the question of Iraq and how best to respond to its blatant disregard for Security Council resolutions and human rights violations. How the United Nations has responded may have dramatic ramifications for the future of its role in the international system.

I said that the United Nations has a history of doing some things very well. I can tell you from my time there that there are some things which it does very well. It is very good in the area of world health and getting countries to cooperate in delivering better health conditions, particularly for some of the Third World countries. We have seen its role in the eradication of polio, smallpox and a whole range of other deadly diseases which have afflicted this world over a period of time. The United Nations has been very good at that. The United Nations has been very good at helping emerging democracies, where there has been no democracy for years, and teaching those countries how to develop a democracy and set up democratic institutions. The United Nations is very good in some areas of education. For example, in many countries it has helped in the education of young people and the education of those previously deprived of that opportunity. But, historically, the United Nations has failed abysmally when situations have arisen that fundamentally question the legitimacy of regimes that continually perpetrate human rights violations against their own people. That is where the United Nations has failed abysmally, and it has failed abysmally for years.

In 1992, Bosnian Serbs in the former Yugoslavia began a murderous campaign of ethnic cleansing against Muslims and Croats. The United Nations took over eight months to send a deployment of troops, and by this time Bosnian Serb forces had taken over 70 per cent of Bosnia's territory and delivered enormous suffering and human casualties. That sort of delay by the United Nations has caused human rights violations and casualties to occur and the United Nations has a lot to answer for as a result. Furthermor, there was a distinct lack of United Nations action in the Kosovo crisis of the late 1990s. To all of those people who demand that there should not be any military involvement in Iraq without the sanction of the United Nations—or without a further 18th resolution to make sure that the United Nations is totally in support of what might happen—I say: where were you in the mid-1990s when the United States and NATO decided that they would go into Kosovo without United Nation sanction to free those people who were being so terribly treated in Kosovo at that time?

The opposition was noticeably silent on the need for a United Nations resolution in that case. Perhaps opposition speakers to follow can include in their contributions to this debate some of the reasons why it is so necessary today to have a United Nations resolution or an 18th resolution passed by the Security Council when, in Kosovo, there was no need for any resolution at all and they supported what took place at that time. Terrible human rights violations were being perpetrated in Kosovo through ethnic cleansing. What is the difference between the situation there and the situation in Iraq today, where we know the sorts of human rights violations that are being perpetrated against the people of Iraq?

It was the threat of a veto by China and Russia that prevented a Security Council resolution on military action in Kosovo, despite growing humanitarian concerns in the wake of systematic ethnic cleansing. It was the threat of a veto by France in this instance, in exactly the same way that China and Russia threatened to use that veto in the late 1990s when action was taken in Kosovo, that has caused action to be taken without a special Security Council resolution. What is the difference between the situation then and the situation now? I will be interested to hear what members of the opposition and the Democrats have to say about the situation then and the necessity right now, in this situation, for there to be an 18th Security Council resolution. The role of stabilising the situation then was left to NATO, under the leadership of the United States and with strong support from the United Kingdom. Exactly the same two countries have shown strong leadership in this situation in the face of the threat of a veto in the Security Council. From 29 March to 9 June 1999, in the absence of a United Nations mandate, NATO took military action against Serbia to stop the persecution of civilians. NATO was successful and Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic agreed to NATO demands.

A similar pattern has presented itself in Iraq. Saddam Hussein has a proven record of terror, just like the terror that was being inflicted on the people of Kosovo and on Bosnian Serbs earlier in that decade. Many blatant acts of brutality against civilians and the neighbours of Iraq have occurred systematically since Saddam Hussein's rise to power in Iraq. There are still over 600 cases, representing 14 nationalities, of missing gulf prisoners of war or people missing in action and only four of those cases have been resolved. According to the United Nations, Iraq remains the country with the highest number of disappearances in the world. Yet we hear senators opposite and Democrats senators saying, `Let the weapons inspectors have more time.' In fact, they have had 12 or 13 years. Let us not forget that, during the Iraqi government's so-called Anfal campaign against the Kurdish people in northern Iraq, an estimated 100,000 Kurds died or disappeared. That is a statistic that we should never be allowed to forget.

Saddam Hussein became the first leader in the post Second World War era to systematically and aggressively gas his own people. This is the sort of person that the Labor Party and the Democrats want to give more time to. Should he be given more time to systematically gas or inflict human rights abuses upon more of his own people? Thousands of people have been executed. Torture has been extensively documented, through techniques that have been described in detail on many other occasions. The United Nations should not have sat back and waited as Saddam Hussein continued to persecute his own people and to threaten both his neighbours and the stability of the international system with his continued pursuit of a weapons of mass destruction capability. If the United Nations cannot reach agreement and simply sits back and does nothing, should we as international citizens sit back and watch those Iraqi people suffering? We have international responsibilities. I am delighted that the Prime Minister and the government have today decided to exercise those international responsibilities.

Can I say to those people who march in the streets for peace that peace is something we all want. There is not one person in this chamber who would not prefer peace as an option. Those who oppose any unilateral role outside of a United Nations mandate did not mind the role outside of a mandate when it occurred in Bosnia or in Kosovo. It is only in Iraq where they consider a mandate is required. There are those who are worrying about the possibility of civilian casualties. Where were those people when the UN failed to respond to the massacre of millions of men, women and children under the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia or to the many other human tragedies—such as that in Rwanda or, currently, in the Sudan—in our recent history? None of those countries possessed weapons of mass destruction. We know that in fact Iraq does possess those weapons.

The Labor opposition seem to want to have their cake and eat it too. They do not deny that there are weapons of mass destruction. They agree that weapons of mass destruction must be gotten rid of. If the United Nations Security Council had voted to get rid of those weapons, they would have been quite happy to support military action against Iraq. On the Security Council, some of the African countries like Cameroon and others were to make the decision as to whether or not there should be a majority.

The strange thing is that, if those weapons of mass destruction still exist, if they are still in Iraq, and even if the opposition think they should be got rid of, they say, `It is okay if the United Nations says you can get rid of them, but if the United Nations doesn't give you a specific mandate in the 18th resolution of the Security Council regarding Iraq then it is quite okay for Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi regime to keep them. In the absence of a specific United Nations mandate, it is okay for Saddam Hussein to keep those weapons.' That is a logic that I and many others in Australia simply cannot follow. If weapons of mass destruction are wrong, they are wrong with or without another mandate from the United Nations for military action to get rid of those weapons.

I join my colleagues in wishing those serving in our defence forces well. They serve our country with pride in a faraway country with families at home who no doubt worry. It is easy to understand how the families of servicemen can be deeply affected by deployments overseas, as has been the case with other overseas deployments. I would cite East Timor, Bougainville and all the other more recent activities in which we have taken part, where our defence forces served with pride their government and their country overseas. I certainly wish them well and hope that any conflict will be short.

I also express my admiration for the strength of the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair. I did not think I would ever see the day that I would stand up in this place and speak with admiration of a Labour Prime Minister. He has served his country so well and has shown such strength of character—a strength of character which, I am sorry to say, we have not seen in the current Leader of the Opposition in Australia, nor in the contribution made by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. Tony Blair, in the face of all the information that has been provided to him, has chosen the path that he believes is right for his country, even though he knows there is opposition within his own party and within his own country.

It is a fact that nobody other than those in executive control of a government can be fully informed of all the facts that are available. Many times we have heard people in Australia say, `Just give us some more information. Tell us what you know, and then maybe we'll support you.' It is in fact impossible for the executive arm of any government to release to the public every piece of information they have. Much of it is intelligence. Here, much of it is garnered from our intelligence organisations and from intelligence organisations overseas. Much of the information that is given to us by other intelligence organisations cannot be given to the Australian public. It is only given to us on the understanding that it remains intelligence information for the government of the day, the executive or the other intelligence organisations within Australia. If you told the Australian public or anybody else all your intelligence, you simply would not get intelligence anymore.

There is a limit to what the Australian public and the public anywhere in the world can be told. Members of the Labor Party who were members of the government back in 1991, the last time there was a war in the gulf, would know that there are certain pieces of information that simply cannot be provided to the public. The executive must make that decision, and they will be judged on that decision by the people of Australia at some stage in the future. We know that, and I think it was a very bold decision of the Prime Minister to accept responsibility knowing that his actions will be judged at some stage in the future by the Australian people because, fortunately, unlike Iraq, we live in a democracy where the people of the country can choose their leader—something that is denied to the people of Iraq.

My final point is that strategic alliances are very important to Australia and to Australia's future. We on the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade are in the middle of an inquiry into maritime strategies. One of the questions people often ask is, `Should we be self-reliant?' or, `Is it feasible to look at self-reliance as a strategic objective in this current day and age?' My personal view is that it is not feasible. A country our size cannot be self-reliant. We need strategic alliances. The United States has been our longest and strongest ally for a number of years. It is not just now that we need this strategic alliance with the United States, the world's only superpower; we also need a strategic alliance that will provide safety and security for the future. I am quite sure that anybody who has been involved in the decision making that has gone on in the last month or two knows how important that strategic alliance with the United States is for our future and for the safety of our children and, as time goes by, their children.

I fully support the motion moved today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. We are not looking forward to the events of the coming days, but we do hope that the events that we are now committed to can be concluded quickly, with a minimum of casualties both in the civilian population and in the defence forces. We hope that at the end of the day a tyrant who has been in power for years, committing human rights violations on a scale not unprecedented but certainly as large as those we have seen in other countries in recent times, will no longer be there—and neither will his weapons of mass destruction.

talk.start.para: —History, I believe, will remember today as the day Australia betrayed any sense of independence and signed up to starting a war which was not in this nation's national interest. Tragically, I believe history will remember today as the day that our Prime Minister committed our troops to the control of a US command on the basis of a phone call after an international strategy meeting to which he was not invited.

speech.para: I ask the Senate to pause for a moment. Put aside all that rhetoric we have heard from government senators and from the Prime Minister. Put aside the words `strategy' and `alliance' and every other like word and just think about what we are actually doing today. We are committing Australian lives to war. We are jeopardising lives from around the world, but the decision we are taking today is to commit Australian forces to a conflict from which many of them will not return. It is so much easier to commit other people's lives when we camouflage it all in strategies, alliances and such rhetoric. But I ask the Senate to stop for a moment and think of some of the footage that we have seen in recent weeks of soldiers and their young kids and families, of the photographs we have seen in the press of people who are just barely 20 or so, whom we are committing to a conflict far away from here in the knowledge that a lot of them will not come back. Just think of the human cost.

When we went into Vietnam it was just a small number of special advisers. Thousands of Australians lost their lives there. I wish this government showed a lot more humanity and sensitivity. Sadly, we can reasonably predict that there will be Australian casualties. We can reasonably predict that this Prime Minister will have blood on his hands out of this conflict. And we should not forget his shameful dereliction of the responsibilities of national leadership which demand of him, which demand of any prime minister and which demand of any minister representing the Australian people that they put the interests of the Australian people before the interests of the great superpower, the United States of America in this case, not vice versa as they have done in this instance.

This debate is a grave and serious one. But I sadly reflect on the potential human cost of not only Australians but other allied forces, and not only allied forces but the hundreds of thousands of Iraqis—men, women and children—who will suffer and who may lose their lives. When Senator Ferguson says that under our system of democracy the Prime Minister will face his judgment, sadly a lot of those people whom we are committing today will not be here to pass judgment on this Prime Minister. As I say, it is so much easier when we are sacrificing other people's lives and not those of our families. I wish this Prime Minister took seriously the job of representing these people when they feel and they say very loudly that it is not in this nation's national interest to start a war in another part of world when we have so many other priorities in our national interest closer to home.

In speaking in this debate, I draw some background knowledge from my membership of the Hawke government's first Gulf War war cabinet committee. That experience has led me, like many of my colleagues, to more accurately appreciate the real challenges involved in the current ambitious US plans. I also come to this debate as someone who is not opposed to the US alliance. I believe it still has relevance and importance to Australia. However, I do not believe that this alliance demands that Australia cede national sovereignty and decision making to a group of extreme right-wing Republican politicians who, for the moment, control the White House.

Australians and Americans share many values and experiences. In this current crisis war is supported and opposed by many people in both countries. In fact, much of the most powerful antiwar material is at present being generated in the USA. Under alliance treaties, Australia has a legal right to say no to US demands. In this instance, I believe we also have a moral right to say no, as we have in the past and as an Australian Labor government did in respect of the conflict in Vietnam.

It is clear that this Prime Minister does not have the courage to stand up and tell G.W. Bush what the Australian people are thinking and think is in this country's national interest. Not only does he not have the courage to front President Bush but we are in the unfortunate situation where our Prime Minister does not even have the courage to front the Australian people. While he sends our soldiers off to Iraq to fight his war, he cannot even summon the courage to go to the suburbs of Australia—Leichhardt, Thebarton, Balwyn and Lower Templestowe, for instance—to argue and fight for his decisions. He does it from the comfort of a TV or radio studio. He is not prepared to go out and meet the people. This is a Prime Minister who is so charged with ego that he struts around the world thinking he is Winston Churchill, when the truth is anyone who sees him believes he is Captain Mainwaring.

This is a difficult situation, and this is a war that did not have to start. The UN process was achieving an enormous amount—a lot more than I am sure the American administration thought it would achieve when they embarked down the road of the UN. There is enormous opposition to this war. For me, one of the main reasons that public opinion worldwide is so solidly against the war is that people are deeply concerned at the competence and motives of those who lead us into it. People worldwide are concerned that the US administration behaves as if it were reliving a Ronald Reagan B-grade movie. They see all too transparently the exercise of might over right by what is increasingly coming to look like a group of latter-day Texan oil claimjumpers.

Despite the comprehensive and consistent efforts of the world's media, people are seeing right through the US administration and they are expressing their fears. The war, we are told once more, is about to happen, and it is happening without real debate and understanding of the consequences and impacts. What debate, for instance, have we had in this country? What discussion have we had? What understanding is there of the regional and global consequences of what the USA proposes? What are the implications for global stability of the numbers of victims and refugees? What do we really expect the invasion to achieve? How long will it take? What are we really seeking to establish by so-called regime change? What are the implications for the international rule of law and the status of the United Nations? Importantly for Australia and Australians, what are the implications for our national security? All these questions remain unanswered. They should have been critical issues in a genuine debate before it reached the point that we have reached today, but they have only been given cursory attention.

The Prime Minister, John Howard, is not leading this country into war with any sense of dignity and honesty; he is misleading this nation into war. We are being misled, as we have been asked to believe over the last few months the fiction that this government had not made a decision to commit—it had not made a decision, so a decision was not up to scrutiny. Further, we were told just a few weeks ago that the PM, when he went overseas on a peace mission, was advocating peace when all he was doing was advocating a war.

This nation is being misled because the Prime Minister wants to go to war outside the rule of international law as embodied in the UN Charter. I believe we are being misled because the case for war has not been made. We are told an invasion into Iraq is an important step in the war against terror. Yet short of a plagiarised and inadequate UK government document, no case has been led to prove the link between al-Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. Instead of evidence, the world has been subjected to a two-pronged campaign from the USA—a campaign that spied on states that were not part of the coalition of the willing, a campaign that sought to buy votes. It was a campaign of spy and buy, and the campaign did not work because such a campaign was not a good enough substitute for the real evidence that was needed.
We are being misled into war because the judgment to go to war is, I believe, fundamentally flawed. For instance, in 1996 former President Bush, the current President's father, said:

quote.para: To occupy Iraq would instantly shatter our coalition, turning the whole Arab world against us, and make a broken tyrant into a latter-day Arab hero.

speech.para: Around the same time, Dick Cheney, who is now the Vice-President, said:

quote.para: To have brought the Gulf war into the populous Iraqi capital of Baghdad ... would have put large numbers of Iraqi civilians and hundreds of thousands of our troops at risk of being killed.

speech.para: That is a reflection on the earlier Gulf War— one that is quite pertinent when we assess the judgment that our leaders have taken in respect of this one. Cheney also added that if the US were to engage in another war with Iraq and try to remove Saddam Hussein from power, the international coalition `would come apart'. We are now doing what both Bush Sr and Cheney warned against—and we are on the verge of paying the price that they predicted. We are being misled because not only Australia but indeed the whole world has for a long time not been told the real purpose of this invasion. What was the end game to be? What is the end game to be now? Was it the dismantling of weapons of mass destruction? Is it to be regime change, or is it, as many right-wing US think tanks demand, cultural dominance of the region? In this context Australians have been asked to give President Bush and Co. a blank cheque on this central issue.

Increasingly, more and more Australians think that we are being misled because they are concerned that the Howard government's commitment and rhetoric are not in our national interest. Australians can see that their government is making them and this nation a target. Howard, by his misguided leadership, is inviting and inciting action against Australia and Australians both at home and abroad. Australians can see, for instance, that of all the countries which form part of the coalition of the willing we alone are surrounded by countries with large Muslim communities, each with their own domestic challenges to contain extremism. Our action does not assist them in their efforts—we make it harder for them. In this context, Australians see the potential dangers from North Korea as being a priority over a war in another region—and they are asking why this government, their government, cannot see the obvious.

I believe we are being misled because Australia, under John Howard, has picked this fight. We were presented with two options: the UN and its rule book—the course that I and the Labor Party favour—or the unilateralism offered by the US. We chose to reject the international rule book and the protection it offers. Saddam Hussein does present a real problem. He needs to be addressed and the problem needs to be addressed, but the issue has always been: how do you do this most effectively? How do you contain Hussein without giving oxygen to terrorists and terrorism world wide? For me, the UN is the only option. It is empowered to do so; it is on the way to doing so. Blix is achieving results, and his process should have been given the extra time needed. But John Howard and this government have never really given Blix a chance. The Prime Minister has chosen to protect the international rule book by scrapping it, and I do not think that is a legitimate approach.

It is going to be extremely hard to predict, and anything may eventuate from the invasion, but as we embark upon the last stages of this process I think we should consider some of the direct consequences and implications of US led action outside UN authorisation. Firstly, we do turn on the taps of oxygen to potential terrorists world wide, particularly in the Middle East and in our region. Lord Hurd, the former Conservative foreign minister, recently asked, `Do we help or do we hinder the war against terrorism by invading Iraq?' He further asked:

quote.para: Would we thus turn the Middle East into a set of friendly democratic capitalist societies ready to make peace with Israel, or into a region of sullen humiliation, a fertile and almost inexhaustible recruiting ground for further terrorists for whom Britain is a main target?

speech.para: In other words, what Lord Hurd was saying was: even if we win, do we lose? And in so doing, do we destabilise moderate Arab regimes, further undermine the security of Israel and breed more terrorists for the world to handle? Particularly for Australia, do we ignite the embers of terrorism in our region and make ourselves a target? In Iraq itself, how do we handle a potential Kurdish state in conflict with Turkey—a continuing conflict which still has not, in the preparation for war, been accommodated in any sense at all? How do we handle the Shia entity in the south, united with Iran? Indeed, what will happen to leaderships in the region—such as those in Turkey, Iran and elsewhere—in the aftermath of these events?

Unfortunately, you do not find these questions addressed in our media—a media which wants us all to believe that we are about to embark upon a high-tech, quick and victimless war. It is almost like a computer game. It is the same media who told us some 10 months ago that the US would get an all-empowering resolution through the Security Council in a matter of days and that the war would be over by the end of September. As I said earlier, my position is that the UN, the body which has been empowered with the authority in these matters for over 50 years, should be trusted in respect of what further action is necessary. And it looks like it will not be.

I would like to address a couple of other issues that I believe will have some longer term consequences. Whatever happens over the next few weeks, there is probably one relationship which needs close attention— and that is the one between the USA and Europe. Tension between these two entities is not new. Under the Bush administration, there have been deep divisions over a number of issues such as privacy, Kyoto and regulation of the tobacco industry—just to name a few. Iraq comes on top of these issues and could very well lead to a lasting disconnection between former NATO allied countries.

European leaders can see that this US administration has failed the test of leadership. They have seen Bush's proposal being frozen by the world community for some 10 months in the Security Council. They have seen Prime Minister Blair do the President's bidding when the President was not up to it. They have felt the sting of personal abuse from the US administration and its media outlets and they can see a potential for themselves to take a more critical role in world leadership. I am not saying that this is a definite turning point, a return to bi-polarity in world affairs, but at least for the moment G.W. Bush has done what 50 to 60 years of Soviet leadership could not—and that is to put distance between important European nations and the USA.

Whatever happens, there will also be one lasting issue of concern for Australia. We are still defining our role within the region. We had a blemished history with our White Australia Policy. We were working to overcome that. Now we are developing an identity as the deputy sheriff of the USA. In this context, being one of a handful of countries prepared to go it alone against Saddam Hussein threatens our national security. I think we can fairly predict that Australia and Australians will be at greater risk at home and abroad, given the presence of terrorist cells so close to our shores. In the next few weeks, therefore, there will probably be a change in international politics in a manner which was not anticipated by the Republican White House when it embarked on this high-risk strategy. There will be bruised egos and bruised national prides, although it is hard to identify where they will be. To repeat the words of former Minister Hurd, there will be at least one `region of sullen humiliation'. It is hard for us to predict which of a number it will be—USA, Europe, the Middle East, Asia. Whatever one it is, it is going to have enormous repercussions for this country.

In closing, I repeat the point I made at the start: my real feeling and sentiment and priority on a day like today is for the people and families who will be affected by this particular conflict. In a sense, we are far removed from it and we can—although we should not—look at it in a dispassionate way, as has been reflected I believe by some of the government speeches this afternoon. The fact is that we are sacrificing the lives of Australian soldiers and their families in this conflict—a conflict which, to be honest, is not our fight. It is not one that we planned. It is one that we have been dragged along to because this Prime Minister initially thought that there would be domestic advantage out of it but who probably now thinks he has to follow the President of the United States whoever that President is—particularly this one, a President who strokes his ego from time to time and has done so over the last couple of years. It is the wrong reason to go to war. It is a decision that should not have been taken. It is a decision that the Australian people do not support.

talk.start.para: —This is a speech that I certainly did not want to be standing here today giving. Indeed, the series of speeches both in this house and in the other place today is one that I think the majority of the Australian population did not want to hear. Indeed, the latest opinion polls tell us that some 71 per cent of Australians are opposed to our involvement in this war.

speech.para: To start at the beginning of the motion, at paragraph (a), yes, we should certainly condemn Iraq's initial refusal to abide by the resolutions passed by the United Nations Security Council. But ultimately the question of whether or not it has complied is an issue for the United Nations and not for the United States. When did America appoint itself the head of the world's police force when there was no conflict? There is no actual conflict; there is only a potential for a conflict. Why are we, Australia, joining now in the posse? Apart from the fact that this war is not even America's call, where has the US been on the 32 occasions when Israel has refused to abide by UN resolutions? Or Pakistan? Or India? Or the Palestinians? The list goes on—all of those countries refusing to abide by UN resolutions. Why is this government so willing to follow the lead of a country whose argument is so illogical and riddled with inconsistencies, self-interest and hypocrisy?

Article 42 of the UN Charter sets out that it is the Security Council that is delegated to authorise military action. Without a second resolution, an act of aggression against Iraq could well be illegal. New precedents for dispute resolution in the years ahead are being set by what we are now agreeing to, by what we are now being a part of. The reason the US would not put another resolution before the UN is that it would most certainly fail. The United Nations is far from unanimous that Iraq is a major threat. Basically, the US decided that it would go for cover, that it would twist around previous resolutions and try to justify what it is doing on that basis.

Moving to paragraph (b) of the motion, by their own admission and in their very detailed reports the UN weapons inspectors have found very few weapons and those that they have discovered Iraq has been progressively destroying. Some have already been destroyed; others were in the process of being destroyed at the time America decided that it would not wait any longer. America basically has built its argument on a sea of sifting sands. The reasons change almost daily. It did start arguing that Iraq had to disarm and if Iraq refused to let the weapons inspectors in then that was a case for war. The weapons inspectors went in and Iraq started to disarm, albeit slowly. Iraq was complying with UN resolutions, allowing the weapons inspectors access and then starting the destruction of those 70 al-Samoud II missiles and, I understand, some 42 warheads so far. Ploy or not, Iraq invited the UN inspectors back to discuss new evidence of accelerated disarmament. But now the US has shifted the goalposts: not only now does it want Saddam Hussein out as a necessary condition to prevent war but also today it has decided that his sons are added to the list and they too must leave the country in order to avoid war.

talk.start.para: —Such good boys!
—Senator McGauran, I will take that interjection. No-one is suggesting for a moment that either Saddam Hussein or his sons are people who have looked after the population of their country.
(Senator Lightfoot)—Senator Lees, you may take the interjection but you should nonetheless address it through the chair.

—Sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. To address the interjection through the chair, which I will cover further and later in my speech, I am not suggesting one way or the other the likelihood that Saddam Hussein and his sons are of a benefit to the country; I am simply arguing strongly that the US should not keep changing the goalposts and keep raising the bar as to what Iraq needs to do in order to prevent war. The US is obviously determined to go to war regardless of what Iraq does.

speech.para: Let us look at what some others who know what is happening in Iraq have said. A former UK cabinet minister, Robin Cook, has said that following the first Gulf War, as a result of all the destruction and devastation of the country and as a result of the sanctions that were imposed after that, Iraq has largely been crippled, economically and militarily and that it is not therefore a serious, immediate threat either to the region or to world peace. All the evidence suggests that the international pressure has largely contained Saddam Hussein and his sons. If Iraq is such a threat to the security of the world and if it really does have these weapons and is intent on using them, then why is America letting us know, step by step, everything it is planning to do? Successful military action has in the past relied on secrecy, stealth and surprise. None of these have been put into play this time. The military plans of the US and its few allies have been well telegraphed in advance. Why? Because there really is no substantial threat.

Paragraph (b) of the motion mentions potential damage to Australia's security. How will it be damaged? Perhaps future speakers would like to pick up on this issue. How is Iraq a danger to us? I would suggest that, in fact, it is the war that is likely to damage our security. Australia's unwarranted participation in this war is likely to anger our neighbours, and while, as Senator Hill mentioned, some presidents have expressed their belief that they are not in any way opposed to Australia and, indeed, want to remain friends, much of their populations feel otherwise. It will give terrorists in this region yet another reason to pursue their campaigns. Obviously, we must continue to fight terrorism. But the deliberate terrorising of an entire nation is hardly a sensible strategy. There is no logic in the argument that, by launching a war against Iraq, global terrorism will be reduced. In fact, it is highly likely that by attacking Iraq and generating antagonism and anger, particularly towards the US and its allies, across the Muslim world the risk to us will actually increase.

The UN, the organisation trusted by the world for the past 50 years to work for peace, has clearly set out two scenarios in which war might be justified. The first is in self-defence and the second is for humanitarian reasons. America can hardly argue self-defence in the case of Iraq while it also confidently claims that this war is going to be over in a couple of weeks—at an absolute maximum, 90 days, according to today's press. Given that Iraq is such a huge threat, it seems that the war is going to be very short! How can America argue on one hand that Iraq is so ill-prepared but, on the other hand, that it may have these weapons that pose such a terrible risk that we therefore have to go to war against it? It simply does not make sense.

Paragraph (c) of the motion mentions Iraq's continued support for international terrorism. There is no link between Iraq and either the events of September 11 a couple of years ago or last year's Bali atrocities. A number of other countries have been linked to these events, but so far Iraq has not. Paragraph (c) also refers to the abuse of the Iraqi people. Yes, Saddam is a tyrant. He has little regard for anyone who opposes him or, indeed, anyone who hints they may be capable of opposing him. Saddam Hussein is a cruel and ruthless leader; we are not debating that. But arguably he is no worse than many other dictators around the world, and I give Zimbabwe as just one example. And what are we doing there? We are off to play cricket.

Australia is about to take part in a war with a country where half the population is under the age of 16 and where international sanctions over the last 12 years have taken a devastating toll. Malnutrition is widespread. Cholera, hepatitis and typhoid are common, malaria and dysentery are rampant and 4,000 children die every month from starvation and preventable diseases. Paying attention to the sanctions is one way of dealing with some of these issues, and that is certainly a road we should be taking before we consider bombing this country.

This morning, the Prime Minister said that this war is not in Australia's interests but is necessary for humanitarian reasons. Someone needs to explain to me how bombing a country with so many children, deliberately trying to destroy roads, infrastructure, bridges, communication facilities and electricity-generating facilities, cutting off millions of people's access to food sources and, very likely, creating a cholera epidemic thanks to the backup of raw sewage in the streets can be necessary for humanitarian purposes. The UN estimates that direct civilian casualties of the war will be up to half a million people, of which between 10 and 50 per cent will be deaths. How can such carnage and destruction be justified on humanitarian grounds?

With regard to paragraph (f) of the motion, we must continue to fully support the service men and women who are to be a part of this conflict. We hope and pray that the Australians who are there will come home safe and well. I am questioning the need to send them to fight in the first place; I will never support that. I hope our troops, when they return, will not meet the negative response that troops coming back from Vietnam met, and I hope that everyone in this place works for that end. I hope that they will be fully supported through the Department of Veterans' Affairs, that their health needs will be met and, if necessary, that their other needs, such as for retraining, will be adequately met. What we have seen in the past, from this government and previous governments, has been little more than penny pinching. The troops are running huge risks over there, particularly if they do end up actively involved in this conflict. The impact of the previous war is still there in southern Iraq. Following the first Gulf War, large areas of Iraq remain contaminated as a result of the use of depleted uranium weaponry. For those people who have gone back and resettled those areas, that has resulted in huge increases in the rates of a number of cancers and also a very significant increase in birth defects. We must all understand that these troops are running enormous risks, and we must be prepared to fully support them on their return.

I find paragraphs (g) and (h) of this motion particularly difficult. To suggest that we extend our sympathy to people while we bomb the hell out of them—to say that we should have sympathy because it is us who are going to be part of this destruction—I find quite extraordinary. Talking about committing to help them afterwards, obviously they will need an enormous amount of help. But wouldn't it be far better, rather than undoing the damage, if we did not cause it in the first place? It is clear that what the US really wants is regime change in Iraq, and there are a whole lot of other reasons they are giving us for going to war. But regime change is not a justifiable excuse—certainly not if we are still trying to abide by United Nations standards.

Australia should not be a part of this. Indeed today is going to be another of those dates on Australia's calendar. The date 18 March 2003 will go down in history as the day Australia stepped well outside the UN processes when we went to war against a nation that is not an actual threat simply because we wanted to be with the United States and go to war against a potential threat, a possible threat, well aware—and this motion proves it—of the damage that we are going to do to the Iraqi people.

I will conclude by looking at the Labor Party's amendment. It effectively guts this motion and replaces it with something I would much prefer to support and will be supporting. But I would like to go further. The US has used a long list of tactics to try and get other countries onside. It has tried bribery, it has tried cajoling and it has tried threats. Still it does not have enough support to be confident about putting a second motion before the United Nations. It has threatened to remove aid, it has promised to give aid, it has talked about trade—it has used all sorts of carrots and sticks to get people to line up behind it, and they still have not.

Even if the US had been successful in this campaign, I still could not have supported the motion. Basically, the US have polluted international relations by using these tactics to get people onside. But all the bribes and threats have not done it and Australia should not have fallen for it. Given the strength of the world's opposition, we should now be calling our troops home. That really would have shown strength on the part of our Prime Minister, because that was the most difficult decision. The US have been scratching around, like chooks in a chookyard, looking for an excuse for month after month after month. They have failed to get a decent excuse, but we are off to war with them anyway. I stand here today saying that I could never support what this government is doing in sending our troops into this war against Iraq.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to support Senator Hill's motion in support of Australia's commitment to assist the coalition of the willing to remove Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction. What is our aim? Our aim is to disarm Iraq. Why are we doing it? Because it is correct, it is in the best interests of Australia, it is in the best interests of the international community and because the UN is not prepared to act. No-one wants this war, but no-one can continue to tolerate the price of inaction. The future of collective responsibility for international conflict resolution is very uncertain. Why is it uncertain? Substantially, it is because of French opportunism.

speech.para: I was interested in Senator Ferguson's contribution for a number of reasons, but particularly because of his comments about what the UN does well and what it does not do well. I was interested in his comments about Kosovo and East Timor, both of which were given very belated UN support. But, in this problem, we have had 12 years since Saddam Hussein agreed to disarm at the end of the Gulf War, 17 months since September 11 and six months since President Bush went to the UN and insisted that the UN make Saddam Hussein comply with existing UN resolutions. We have also had five months since resolution 1441 which called on Saddam Hussein to disarm in line with original resolution 678 and subsequent resolution 687 after the completion of the Gulf War.

This is not a game. Disarmament is not a `catch me if you can' situation. Saddam Hussein has systematically cheated and retreated—that is the best way of looking at it—over the last 12 years, playing this game where he thinks he can get away with his approach and hide his weapons of mass destruction from an apparently divided world. Disarmament is not about process, it is about substance. Clearly, Saddam Hussein has weapons of mass destruction. The evidence suggests that he needs to answer questions on what he has done with the 6,500 chemical munitions with potential contents of 1,000 tonnes of chemical agent; 8,500 litres of anthrax; 650 kilograms of bacterial growth media, which could be used to make up to 5,000 litres of anthrax; 360 tonnes of bulk chemical agent; 1.5 tonnes of VX and 3,000 tonnes of precursor chemicals. Saddam Hussein admits in the last few days that he has had these weapons. We would like to know what he has done with them. I suggest that he probably still has most of them.

He has used these weapons on his enemies, both internal and external. He has used them on the Kurds, on the Marsh Arabs and against his external enemies, namely, the Iranians. The time for talking is over. The containment imposed by the US, virtually alone, is not a long-term option. It is not the option that was so successful during the Cold War, between the former Soviet Union and the US, where mutually assured destruction meant that both countries virtually contained each other. This is not one of those situations. For the US, with Iraq it is not a long-term option. The time for moral pressure is over, but perhaps if we had had some moral support from France it might have worked. The time to act has arrived, and even now at the eleventh hour, the US has given Saddam Hussein a 48 hour-option to leave and comply with the requirements of his disarmament undertakings.

This is a very tough call for the government. Tough calls are easy to avoid—you just do not make them. But I support John Howard and the government because it is right and courageous and, most importantly—it needs to be put on the record again and again—so does the whole coalition. If you could sum up the mood within the government it would be as both sombre and resolute. None of us are warmongers and none of us have a gratuitous view about our right to take this action in support of the United States and the British—it is because we believe it is right. I want to reassure the Australian people, including a number of people who might wonder about our decision and have legitimate differences of opinion with us, that their government is dedicated and has resolved to make this decision in support of the United States and Britain to disarm Iraq and remove the threat of weapons of mass destruction in Iraq's arsenal.

Judgments will be passed on us at a future time and we do not shy from that. We do not shy from people having an alternative view to the government's. Why do you think we have this unity of purpose? It is because we are doing what is both morally and legally correct. It is because over 12 years of diplomacy Saddam Hussein has ignored the 17 resolutions requiring him to disarm and destroy his acknowledged cache of weapons of mass destruction. This is a challenge for all of us, especially the United States, which has shown great leadership in this new phenomenon of dealing with rogue states who have weapons of mass destruction. The second challenge is dealing with those terrorist organisations and other people or states which pose an asymmetrical threat and may wish to use those weapons and who would be quite capable if they had them of using them totally indiscriminately against nations of the West, particularly against nations like Australia. These people dislike intensely the United States and the West generally. They are arbitrary in their violence and unfortunately must be confronted. Bullies and terrorists are in the same boat. Appeasement just does not work; it has not worked and it will not work.

What is the legal advice for our support for the United States in this compliance action? Firstly, the government is acting on the best advice it has available to it, and this comes from the best range of international lawyers available. I am not quite sure whether the Prime Minister has released that advice but he intends to. The United States and the United Kingdom, I understand, will also release their legal advice. We have other supporters, including some who might come from the other side, such as the former leading ALP apparatchik, Michael Costello, who is quoted in the media as saying that Australia has the legal grounds to act.

But we also believe that, pursuant to existing Security Council resolutions and treaty obligations, our legal position is secure. When I was a student at law school a long time ago I took a pretty jaundiced view of international law, mainly because, in my simple view, the rule of law and the exercise of the rule of law is about laws being enforced and unfortunately international laws are not frequently enforced. You cannot make a valid comparison between the regimented rule of law in countries like Australia and America and international law; it just does not work that way. Before the Gulf War, resolution 678 authorised military measures to eject Iraq from Kuwait to `restore peace and security' and to give effect to `all subsequent resolutions' on Iraq, which included 687, calling for its complete, immediate and unconditional disarmament of its weapons of mass destruction. That is a pretty clear indication to me of what was required.

That is why, in passing, I have to say that the French have been so duplicitous and opportunistic. This is a nation that can never be relied upon. It must be remembered that in order to appease the French the United States negotiated Security Council resolution 1441, which was to further endorse the previous Security Council resolutions which France has thoroughly trashed over the past 12 years and which has delayed US action for months recently. France is not doing this to contain Iraq; France spent the 1990s weakening sanctions through its self-interest in the Middle East. It seems that France sees this as an appropriate opportunity to weaken the United States and build itself a new international relevance. Its decision to pre-emptively announce that it would use its veto fundamentally weakened the containment option which it espoused and continues to espouse. Its final act of treachery was to announce that it would never sanction force against Iraq. Quite bizarrely, it even rejected the British compromise position—the most recent compromise position—before Iraq did. I have to say that perhaps the French have never recovered from the fact that French is no longer the language of diplomacy—

talk.start.para: —Australian wines are better—

—Yes, certainly better than the French wines. It will take a very long time before people start learning French again for that reason. Apart from anything else, the United States has saved France's face on a number of occasions. They were failed colonialists in South-East Asia and in World War I and World War II. This needs to be put on record: they were given a seat on the Security Council after World War II in the fraudulent and embarrassing attempt to give them the status of being part of the victorious allies over Hitler's Germany—nothing could have been further from the truth. We all know that from learning modern history at school. They have always threatened veto against any exercise of force against Iraq. Because the United States has made a decision not to seek the 18th resolution which would allow them to have their veto, they will not have their opportunity to exercise it, but in doing so they have fundamentally weakened the moral and, I dare say, military option to make Saddam Hussein comply with the resolutions of the United Nations.

speech.para: I want to say something of our deployed members of the ADF and to their loved ones who are in Australia. These troops are outstanding. They are well trained; many have seen active service already in East Timor, Afghanistan and other activities in the war against terror; they are very well led and they are very well equipped. They are a credit to this nation and they go with all our support. I am very heartened that we have had expressions of support from our political opponents who do not support their deployment. Any beef people have with the government's decision is to be directed towards us and not our troops. Senator Lees was absolutely correct when she said we would never like to see another occasion of returning troops not having the gracious and appropriate reception that they will have when they return— hopefully with no casualties or very few casualties amongst them. I also hope that they return to this country very soon.

Our aim is to disarm Iraq, but if Saddam Hussein is removed then so be it. His human rights record and political dictatorship have brought havoc to a potentially very wealthy nation. Unlike a lot of other countries of the region, Iraq has the capacity to feed itself in addition to having eight per cent to 10 per cent of the world's known oil deposits. It has the area between the Euphrates and Tigris rivers, which in biblical and mythical times was the Garden of Eden. That area of Iraq is substantially degraded now, but it has the capacity to feed itself. Before the Gulf War in 1990 it did so, and did so well, and in fact exported food.

After the disarmament of Saddam Hussein, Australia must and will—and I am pleased that it is in the motion—play a part in the humanitarian effort to rebuild Iraq. Iraq, of course, is an important market for our wheat, has been for a number of years and has increased in importance over the last few years. Iraq also owes Australian wheat growers a large amount of money—around half a billion dollars—which after the Gulf War it was not able to repay, not because it did not want to but because the oil for food program did not permit Iraq to meet debts that had been accrued prior to the Gulf War on the basis that it may be repaying debts that were inappropriate and may have been to various countries for arms and various other matters. But there is a debt there to the Australian Wheat Board, and hopefully that will be paid in due course.

I am heartened in a geostrategic sense by the US announcement of the so-called road map for the Israel-Palestinian conflict resolution possibility. Let us hope that we shall see a couple of very good strategic outcomes come from the disarming of Saddam Hussein. I am also confident that the strength of our relations with the countries of our region exceeds any differences we might have over Iraq.

The Prime Minister visited our most important regional neighbour, Indonesia, just the other day. He reassured President Megawati that our approach in the Middle East has nothing to do with Islam. We have no quarrel with Islam or Islamic countries. He says— and I believe him—that she accepted his explanation and said that she would make that very clear to her colleagues in the government of Indonesia. We share with them a regional concern in the Asia-Pacific region to avoid the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and to share the common threat that we all have from modern international terrorists that have no particular victims in their sights and are most indiscriminate in the way they exercise their terror.

The performance of Tony Blair is admirable. For him the stakes are very high but he, like our Prime Minister, is doing what he knows is right. I have been very concerned in this debate about the degree of anti-Americanism. You might expect it from the uninformed or the plain crazy like some of our Democrat colleagues, but you do not expect it from the Labor Party. Their criticism of the US is made somewhat hollow when the Blair government has taken the very strong position that it has.

These are difficult days. This has not been a decision taken lightly by the Prime Minister or by the government, but there is a sombre and resolute commitment to the decision made by the government. I share that. I feel very privileged to be part of this debate. I also feel very worried and concerned about our troops serving a long way from home. Like all senators, I hope that they return shortly and that they return safely to their homes having done a job that needs to be done. That is the way that Australian military personnel have consistently exercised their role over the last 100 years and I hope it is the way they will consistently exercise their role into the future. We are represented by very talented and capable ADF personnel. They are doing a job that the government knows needs to be done. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Having listened to Senator Sandy Macdonald in this debate, I acknowledge that this is one area where we will depart from agreement. Senator Sandy Macdonald and I, as members of the defence committee, have agreed on a number of matters over a long period of time. In my own mind I clearly believe that what the government have undertaken is simply a mistake. Senator Sandy Macdonald and others in this debate have mentioned disarmament. Disarmament is important because of what is happening not only in Iraq but elsewhere throughout the world. In this specific case, of course, in which we are dealing with Iraq, it is important to disarm Saddam Hussein and his regime. But it seems to me that the argument has shifted to regime change. If this is about regime change—which now seems to be gathering momentum—then one needs to be very concerned about the path that this debate is proceeding down. One cannot help but admit that the regime that Saddam Hussein overlooks is murderous, barbaric and cruel. No-one is going to get into that debate with anyone on this whole issue. But I am worried, if we go down the path of setting this as a precedent, what other regimes which are equally contemptuous are going to be subjected to exactly the same treatment. And there are many other—
—Not us, I hope.
—No, but there are many other regimes throughout this world, Senator Macdonald, that you and I well know, that are held—

—Senator McGauran, if you want to get up and contribute to the debate, get up later. There are many contemptuous regimes that are held in great disrespect throughout the world. I believe that, as is being portrayed currently by the Americans, this is about regime change. It is not simply about the disarmament of Saddam Hussein and his acolytes in Iraq. How did all of this arise? It arose in the first instance because of terrorism, the spread of terrorism and the war against terrorism and because of weapons of mass destruction. At this stage, any reasonable person would agree that there has been no convincing evidence to link Iraq with either terrorism or weapons of mass destruction.

speech.para: Where pressure has been applied, the regime under Saddam Hussein has now started to bow. One might say that that is taking a hell of a long time, and so it may be. But it does not mean that one has to drop everything and go off to war to achieve the aim of disarmament of this regime. For me, war is always the last resort—it is the very last thing that should be attempted or engaged in—because of the complete difficulty that I have with war in my own conscience. That does not mean that I am a pacifist or that I am anti-war, but it should be the last resort. I do not believe that at this stage it is the last resort. I believe that it suits some timetable and strategy that America has put in place over a period of time.

The other concern I have is that the action that is currently being advocated by the governments of the United States, Britain and, of course, Australia will set a bad example to other world powers who will take this as an endorsement for them to act pre-emptively in their own right where they have international quarrels. I do not want to list where those quarrels are, but you do not need to be Einstein to work out where they are, where the flashpoints are and where the tensions are throughout the world. If the justification on this basis is to go in and change the regime in Iraq, what would be standing in the way of other nations throughout the world doing the same? They see this lead being given through the Americans, British and Australians and say, `If it's good for the goose, it's good for the gander. They can do this, why shouldn't we?' That poses a real cause for concern because, when one thinks about the potential conflicts that exist throughout this world, there are some real, striking flashpoints.

I believe that what we are seeing is an abandonment of the UN as a peace conciliator. Peace is always far preferable to war. Peace is far preferable to conflict. It seems to me that the pressing and urgent need for a second resolution to go before the UN Security Council has been abandoned. The processes at the UN have been abandoned. For me, the difficulty is that the last resort has not yet arrived; one does not need to go the next step yet.

We on the Labor side of politics have been consistent in our approach on this issue since April 2002. However, as I said in a previous speech on this debate, the government have moved backwards and forwards on the issue; they have vacillated. They have got themselves caught out and then tried to redeem themselves, but all the time without being honest with the Australian public that they were committed in the long term to going to war if needs be; in other words, without seeing that the last resort—that is, the resolution by the United Nations of this issue— could take place.

To me, the government's action does not warrant any support at all. They have provided no justification, at this stage, which any reasonable person can accept. I feel sorry, though, for our defence personnel. Our defence personnel merit real support in what is taking place at this time. We on this side of politics wish them a safe return, as do those on the other side. We will also keep in mind the hardship that their families will confront over the period of time that any war might take place. But the fact of life is that we have engaged too soon. We have committed too soon. These problems should not be confronted by the service personnel of our defence forces and by their families.

As Senator Sandy Macdonald said quite correctly, there are a lot of very good men and women who serve in our defence forces. They are well trained, they are loyal, and they are not a rabble such as one would find in some of the less desirable defence forces. They are very forthright, upright human beings and individuals. They too have different views and opinions on this issue but, acting under the command of a democratically elected government, they have gone to do their job and we have a basic and fundamental responsibility to respect them and the role that they will perform. The fact that we do not like the war that they have been engaged in by this government is another issue, but those people deserve our respect and support. If nothing else is said in this debate, it needs to be said over and over again that those people should not be the subject of criticism by anyone throughout this land. If any group is to be the subject of criticism, it is the government, because it is the government who—whilst democratically elected— have taken the decision to commit our forces to the war in Iraq.

The government, along with a number of other governments, were adamant about the second resolution appearing in the United Nations. That of course has not come about and we now see the decision to go in without any real consultation with the Australian government. It was simply a matter of the President of the United States picking up the phone and asking the Prime Minister of Australia to send forces in. How demeaning that is—after no consultation with the Australian government, picking up the phone and saying: `We're ready now. Please send the forces in'! It is a little bit rich.

The other issue that was touched on by Senator Sandy Macdonald—and I have not, because of other commitments, listened to too many other contributions this afternoon—that needs to be taken into consideration in all of this is the issue of our Asian neighbours. Whilst Senator Macdonald referred to the consultation that has taken place with Indonesia, there are far more neighbours in this region than just Indonesia, many of whom follow the Islamic faith, many of whom are not—whilst we are basically a multicultural society in Australia now—basically an Anglo-Celtic society. One wonders what the government have been doing in terms of consultation with our Asian neighbours.

talk.start.para: —Japan, Singapore, the Philippines?

—When I last spoke in this debate, it was very poor indeed. I hear a bit of chirping coming from the other side, but that leads no-one to believe that there has been any real consultation with our neighbours, with whom we have to live. The only consultation that this government have been involved in has been picking up the telephone to talk to Mr Bush.

speech.para: I agree that terrorism must be stopped— there is no argument about that—and that those who sponsor terrorism must be stopped; but, when all the avenues have been thoroughly explored and exhausted, then and only then should force be considered. I do not believe—and this is where I will be at odds with my good friend on the other side Senator Sandy Macdonald—that every avenue has been explored. Whilst Senator Macdonald and others will allude to the 12-year period, one can say that patience is a virtue. I am sure, Senator Macdonald, if we were a bit more patient, with more pressure and appropriate pressure applied from the appropriate sources, then disarmament could be achieved without the need for force and violence.

There are people out there in the community who are pacifists by nature and would say that there should never be force used under any circumstances. I understand that sentiment. Whilst I understand the sentiment, I cannot necessarily subscribe fully to it. As I have said—if one follows logically what I have said—if there is no other avenue open, if it is the last resort that is available, then one must consider it, but consider it in the gravest of moments. I do not believe the Australian government had reached that position. More consideration should have been given to the action of committing our troops to a war with Iraq. Sometimes force will be necessary and at other times it may be necessary, but this is certainly not the time to use force.

I want to briefly comment on the US alliance, because, again, that was referred to by other speakers in this debate. The US alliance is deeply important to Australia—there is no doubt about that—but it does not require Australia to kowtow, on every occasion, to the will of the United States. If one thinks of any mature relationship in life, that relationship does not mean that you jump every time a friend or ally asks you to do things. It would be a sad world indeed if that were the basis of any relationship or friendship. I think the importance of the relationship between America and Australia is that it has been marked by a range of governments over a long period of time, particularly since the Second World War. We have been an integral partner with the United States in many activities over a long period of time. One does not have to be anti-American to say to the United States on this occasion, `You are going too soon. Your actions on this occasion are wrong. Your actions need not be taken at all.' It is not difficult to say that. One would think, if the United States were mature in their attitude towards us then they would accept that view in a reasonable manner.

A mature relationship—not only with the United States but with any government—is one where our view is sought. This did not happen on this occasion in our relationship with the United States. Our view should be sought; it should not be a case of the Australian Prime Minister hanging around the telephone waiting for a call from the President of the United States. At the end of the day, that impresses no-one. This is really about how ordinary, average Australians perceive what is going on. Average Australians do not want war; that is a natural reaction. Average Australians also want fairness and justice to apply in our international relations, and that is not happening. Ordinary, average Australians want to see that international diplomacy, through the likes of the United Nations, is absolutely exhausted before any thought of a last resort to war occurs. We have upheld the principle, over a long period of time, that the role of the United Nations is to provide the base upon which peace can be founded. But, on this occasion, the United Nations has been cast to one side and that is a cause for grave concern.

In conclusion, I want to say that I do feel for the families and for those service men and women. I know that our service men and women will serve our country proudly and I want to make the point once again that they are deserving of our respect. The fact that they are there legally and legitimately should not be challenged. What needs to be constantly challenged, though, are the maverick actions of this government in committing us to a war we should not be involved in.

talk.start.para: —I believe that today is a tragic day for our nation and, like me, many Australians are angry and saddened. I know that there are many hundreds of thousands of Australians who are frustrated by a prime minister who is not paying attention to them, a prime minister whom they perceive as taking orders from or listening to the President of the United States rather than listening to the voices of thousands upon thousands of Australians, those very Australians he was elected to represent. Today, the Prime Minister has committed our country to be an accomplice in an unjustified and immoral war. He has made this commitment against the will of the majority of Australians. Fifteen men and two women have committed Australia to war, sending young Australian men and women potentially to their deaths. On that note—because there are only two women in the cabinet—I am glad to be the second female speaker so far in this debate.

speech.para: This decision to deploy troops to support the US with such alacrity—as we have seen in recent months—has been made without the support of opposition parties in this place, without a UN mandate and in the face of the overwhelming opposition of the Australian people. How dare the Prime Minister claim today that we risk undermining our relationship with the United States by not committing troops to this potential conflict. How dare that be used as an excuse. What about the risks in undermining our relationship with the international community, not to mention those vital multilateral frameworks such as the United Nations?

How dare the Prime Minister in some way interpret this as an attack on our troops. The voices of opposition to this war were loud and clear a long time ago, before troops were predeployed. We do not have a beef with the troops. We have a beef with the decision of the Prime Minister and this government because today we abandoned the processes of the United Nations. Our Prime Minister has subscribed to the rhetoric of the President of the United States, George W. Bush, that if the United Nations does not agree with the United States it is irrelevant. That is not democracy. The United Nations was not intended to be the puppet of the United States. How can we now accept George W. Bush's claim that he wants to bring democracy to the Iraqi people when he is abandoning democracy to bomb them?

We are constantly, almost daily, being told by the President of the United States and by our own Prime Minister that the world has changed and that we live in new and different circumstances. I think that many of us acknowledge, particularly in light of recent terrorist attacks on our nation and on other soils, that we do face different challenges and that we do live in a different environment. Indeed, the terrorist attacks have alerted us to a new and very serious security threat. But in his speech last week the Prime Minister failed to provide any evidence of a link between Iraq and al-Qaeda. Clearly he has no evidence—if he did I am sure that he would have presented it—and, in the absence of any evidence, the Prime Minister continues to use terrorism as a justification for war. The Prime Minister is basing the gravest decision of his prime ministership—of his premiership—on misinformation. War against Iraq will not diminish the threat of terrorism. As we know, at least one senior intelligence analyst—along with many other voices in the community, of course—has said this. The analyst was prepared to sacrifice his job and his career in order to expose this very deception.
In 1945, nations around the world joined together to establish the United Nations. They signed a document outlining their desire, which was:

quote.para: ... to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war, which twice in our lifetime has brought untold sorrow to mankind ...

speech.para: We must not let the threat of terrorism cloud our memories of the past. We must not forget the great tragedies that led to the formation of the United Nations. This generation and all generations must not forget that untold sorrow. We must do all we can to avoid the mistakes of the past.

As I said in the other debate on this issue, war is not about leadership. It does not demonstrate leadership or success. War represents failure, because it gives up on those things that characterise decency, democracy and civilisation: negotiation, rational discussion, persuasion, the use of international goodwill and the offer of help in return for cooperation. These are the characteristics of a civilisation and of a democracy. If the combined brains of the international community cannot avoid war, then we have all failed desperately.

When the international community is calling for peace and for the peaceful disarmament of a dictator, I would have thought that this marks the maturation of a global world. Does this not demonstrate a civility among citizens of the world? Should we not be using those aspects that democracy and civilisation have to offer us—our intelligence in negotiation, compassion, diplomacy and debate—for a peaceful outcome? Instead, some leaders hark back to atavistic notions of la gloire. They continue to perpetuate the notion that war is success and that the outcome of war is success.
