The tragedy of the failure with which we are faced today is that Australia is among a group of nations that has prevented the international community from succeeding in its efforts and endeavours to disarm Iraq peacefully. The so-called coalition abandoned the United Nations when it became clear that its position was not supported by the international community.

To put this in context, for weeks—indeed, for months—our Prime Minister and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Tony Blair, campaigned for a second UN resolution. They implied that resolution 1441 did not authorise military intervention. They stressed the desirability for any military action to occur under the auspices of the United Nations. Our Prime Minister flew all the way to Washington to make this point to the President of the United States. We certainly supported him in making that specific point. At that time I quoted Churchill, who said: `To jaw-jaw is better than to war-war.' Yet today our Prime Minister has told us that there was never really any need for a second resolution. How are the people supposed to believe our Prime Minister when he changes his position at the request of George Bush? When was he being sincere? When was he being open with the Australian people? When it became clear that the Security Council would not support military action at this stage because it believed that Iraq could still be disarmed peacefully, the coalition did not abandon its misconceived plans for war; it abandoned democracy.

I imagine that a number of people in this place are familiar with the story of Sadako Sasaki. It has been widely reported, so they may have read the story or seen it online. Sadako was two when the United States dropped a nuclear bomb on Hiroshima. She fled with her family and, while doing so, was drenched with the radioactive black rain that fell throughout the day. She appeared to be a perfectly normal, healthy girl—apparently, she was the best runner in her sixth grade class—until the age of 12, when she suddenly developed leukaemia. As she lay in hospital Sadako attempted to fold 1,000 paper cranes. She believed that, if she did this, it would heal her. Before her death she said to the cranes, `I will write peace on your wings and you will fly all over the world.' But Sadako did not have the strength to fold 1,000 cranes. She died on 25 October 1955, having folded 964. Her friends made up the 1,000 cranes and placed them in her coffin with her when she was buried. Since that time origami cranes have symbolised peace.

Yesterday, in my home state of South Australia, a beautiful sight graced the steps of our Parliament House. People had gathered there to fold 1,000 paper cranes for peace. Their wish was that we do not go to war. Today our Prime Minister crushed their hopes for peace, but I will ensure that their message gets through to him. I will deliver to the Prime Minister those 1,000 cranes that they have so carefully prepared. I will join with those who are committed to ensuring that Sadako's story is not forgotten, like the children in her school who started the national campaign to ensure she was remembered.

I believe we can actually learn a lot from the children of the world at this time. In the midst of this debate, let us contemplate for a moment what happened in Port Augusta yesterday when young asylum seekers were embraced by fellow schoolchildren on their first day of school. By demonstrating their compassion—by offering strangers life, not death—these children showed the way to their elders. They had the courage to reach across the barriers of culture and race and the stigma that some of their elders have inflicted on asylum seekers. Those Australian kids did our nation proud. They continued Australia's strong tradition of embracing and accepting other cultures. They showed kindness to strangers.

As a South Australian I was proud of them all. I only wish I could see their values and their actions reflected in the actions of this government. To think that war is about to be waged in their names is a disgrace. To think that young people just a little older than these kids will have to fight a war and inflict death and destruction is disgraceful. Our young people are building peace and understanding. Our young people could tell you what the United Nations stands for and how vital it is in our troubled world. Unfortunately, they will now inherit a world in which the United Nations has been undermined by the actions of some vigilante governments.

Tonight I take this opportunity to address two particular groups of Australians. Firstly, like my colleagues, I would like to say to the Australian servicemen and servicewomen who are over in the gulf that our thoughts are with you and your families at this time. I respect your courage and your commitment to this country, and I acknowledge that you are acting on the instructions of your government. Secondly, to the many thousands and thousands of Australians who were aggrieved by the Prime Minister's decision today, my message is: don't give up now. We need to hear your voices more than ever before. We cannot let the Prime Minister dissuade us from standing up for what is right, because I believe that persistence can turn this situation around. After all, it was the community's strong opposition to the Vietnam War that eventually brought that conflict to an end.

While the Prime Minister purports to speak on behalf of the Australian community, it is really important for us to show the international community that he does not speak for all of us. We need to unite with others around the world to make it clear that we do not support this war. We want our people to live peacefully, without the deaths of thousands, maybe millions, on our conscience. We want to face the problems that we have as a nation, not create new ones. We want to write our history. We want to say sorry, not create more and more reasons for being sorry.

Many Australians can only see the faces of Iraqi women and children at this time, afraid of us now instead of Saddam Hussein—Iraqi children who may never celebrate another birthday and who will witness horrors, no doubt, that no child should see. These children should be playing in the parks, not hiding in bomb shelters. The Iraqi community no doubt is a community now gripped by fear, a community facing the military might of the world's superpower for crimes that they have not committed. This is not liberation; this is potentially death. And Australia will be complicit in these horrors, not because we want to but because we have been taken against our will down a dangerous and unjustifiable path.

I ask the Prime Minister to reconsider. We have one last window of opportunity—48 hours to turn around and do what is right. If we do not act now, I think irreversible and unimaginable damage will follow. I ask the Prime Minister to ring the United States President, George Bush, and tell him what the Australian community really thinks about this war. I ask him to withdraw the commitment that he gave without the authority or the mandate of the Australian people or the United Nations. I ask him to bring the troops home. I ask the Prime Minister to listen to his country men and women and act like a statesman, a leader, a visionary, and bring our troops home.

talk.start.para: —I have been listening very carefully to the contributions made by the honourable senators who have spoken before me. I want to summarise what the Labor Party, other apologists and fellow travellers have been saying about Australia's leading role in confronting Saddam Hussein. I will summarise the points and then address them one by one. Basically, they are saying that Iraq and Saddam Hussein do not have weapons of mass destruction; if Saddam had them, he would not use them; a connection between Iraq and al-Qaeda has not been proved; the coalition of the willing is a small and isolated group of nations; we are damaging our relations with our regional neighbours and if we fight we will only make that worse; it is all about the United States getting its hands on Iraqi oil; we have no right to interfere in the internal affairs of another sovereign state; we are lackeys of the United States; our policy on Iraq exposes Australia to a much heightened risk of terrorism; an invasion of Iraq without a new United Nations approval would be illegal; an invasion of Iraq without a new UN approval would be in breach of the statutes of the International Criminal Court; and what we are doing can be, and is being, construed as anti-Islam.

speech.para: That is basically the argument being put in this chamber and the other place and across our community by those who are opposed to the course of action that our government has committed us to. I respectfully submit that these are great untruths being spread around our nation and in this place. It is a fallacious fiction that is being put about. I want to answer, as I have indicated, all of these points and to make some other ancillary but important points.

It is said that Iraq and Saddam do not have weapons of mass destruction. We went into Iraq originally—the United States together with the allies—to liberate Kuwait and we stopped. When we stopped, an agreement was made with Saddam that he would disarm and destroy all his weapons of mass destruction. We know that Saddam has the deadly nerve agent VX. He denied that he had it but only on Saturday he allowed weapons inspectors to destroy some stockpiles. That was a lie; that was a breach of trust that became obvious only last Saturday. We know that he has missiles that break the UN rule imposed on Iraq in 1991 after he was thrown out of Kuwait. He has had a token few destroyed—no-one outside the Iraqi military yet knows where the rest are—despite claims that they have all been destroyed. We know that he has 10,000 litres of anthrax and the capacity to use it as a weapon—and we know that he has the capacity to produce more anthrax. We know that he has gas and nerve gas weapons. We know—as do his Kurdish fellow citizens on whom he has used them—that he is quite capable of using them as a weapon of mass destruction. In fact in 1988, 5,000 Kurds were gassed by Saddam. Those people who say that he does not have weapons of mass destruction and those people who say that he will not use them are clearly very wrong. I submit to them that they should just abandon that particular form of attack on the governments of Australia, Britain and the United States.

There are people who say that a connection between Iraq and al-Qaeda has not been proved. The Prime Minister has argued that to wait for absolute proof in circumstances like this is to risk a Pearl Harbor style surprise attack. President Bush put it succinctly in his address to the American people today. He said that a policy of waiting to retaliate against terrorists who could be armed with weapons of mass destruction was not self-defence; it was suicide. We know, for example, that Iraq supports Palestinian terrorism with money and training and pays the families of suicide bombers up to $25,000 each for every suicide bomber. We know that Osama bin Laden has said that Saddam, whose secular regime he abhors, should be supported in his defiance of the world.

Another argument says that the coalition of the willing is a small and isolated group. Again that is simply not true. It is true that only America, Britain and Australia have committed war-capable military forces to the region. However, the gulf states of Kuwait and Qatar are providing material assistance in terms of bases. Poland has a small number of specialist troops in the region, plus a logistics ship. Hungary is providing training for members of the Iraqi opposition. Turkey now looks set to agree to US troops using its soil to reach northern Iraq. Including Turkey—which has now signed up—Australia and Britain, there are 29 countries in the coalition of the willing. The others are: Albania, Bahrain, Bulgaria, Croatia, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Egypt, Estonia, Hungary, Israel, Italy, Kuwait, Jordan, Latvia, Lithuania, Macedonia, Oman, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Romania, Saudi Arabia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain and the United Arab Emirates. That certainly is a very strong coalition of the willing. I submit that over the next few days the coalition of the willing will grow, not shrink, as a result of the strong leadership shown by America, Britain and Australia. The world knows that Saddam must go. None of the 15 members of the Security Council who voted last November for resolution 1441 believe Saddam is anything other than a dangerous and vile tyrant. None of them believe he has given up his deadly ambitions.

The other line in relation to the coalition of the willing that is being peddled is that we are damaging our relations with our regional neighbours and that, if we fight, we will only make that worse. That is not true—except perhaps for Dr Mahathir in Malaysia. Indonesia's President Megawati particularly understands our position, thanks to the efforts of our Prime Minister, who visited her on the last leg of his recent and very important trip to the United States and Britain. More than most regional leaders, she would understand how the horror of Bali has focused Australian minds. But of course there are other countries who support what the United States and Australia are doing in Iraq—including Japan, Singapore, South Korea and the Philippines.
Debate interrupted.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Allison to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That there be laid on the table, no later than 4 pm on 20 March 2003, the letter dated 2 December 2002 from the Minister for Health and Ageing to the European Commission on the matter of the European Union's decision to phase-out tobacco sponsorship of formula one races in 2003.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Allison to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:
(i) the press coverage for the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne on 8 March and 9 March 2003 again provided tobacco companies with unparalleled advertising opportunities, and
(ii) this will be the eighth year that the race has made an operating loss, and again Victorian taxpayers will underwrite the event;
(b) urges the Federal Government to:
(i) bring forward the removal of the exemption for tobacco advertising at the Grand Prix from October 2006 to January 2005, in line with the recent decision of the European Commission,
(ii) progressively tighten conditions on tobacco advertising up until the removal of the exemption, and
(iii) ban incidental advertising of tobacco products outside the confines of the Grand Prix from 2004; and
(c) urges the Victorian Government to:
(i) investigate alternative venues for the Grand Prix,
(ii) make public the contract signed with the Grand Prix Corporation, and
(iii) reveal the extent to which it subsidised the Grand Prix in 2003.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Stott Despoja to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern, the serious hardship facing coffee producers of the developing world as a result of low coffee prices and, in particular, that:
(i) many coffee farmers are being forced to abandon their livelihoods and sell their land at a loss,
(ii) the financial strain on coffee farming families reduces their capacity to meet their basic needs, including schooling, food and medicines,
(iii) a lack of money in coffee-producing communities, together with overburdened health-care systems, threatens the stability of already vulnerable economies, and
(iv) intensive farming methods adopted, by reason of financial necessity, seriously damage the natural environment;
(b) acknowledges the financial support provided by the Government through AusAID to rural development and other assistance for coffee producing nations; and
(c) requests that the Government provide further political and economic support for:
(i) the International Coffee Organis-ation's Coffee Quality Scheme, which aims to restrict coffee exportation on the basis of quality,
(ii) the destruction of lowest quality coffee stocks, and
(iii) direct poverty alleviation programs targeted at coffee producing communities.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Brandis to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Economics Legislation Committee be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate on Wednesday, 19 March 2003, from 4.30 pm, to take evidence for the committee's inquiry into the Corporations (Fees) Amendment Bill 2002 and 2 related bills.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Payne to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the time for the presentation of reports of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee be extended as follows:
(a) in respect of the 2002-03 additional estimates—to 20 March 2003
(b) annual reports tabled by 31 October 2002—to 15 May 2003
(c) Customs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2002—to 25 March 2003

subdebate.1.para: Senator Ferguson to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD be authorised to hold private meetings otherwise than in accordance with standing order 33(1) during the sitting of the Senate on the following days:
(a) Thursday, 20 March 2003, from 11 am to noon; and
(b) Thursday, 27 March 2003, from 11 am to noon,
in relation to its inquiry on the review of agency security arrangements.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Tierney to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Legislation Committee on annual reports tabled by 31 October 2002 be extended to 26 March 2003.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Allison to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That there be laid on the table by the Minister for Defence, no later than 4 pm on 20 March 2003, all documents commissioned by the Australian Government and its agencies and the United Nations that provide comments on, or formal legal advice regarding, the legality of involvement in a war with Iraq where there is no resolution subsequent to Resolution 1441.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Bartlett to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes the comments of many former leaders and security experts opposing war on Iraq, including former Australian ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Woolcott;

(b) notes that senior British Cabinet Minister Robin Cook resigned on 17 March 2003 from his post as the government's leader in the House of Commons over the United Kingdom government's decision to back military action against Iraq;
(c) notes that the reports of Hans Blix and Mohammad El Baradei on weapons of mass destruction in Iraq made strong recommendations that the weapons inspection process continue;
(d) notes that the resolution tabled in the United Nations by France, Russia and Germany urges the continuation of the inspection regime rather than military action;
(e) notes that Iraq has been successfully contained for 13 years, committing no external acts of aggression; and
(f) opposes the Cabinet's decision to participate in a war against Iraq without a United Nations resolution authorising force.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Nettle to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—

(a) notes that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is being discussed as part of the negotiations that commenced this week on a free trade agreement between Australia and the United States of America;

(b) further notes that United States drug companies are pushing for substantial changes to the PBS that would lift their profits and increase the cost to the public of supplying subsidised prescription medicines to Australians;
(c) affirms that the PBS is a vital component of Australia's public health system; and
(d) calls on the Australian Government to withdraw the PBS from the free trade negotiations.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Nettle to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—

(a) notes that the current fringe benefits tax on employer-provided cars is calculated so that the more you drive the less tax you pay, leading to many unnecessary kilometres being driven in order to avoid tax;
(b) notes that employer-provided car parking is exempt from fringe benefits tax but employer-provided public transport passes and bicycles are not;
(c) condemns the Australian Government for supporting policies that are clearly biased against public transport in favour of cars;
(d) expresses grave concern about the environmental damage resulting from these circumstances;

(e) notes that the Government has already had an opportunity to address this situation by adopting the Ralph report's recommendation, and condemns the Government for failing to act upon that recommendation; and
(f) calls on the Australian Government to amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to encourage the use of more sustainable transport.

talk.start.para: (Senator McLucas)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —On 30 April next, it will have been 28 years since the fall of Saigon. People of my generation remember the Vietnam War mainly from the grainy black-and-white television images we watched as children and teenagers. Later, many of us studied those events as university students, and read about them in books like David Halberstam's The Best and the Brightest and Neil Sheehan's A Bright Shining Lie. The consensus of opinion—not just on the Left but also, I think it is fair to say, among the political middle ground at the time—was that the Vietnam War was a grave error of American policy; that Vietnamese communism was, in truth, merely an expression of Vietnamese nationalism; that the war was a civil war in which the Western powers had no interest.

speech.para: With the passage of the years, that 1970s view of the Vietnam War has come to be more and more discredited. Increasingly, thinking people have come to realize that the people of South Vietnam were betrayed by a weakness of will among the West—a weakness made fatal by the disgrace of Richard Nixon. Had the American government not been immobilized by Watergate in late 1973 and 1974, would North Vietnam have violated the Paris Peace Treaty? Would it have succeeded, had it tried?

In his memoirs published in 1994, General Colin Powell, who was a commander in Vietnam, lamented the policy of American administrations in the 1960s and 1970s— both Democrat and Republican—by which American soldiers were sent into battle with one hand tied behind their back: constrained from finishing their task by weak political leadership, itself intimidated by hysterical and wrong-headed domestic public opinion. Had the West demonstrated the will to prevail in South Vietnam, how different would the history of our region have been? And, in particular, how different would have been the lives of the South Vietnamese people? Perhaps South Vietnam would have developed, under the benevolent influences of democratic government and free enterprise, into another South Korea.

But we know that did not happen. To this day, the people south of the 17th parallel have not known democratic government. They have not known civil liberty. They have not known free enterprise. It is not to the point to say that the government of the Republic of Vietnam was corrupt and illiberal. Perhaps it was. But it was a government from which healthy liberal democratic institutions could have evolved, as they did in South Korea. The communist government of Vietnam is a government from which liberal democratic institutions can never evolve, under which fundamental human rights and freedoms will never be protected.

This evening Senator Ian Macdonald, Senator Payne, Senator Mason, Senator Santoro and I had the privilege of welcoming to Parliament House Mrs Jackie Bong-Wright, the President of the Vietnamese- American Voters Association; Mr Trung Doan, the president of the Vietnamese community in Australia; Dr Phuoc Vo, Chairman of the Vietnamese Physicians of the Free World; Mr Henry Dang, Secretary-General of the Buddhist Federation of Australia; and Miss Dang Lan of Vietnamese Community Radio. I acknowledge their presence in the President's gallery tonight. Mrs Bong-Wright is visiting Australia to raise public awareness of the political persecution of Vietnamese citizens. I am glad also to acknowledge the role of Amnesty International in agitating on behalf of Vietnamese prisoners of conscience. As well, I wish to acknowledge the work of my good friend Dr Cuong Bui, a greatly respected leader of the Vietnamese community in Brisbane and Australia, in advancing this issue.

Tonight, Senator Mason and I will speak about the persecution of adherents of the Buddhist and Catholic faiths by the Vietnamese government. I acknowledge the contribution of Senator Santoro, who also spoke in this place, on 3 March, about other Vietnamese prisoners of conscience.
The cases which I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate are those of two leaders of the Buddhist church in Vietnam, the Most Venerable Thich Huyen Quang and the Most Venerable Thich Quang Do.

Thich Huyen Quang is the leader of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam. The Venerable Quang is currently held under house arrest and in internal exile. He has been in this situation since 1981. Although he is now an 83-year-old man who requires daily medical attention, he is denied the medical care which he needs. The Venerable Quang's current circumstances are the latest episode in a long tale of political persecution, which began two years after the communist conquest of South Vietnam.

And what was his crime? In March 1977, he wrote a letter to the then Prime Minister of Vietnam, Pharn Van Dong, protesting at 85 instances of repression of Vietnamese Buddhists. He did not publicly agitate. He did not stage protest rallies. He wrote a letter! And for this `crime', he was arrested on 9 June 1977, together with five other prominent church leaders, and charged with the crime of `opposition to government policy'. He was, of course, convicted and given a two-year suspended sentence. In October 1981, and again in February 1982, the Venerable Quang was arrested for defending the rights of his church. On the latter occasion, he was placed in internal exile, the civic no-man's-land from which he has never emerged.

A similar fate has befallen the Secretary-General of the Buddhist Church of Vietnam, the Most Venerable Thich Quang Do. He was one of the five other Buddhist leaders arrested with Thich Huyen Quang in February 1982. In Venerable Do's case, he was sentenced to 10 years internal exile after a sham prosecution and a process of interrogation during which he was tortured. In August 1994, Thich Quang Do wrote a 44-page document, directed to the General-Secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party, Do Muoi, outlining the persecution of Buddhists in Vietnam. For that act, he was arrested on 4 January 1995. He was subsequently prosecuted for the `crime' of `sabotaging government policies and damaging the interests of the state'. Apart from the August 1994 document, the particulars of the charge against him included the allegation that he had attempted—presumably, without the sanction of the authorities—to organize an emergency food convoy to flood victims in the Mekong delta. He was sentenced to imprisonment for five years. After his release, Thich Quang Do was periodically harassed, interrogated and detained. In June 2001, he was placed under house arrest, where he is currently detained by a 24-hour police cordon.

Both Thich Huyen Quang and Thich Quang Do have been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. In the former's case, the nomination was signed by two Nobel laureates; in the latter, by some 200 members of parliament from the United States, Canada, Australia, France and Belgium. The persecution of these two distinguished spiritual leaders is symbolic of the persecution of the Buddhist religion by the government of Vietnam. The church was banned in 1981, and the government declared the practice of the Buddhist religion by adherents of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam to be illegal. In the years since, Vietnamese authorities have confiscated the church's possessions and records, invaded its pagodas and holy places—in particular, by the seizure of the Hoi Phuoc Pagoda in December 1994—and systematically harassed its leaders and adherents. Its two principal spiritual leaders, the holy men of whom I have spoken—Thich Huyen Quang and Thich Quang Do—remain under house arrest and in internal exile to this day.

When we read of the events which led to the Vietnam War, we read of the persecution of Vietnamese Buddhists by President Diem's government in the early 1960s. It was a cause of justifiable outrage, and it was used by many on the Left as a moral foundation for criticism of the American policy of support for the Diem regime. But the persecution of the Buddhist religion by the communist government of Vietnam for more than a quarter of a century has barely raised a whisper of complaint in the West. We see yet another example of a phenomenon upon which both I and Senator Mason have commented before: that selective morality, which condemns with abundant vehemence the illiberal acts of governments in open societies, but is blind to the much more serious and systematic abuse of human rights by the closed societies of the communist world.

As we speak, in the imprisoned land of Vietnam, two venerable old holy men are suffering tonight. They have been suffering for a quarter of a century. The Western democracies failed the people of South Vietnam 30 years ago. We cannot avert our eyes from the consequences of that failure today.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak tonight about the subject matter of a petition that I will present to the Senate tomorrow on behalf of 1,600 South Australians in relation to the detention of David Hicks, an Australian citizen, in a United States military facility in Cuba. The petition I will present calls on the Senate to ensure that Hicks's rights are met under the guidelines of the Geneva convention as it applies to prisoners of war, to send a deputation to George W. Bush asking that David Hicks be returned to Australia and to ensure that David Hicks be entitled to an Australian trial if he is charged with any crime. This petition has been signed by over 1,600 South Australians who feel that the government has let down one of its own citizens in relation to the protection of his fundamental human and legal rights.

speech.para: As many senators will know, I come to this chamber with a specific professional interest in the law and in particular in human rights and international law. I view the case of David Hicks with a particular interest— not because I know whether he is innocent or not; in fact, I have no knowledge of this at all. My concern is that his detention without charge in a United States military facility amounts to a breach of the fundamental legal and human rights of an Australian citizen.

South Australian David Hicks is currently being detained in Guantanamo Bay United States military base in Cuba. Hicks was captured by the US military in Afghanistan in November 2001. As I said, he is presently detained in Camp Delta in Guantanamo Bay in Cuba. Also detained there with him is fellow Australian Mamdouh Habib. Both David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib have been detained in that facility without charge for over a year. Let me say first and foremost that David Hicks must be brought to justice. He must be tried and convicted of any crimes he has committed. However, to date David Hicks has not been charged with any crimes. His fate, it appears, is to perpetually rot in a military jail cell. This is a fundamental breach of human rights. Article 9 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states quite clearly:

quote.para: No-one shall be subject to arbitrary arrest, detention or exile ...

speech.para: It also provides in article 10:

quote.para: Everyone is entitled in full equality to a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal in the determination of his rights and obligations and of any criminal charge against him.

speech.para: It is clear that in the case of Hicks no charge has been brought. He has not been brought before any court. He has not had access to a lawyer and he has not had access to consular assistance. He is not permitted visitors except US and at times Australian military and intelligence interrogators. The only Australian contact he has had has been with the Australian Federal Police and ASIO. The only contact between Hicks and Habib and their families in Australia has been through the International Red Cross.

What concerns me is that this government has accepted this and publicly acknowledges that this is acceptable. It appears to accept that it is for the US government to decide what rights Hicks is entitled to. The Labor Party has been pushing for the Australian government to take action in relation to this situation for more than a year. Daryl Melham, the shadow minister for justice, has asked questions of the government and raised the issue in the media; however, the government has defiantly and stubbornly failed to act. This is an issue that goes beyond the individual case in question. It shows the government's inability to balance human rights with the war on terror. All citizens of Australia, even if they are guilty or even if they are terrorists, deserve to have their case heard. All citizens are entitled to the protection of the rule of law.

It is obviously tempting in an age of uncertainty and heightened danger to abandon the principle of procedural fairness and the rule of law, but we cannot allow these to be recklessly sacrificed during such times. We would not accept the denial of legal rights for even the worst alleged offender caught by Australian police. Simply because the United States military made the arrest of Hicks and Habib does not negate the serious failure of justice here. To be a citizen of Australia should mean more than it apparently does to this government. While Australia intervenes to secure the rights of drug smugglers and murderers who are apprehended in other countries, it seems that when one of our own is captured by the United States under suspicion of crime related to the war on terror then the government does not see fit to intervene. One of the fighters for the Taliban captured in Afghanistan was an American citizen. Unlike David Hicks, he received a trial, he plea bargained and has now been sentenced. Unlike the process for treating its own citizens, Australian citizens it seems are forced to wait until the United States decides that it is time for it to take action to bring them to justice.

The United States has declared that it is under no responsibility to comply with the Geneva conventions in regard to the prisoners detained in Cuba. The Geneva conventions would provide Hicks with the right to humane treatment, the right to challenge the lawfulness of his detention, the right to the prompt access and assistance of a lawyer and the right to be informed of the reasons for his detention. The US argument that the Geneva conventions do not apply has been challenged, including by eminent human rights barrister Geoffrey Robertson QC. The Geneva conventions appear to completely contradict the view of the United States. The convention says that it applies to:

quote.para: ... armed conflict which may arise between two or more of the High Contracting Parties, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them.

speech.para: The United States did take part in armed conflict with the former government of Afghanistan and therefore is bound by the Geneva convention. The words `armed conflict' were specifically chosen to encompass military actions, such as the war on terror, which a country could describe as a police action. The United States apparently views the Geneva conventions as not applying to Hicks because he possibly does not belong to a category enumerated for protection. However, the convention makes clear that every individual should enjoy the protection of the Geneva convention until a competent tribunal has determined whether or not a person is part of a protected group.

Due process of law is a principle that both Australians and Americans value and rely on. However, in the case of the detention of David Hicks, we see it come under threat. This government has been complacent—if not oblivious—about the legal rights of an Australian citizen. It has endorsed the practice of the United States and has raised no objection. In Senate estimates in February this year, the Attorney-General's Department acknowledged that the government believes that the welfare of Hicks is a matter solely for the United States military. Government officials said:

quote.para: It is really a question of whether the United States is prepared to let other countries have any role at all. It is their detention facility. We have access to it on the basis that they permit us to, which has been for the purposes of law enforcement and security investigations, and on limited terms. They are the bases on which we have access to those facilities.

speech.para: The detention of Hicks raises some complex issues of international law to which I do not purport to have all the answers. But his detention without charge and inability to access legal advice and consular assistance is a matter that should concern all Australians. It is of concern that the government accepts a situation where Australian citizenship provides only a second-class passport when an individual gets themselves into trouble overseas for an activity that can be related to the war on terror.

Until now it has been thought that there was little public sympathy for David Hicks in the community. But the large number of petitioners named in the petition that I will present to the Senate tomorrow calling for the recognition by this government of Hick's legal rights shows that discontent in the community is growing. The government claims that it is conducting an investigation into the Hicks case, although this has been going on for a year now and it seems, so far, to be a fruitless exercise. It is a disgrace that the first law officer of the Commonwealth, Attorney-General Darryl Williams, would allow and condone such a denial of legal rights to an Australian citizen. Australian citizens suspected of terrorist offences should be charged and dealt with under appropriate judicial processes. I do not know whether David Hicks is guilty or not. If he has committed a crime, he should be charged in an appropriate jurisdiction and given access to legal advice. He should not be left in the legal limbo of Guantanamo Bay. He may well be guilty. The point is that he should at least be offered the opportunities to defend himself that America once insisted should be offered to the worst Nazi war criminals.

talk.start.para: —Fringe benefits tax on employer-provided motor vehicles currently encourages people to drive further and discourages people from using public transport. It is an environmentally harmful tax. The National Transport Secretariat estimates that 40 per cent of cars on the road during peak hour are company cars and that, overall, company car trips constitute 18 percent of total car trips. As an example of how fringe benefits tax encourages further driving, consider Fairfield Council in NSW. Fairfield Council offers its staff cars as a part of their salary package. It requires its staff to travel 25,000 kilometres each year in order to reach a lower tax rate. So Fairfield Council sets out the monthly mileage that a staff member has to travel to reach the annual 25,000 kilometre target. It works out at about 2,000 kilometres a month, or 67 kilometres each and every day, which is the equivalent of travelling from Parliament House to Queanbeyan and back three times a day. If a staff member is having difficulty reaching that amount, usually because they live close to the workplace, they swap their car with someone who lives further away in order to reach the required monthly mileage.

speech.para: Employees seeking to reduce their fringe benefits tax repeat this situation around the country, a situation which is clearly ridiculous. It arose out of an attempt to save smaller companies from having to estimate how much of their company car use was business use and how much was personal use by filling out time-consuming logbooks. The obligation to fill out the logbooks was removed, and it was simply decreed that the more kilometres you travel, obviously, the more you are driving for business and the fringe benefits tax payable should therefore be lower. So, the more you drive, the less tax you pay. If you drive less than 15,000 kilometres, 26 per cent of your travel is considered to be personal and you pay fringe benefits tax on 26 per cent of the value of the car. If you drive between 15,000 and 25,000 kilometres, the amount reduces to 20 per cent—and so on, until we have people who are driving more than 40,000 kilometres paying fringe benefits tax on only seven per cent of the value of the car. As we have seen with Fairfield Council, employees will go to extraordinary lengths to push themselves down into the lower tax bracket on these issues.

So how much tax is the government forgoing because of this formula? The Commonwealth government produces an annual tax expenditures statement that sets out the amount of tax that has been forgone by the government through favourable tax treatments. For the year 2001-02 it is estimated that charging fringe benefits tax on the full value of cars would have raised an additional $910 million in tax.

Employer-provided car parking is also exempt from fringe benefits tax, despite the clear financial benefit that it provides to employees. If public transport tickets or bicycles are offered as fringe benefits, they are taxed at the full fringe benefits tax rate of 48.5 per cent. If you contrast this with the seven to 26 per cent rate applied to cars you will see that it is clearly inequitable. The government is encouraging driving and discouraging cycling or public transport use.

We understand that last year the federal government directed the Australian Greenhouse Office to prepare a cost-benefit analysis of exempting employer-provided public transport from fringe benefits tax. To date, this report has not been released. A similar study was carried out in Canada, and it found that on a community wide basis there would be a net benefit flowing from the reduction in required road maintenance, air pollution and traffic congestion. It is good to see the Labor Party picking up on the Greens' call to have the Greenhouse Office report released. But we need much more than just the release of the report; we need to see this followed through with action. The Greens are calling on the federal government to encourage greater use of public transport by exempting public transport from fringe benefits tax.

In contrast to Australia, other nations use their taxation system to encourage environmentally friendly transport use. The United Kingdom has recently amended the way that its fringe benefits tax applies to cars. The UK previously used the same method that we do, where the more you drive, the less tax you pay. But now fringe benefits tax is calculated on the amount of carbon dioxide that the car emits. The more carbon dioxide emitted, the more tax levied. This is a much more sustainable approach. In the United States, employers can give their employees tax-free public transport vouchers, passes or fares valued at up to $100 each month.

These are far more sensible measures. Any studies completed on fringe benefits tax, company cars and public transport should be released and presented to the parliament so that this environmentally unsustainable tax can be amended. It is time that Australia caught up to world leaders in sustainable transport. The Greens look forward to the support of the Senate tomorrow for our motion calling on the government to amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act to encourage a more sustainable transport use.

talk.start.para: —My memories of the Vietnam War are not strong, but one of my strongest recollections—indeed, nearly a searing memory—is that of Buddhist monks setting themselves alight to protest at the religious persecution by the then South Vietnamese government. Many will remember those events and those pictures. There were many who condemned the South Vietnamese government for its shortcomings, and many who claimed that, somehow, the communist North Vietnamese government would provide greater religious freedom. Oh, the 1960s! Oh, the romanticism! There were those that thought that communist governments would provide for religious freedom and, as always, many individuals fell for the great lie. Perhaps it is time that they opened their eyes.

speech.para: Today, of course, there is religious persecution in Vietnam—religious persecution founded on the incapacity of communist governments to recognise any authority other than their own tired and irrelevant orthodoxy. The biggest single difference between liberal democracies and communism is that the communists believe that any civil rights that individuals may have are a gift of the state— a scrap off the table, thrown to the undeserving masses by the high and mighty government. Liberal democracies, on the other hand, believe those rights are inherent and self-evident. Many in our liberal democratic tradition believe that such rights ultimately come from God.

While freedom of religion is one of mankind's most precious freedoms, it is far from universal. That is why I rise tonight, along with Senator Brandis and Senator Santoro, to voice my strong concern at the ongoing violation of religious freedoms in Vietnam. No-one, except the Vietnamese government, knows how many religious prisoners there are in Vietnam today. Some of these people have been imprisoned, others are under house arrest and still others are subject to restrictions on their movements.

To highlight the wider problem of religious persecution in Vietnam, I intend to place on the record the plight of two very brave men: Father Nguyen Van Ly and Father Phan Van Loi. Both are Catholic priests and both have been persecuted for nothing more than practising and preaching their faith. Father Ly was ordained in 1974 and served as secretary to the late Archbishop Dien. In September 1977, Father Ly was arrested for distributing essays that were critical of the government's religious repression. Father Ly was immediately sent to a labour camp, but was released several months later with instructions prohibiting him from engaging in further religious activities.

Father Ly continued religious teaching and was again arrested in May 1983. He was subsequently sentenced to 10 years imprisonment and four years probation. Following his release in 1992, Father Ly was again banned from conducting religious activities and was placed under police surveillance. Despite continued harassment, he continued, as he saw it, to work for God. In late 2000, Father Ly produced a number of papers detailing the government's violations of religious freedom. He followed that, in early 2001, with written testimony for a hearing by the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom. Then, in May 2001, more than 600 security police stormed Father Ly's parish to arrest him. He was sentenced to 15 years imprisonment and five years house arrest. He is currently being held at Nam Ha prison camp in Nam Ha province, Vietnam.

I now turn to Father Phan Van Loi. The persecution of Father Phan Van Loi began in 1976, when the Vietnamese government refused to permit his ordination as a priest on completion of his seminary studies. It was not until May 1981 that Father Loi was secretly ordained by the then Archbishop Thuan, who was himself living in exile. In September of that year, Father Loi and several colleagues wrote and performed a short play portraying the government's harassment of Father Nguyen Van Ly. For this five-minute performance Father Loi was sentenced to four years in jail. While Father Loi was in jail, the authorities discovered that he had been ordained without government authorisation, and his sentence was extended by a further three years.

Although Father Ly was finally released from prison in October 1988, he has continued to suffer persecution for his religious devotion. He is currently under de facto house arrest, with security police stationed continually outside his residence to monitor anyone coming or leaving his home. At a time when Vietnam seeks to modernise and to embrace the international community we can only hope that the issue of religious freedom will be addressed as a matter of urgency.

Australia is in a unique position to stress the importance of this issue to the government of Vietnam. This year marks the 30th anniversary of diplomatic relations between our two nations. Australia's bilateral relationship with Vietnam is politically, strategically and economically important. Australia is the third largest donor of aid to Vietnam, with a commitment of over $72 million this financial year. Australia is also home to a Vietnamese-born community of close to 200,000 people. I would like to acknowledge in the Senate tonight some of the most distinguished Vietnamese Australians: Mr Trung Doan, President of the Vietnamese Community Association of Australia; Dr Phuoc Vo, Chairman of the Vietnamese Physicians of the Free World; Mr Henry Dang, Secretary General of the Buddhist Federation of Australia; and Miss Dang Lan of Vietnamese community radio. I only wish my old friend, Dr Cuong Bui, could be with us here tonight. I acknowledge their presence in the President's gallery tonight and also note the presence there of a distinguished visitor to Australia, Mrs Jackie Bong-Wright, all the way from Virginia in the United States, who is the president of the Vietnamese-American Voters Association.

I acknowledge that progress has been achieved in this area. May 2002 saw Australia and Vietnam hold an inaugural dialogue on human rights issues. I welcome this initiative and hope that it will facilitate progress in the future. But we must use these strong links to help people like Father Ly and Father Loi, for these are brave men whose strong sense of moral purpose and unbending determination make them unwilling to live their lives on their knees. Their struggle is a constant and necessary reminder to us all that the great work of liberation and liberalism has not ended with the close of the 20th century. Their struggle continues to inspire us and their determination against all the odds is a triumph of the human spirit.
Almost three years ago I spoke in this chamber about another remarkable Vietnamese human rights campaigner, Father Andrew Nguyen Huu Lee. I said then:

quote.para: I have visited Vietnam on several occasions. Everywhere and often I have been stopped by locals. Careful not to be overheard by agents of state security, they have told me of the failed promise and hardship of Vietnam's socialist experiment. For them and for those fortunate enough to escape from Vietnam, the war has continued for the past 25 years. The good news is that democracy and free enterprise are winning. I am looking forward to coming back to a united democratic Vietnam that has rejoined the family of nations. As Jewish people used to say to each other throughout the centuries of their exile and the centuries of their wandering, `Next year, Jerusalem,' so do I say to all my Vietnamese friends `Next year, Saigon.'

speech.para: Three years on, I remain hopeful. Australia's approach to highlighting human rights issues in Vietnam has often been described as quiet diplomacy. In the 30th year of diplomatic relations with Vietnam, maybe it is finally time for all of us to speak rather more loudly.

subdebateinfo.title: World Conference on Doping in Sport

talk.start.para: —On 5 March 2003, at the Copenhagen World Conference on Doping in Sport, 50 countries, including Australia, signed up in support of the adoption of the World Anti-Doping Code. A further 23 countries asserted their support and will sign up to the code in the near future. This was a momentous occasion for all the sporting organisations and their athletes who place their ethics ahead of sporting success and continue the fight against drugs in sport. The challenge ahead is the successful implementation of the code and its subsequent adoption by all sporting organisations in Australia. This can only occur through education of the whole sports community and the establishment of a cohesive model to administer the code. What is needed is an independent national antidoping tribunal to do this job. This is what national sporting organisations want and it is what our athletes want.

speech.para: Support of the World Anti-Doping Code came at a time when Australia faced what for many—particularly cricket fans—was a crisis in sport. The positive testing of cricketer Shane Warne on the eve of the World Cup cricket sparked an unprecedented debate across Australia. In fact, Warnie and his diuretic was probably the only issue which could have pushed the war with Iraq off the front pages of our newspapers at the time, and it did so for a number of days. What resulted was a general recognition that there was a need for greater consistency in the way athletes have their cases heard and their sanctions determined in the event of a positive drug test. I am not saying this because there was a problem with the way the ACB dealt with Warne, but the issue highlighted how much pressure national sporting organisations are placed under when deliberating on such matters with respect to their own employees.

At the moment, each sport has its own policy on hearing cases and applying sanctions. This often leads to inconsistencies—or at least the perception of inconsistencies—in findings and places an enormous amount of pressure on the time and resources of sporting organisations, not to mention the huge public pressure and media frenzy associated with a high-profile athlete having a positive result. So it is time to begin the implementation of the code and use this opportunity for the establishment of an independent national antidoping tribunal, providing the sporting community with a fantastic opportunity to work proactively towards a more coherent and fair approach covering all sporting organisations.

Once again, the importance of the Australian Sports Drug Agency—ASDA—is highlighted. With this independent tribunal comes the heightened role of ASDA, which is a world first and a leader in the fight against drugs in sport. The Australian Sports Drug Agency was established in 1990 by the Labor government and is one of our proudest achievements in sports policy. Today, ASDA is the envy of many other sporting nations. The establishment of ASDA occurred at a time when no other country had yet come up with a solution to the rise in the use of performance enhancing drugs, and its model was subsequently used as a template for drug testing bodies around the world. These bodies emulated the success which ASDA had had against the use of drugs from athletes at all levels, regardless of stature.

ASDA continues to adhere to international best practice in all its antidoping activities. The importance of education and testing programs is more important than ever if we are to maintain our excellent record in keeping sport free of drugs. Unfortunately, ASDA, which operates independently very effectively, is being hampered through a continuing reduction in funding from the government. ASDA funding from this government has been declining since 1998, with forward estimates indicating the proportion of government funding as opposed to fee for service funding will have decreased from 78 per cent in 1998-99 to 67 per cent in 2003-04, effectively forcing ASDA to be increasingly dependent on fee for service funding.

Government funded tests from the period 1989-90 to 2001-02 have decreased from 85 per cent of tests down to only 56 per cent of tests. The rest are covered by user pays. What should be occurring is not a replacement of government funded tests by user pays tests but a trend towards increasing the number of tests conducted. If the government are committed to getting tough on drugs then, Minister Kemp, I am afraid you are going to have to show me the money. The budget is a little too far away, though, so it has to be soon if you are going to preserve your credibility or the credibility of the government in their commitment to being tough on drugs in sport. Given the rhetorical commitment of this government to get tough on drugs in sport, how can we take them seriously when ASDA does not even have a commitment to maintain their current levels of research and testing in the next financial year?

The coalition have again and again emphasised the importance of their tough on drugs stance, which was reiterated at the Our Sporting Future forum held last week in Melbourne, opened by Minister Kemp. I commend the Australian Sports Commission for convening such an excellent professional development opportunity for national sporting organisation officers and sport and recreation departments to come together to discuss a broad range of issues related to all levels of participation and better governance of national sporting organisations. The minister, however, while stressing the importance and growing relevance of grassroots participatory sports seems to have forgotten the damage that the coalition has done to Active Australia—the key government body charged through the Sports Commission with development of grassroots and community sporting links—through a reduction in their budget. Is it any wonder that we are left doubting just how high the fight against drugs is on the coalition's agenda? Nonetheless, the progress made at the World Anti-Doping Agency meeting augurs well for a positive future, so let us hope the coalition do their bit in this regard.

Regretfully, I have to finish on a negative note. Once again I find myself compelled to defend the role and work of ASDA in the face of another inappropriate attack by the deputy chair of the Australian Sports Commission. Alan Jones has previously used his position as a talkback radio host to carve up ASDA in defence of Warne and other athletes. Instead of criticising the work of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, Mr Jones should be defending our world-class drug testing agency. I said at the time of the Warne controversy that as a senior member of the Sports Commission Board and a prominent figure in Australian sport he has a responsibility to allow due process to occur. I am disappointed that the government have chosen not to publicly admonish Mr Jones for his undermining of ASDA. The government must now put their money where their mouth is and support the pursuit of drug-free sport in Australia. The role of ASDA is crucial to the successful implementation of the code, as is the establishment of an independent national antidoping tribunal.

talk.start.para: —I noted with interest and with very strong support the remarks made by my honourable friends Senator Brandis and Senator Mason about Vietnam and Vietnamese links with Australia. Like them, I would like to welcome to the Senate chamber tonight Mrs Jackie Bong-Wright, the President of the Vietnamese American Voters Association; Mr Trung Doan, the President of the Vietnamese Community in Australia; Dr Phuoc Vo, Chairman of the Vietnamese Physicians of the Free World; Mr Henry Dang, Secretary-General of the Buddhist Federation of Australia; and Miss Dang Lan of Vietnamese Community Radio. As honourable senators have heard Senator Brandis say, from the remarks that I made in an adjournment speech earlier this month, I too have a very close interest in the Vietnamese community in Australia. Along with this I have a determination to assist with the process of liberalising life in Vietnam. These aims are entirely consistent with the multicultural emphasis of our society today and, I venture to suggest, consistent with the historical willingness of Australia and Australians to stand up and be counted when the going gets tough, not just in this country but in other countries also.

speech.para: Tonight is a night to focus on national unity. We are at a difficult moment in our history as the events of today and the debate in this chamber this afternoon demonstrate very clearly. As with national unity, that crucial commodity, so with national symbols: tonight is a night to pay homage to the flag. The Australian flag has been our flag for more than a century. It was a unifying force when it first flew on 3 September 1901. It is still a unifying force a century later in a new millennium. For this reason we must always treat it with respect. Sadly, in recent weeks the flag has been the object of vandalism and desecration. However trying the times, whatever the level of provocation, that act is shameful. In my view, burning the flag is a crime, albeit not an offence that is on the Commonwealth statute. At this crucial time in Australia's history I want to speak about our flag and the duty we owe to ourselves and our country to honour it.

One of the finest aspects of a liberal democracy such as the one in which we as Australians are fortunate to live is that we tolerate behaviour that in less liberally inclined states would probably get people locked up or worse. We tolerate opponents of our own form of government being gratuitously—not to say grossly—rude about the person who occupies the proud and historic position of symbolic head of our nation. We tolerate political expression of opposition to a vast range of our national symbols, long and dearly held precepts and ancient customs. We do so because not to do so would undermine the very ethos on which our liberal democracy—the heir to ancient European, principally British, tradition—is based.

But I believe that there are limits to the tolerance that we as a community should afford to expressions of ill will or even plain ignorance. Our flag is precious. It is, with the Crown, the highest symbol of our nation. It is not a political banner. It is not a plaything. It must never be desecrated. It has been suggested elsewhere in another legislature that desecration of the national flag should be made a criminal offence. Specifically this proposal has come forward from your own state, Mr Acting Deputy President Lightfoot. The Western Australian Leader of the Opposition has proposed it.

Under the legislation that is envisaged, a person who burns, damages or otherwise physically mistreats the flag would be guilty of an offence. Destruction of a flag printed on a T-shirt or poster could also fall within the scope of the envisioned legislation. Without canvassing the merits or otherwise of the envisaged Western Australian legislation, I have to say that the principle of protecting the flag from desecration is sound. In particular, the burning of the flag for political protest purposes is completely deplorable. There have, regrettably, been recent incidents in which such action has been taken, and this is completely unacceptable. I believe that those who show disrespect for the symbols of our nation show disrespect for themselves.

I share the view of my honourable friend the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs on that front, as I do on many others. The minister recently told a constituent who had written to complain about flag burning:

quote.para: Freedom of speech does have boundaries and I am sure that most Australians would find it abhorrent to burn our flag.

speech.para: In my view—and in the view I am sure of the overwhelming majority of Australians— the flag should be deeply honoured and flown at every opportunity. On that score I should like the Senate to note that the Lord Mayor of Brisbane—this Labor luminary who is about to run out on his electors a year ahead of being tossed out by them at the 2004 local government elections—does not think that way at all. He thinks it is too much trouble to fly the flag in a special location on a special day. This year, as on previous occasions, Lord Mayor Soorley refused to consider flying the national flag from Brisbane's landmark Story Bridge on Australia Day. He said that he would have had to pay overtime for the bridge crew to put it up and take it down again. He also said that it just was not worth the effort. In the council chamber last month, when the Liberal civic opposition raised the matter of his consistent refusal to scale the heights of visionary policy, he said:

quote.para: Whether we fly the flag on the Story Bridge or not, it's not going to have a transforming effect on the City of Brisbane.

speech.para: The Flags Act 1953 confirmed our century-old national flag. That was an historic act and not simply because it was an act of this parliament to which Her Majesty the Queen personally assented while on Australian soil.

At this troubled time for our nation, with the shadow of war across the land, it is a pleasant interlude of duty to note that on Friday we celebrate Harmony Day—another great initiative of this government to celebrate the rich diversity of our country and general goodwill of Australian citizens of whatever background towards each other and the world. My honourable friend the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs has been very active in promoting both citizenship and multiculturalism. One of the things the minister has most recently done—and it was done under the flag—is to launch the Australian National Dialogue of Christians, Muslims and Jews.

He did this in the context of the certain fact that, while our eyes are focused on international events, it is important to bear in mind that national security begins with domestic harmony. When 23 per cent of us were born overseas—and I am among that number—we do indeed have a pluralistic society with few if any peers. And when you add those with at least one parent who was born overseas, that 23 per cent soars to 43 per cent. That is an astonishing figure. It is all the more astonishing for the fact that together we make up a successful, cohesive and multicultural society that is genuinely the envy of the world. We share common values. We share a language. We share a great love for Australia. We are reminded daily of the essential truth of our lives in a great democracy: that there will forever be more that unites us than will ever push us apart.

One of the things that symbolises the benefits of being Australian is the flag. It flies over this place in a way that quite properly dominates the Canberra skies. And what a magnificent sight that great banner is, atop the huge flagpole over this people's parliament. How could anyone fail to be moved by the sight of it and the inspiration that it brings? Let us always and unfailingly be proud of our flag and honour it.

There is one group of people at home in Queensland who certainly do all of that and more. I refer to and congratulate the Australian National Flag Association of Queensland. For nearly 20 years ANFA has sought to promote appreciation of the history and significance of our chief national symbol— the Australian flag. Tonight I acknowledge in the Senate the efforts of founder Dr Rupert Goodman AM. He is a great Australian, a Rat of Tobruk and a distinguished author, educator and worker for his community. His appointment as a Member of the Order of Australia in the Australia Day honours list in 2001 was well deserved. Unfortunately, Dr Goodman has not been enjoying the best of health recently, but I know that he still takes a very keen interest in matters to do with our flag. Thanks in part to the efforts of Dr Goodman and other dedicated members of the ANFA, this government took the initiative to have 3 September officially proclaimed Australian National Flag Day to commemorate the day in 1901 on which the Australian national flag was first flown.

Further, the Flags Act has been amended so that our current flag cannot be changed without the prior approval of the Australian people. Dr Goodman has been ably assisted by his wife, Win, and other longstanding members of the ANFA, among them Beth Morrison, Ruth Finnigan and Merv Clarke. Current councillors Austin Wilkins, secretary; Ruth Lines, treasurer; and Michael O'Connor, membership officer, have devoted countless hours to the service of the flag association. I should note that Austin Wilkins also is a volunteer worker for several days a week at the Multiple Sclerosis Society. The person who has been the driving force of the ANFA in the Far North Queensland city of Mackay—Len Hansen, another Rat of Tobruk—is stepping down from his position in the branch this year. He deserves congratulations for decades of dedicated service that he has given. I honour all of these people and all others throughout Queensland and, indeed, throughout our nation who sustain the magnificent, historically valuable and nation-binding symbolism that the Australian national flag provides for all Australians.

talk.start.para: —We are currently in the middle of a row in New South Wales over the Greens policy on drugs, which has emerged as one of the most controversial issues of this election. When the Greens vote was incredibly low, no-one took any notice. Now that their support is a little higher, people are putting under the spotlight, under greater scrutiny, the loopy policies of the Greens party. I want to spend a bit of time this evening going through these, particularly the ones relating to drugs. Senator Lundy is grinning on the other side. Do you really support the Greens drug policy, Senator? I would really like to hear you support that, after I have gone through exactly what is involved here.

speech.para: Let us have a look at this. The Greens approach emphasises drug use as a health related rather than law related problem. This diversion from the criminal justice system is advocated when, according to the Greens, `It can justifiably be avoided.' The word `justifiably' here is of interest, and I will be come back to it a bit later. The Greens believe that the regulation of drugs should be moved outside the criminal framework. They believe that most drugs should be more freely available. They believe in allowing a regulated supply of cannabis at appropriate venues. So what do they mean by the terms `justifiably', `regulated' and `appropriate', and who is going to measure the yardstick? I wonder if it is going to be Mr Cohen and Ms Hale, who are the Greens in the New South Wales upper house; or perhaps Senator Nettle and Senator Brown might measure these things in this place.

In the last election, the Greens had a long list of rather loopy policies in addition to their policies on drugs. The release of caged birds was one of these policies. Bird owners would be very concerned about that. The removal of shark nets was another policy. Swimmers would be a little bit worried about that in the Australian summer. Routine disarming of police was another policy, and seems to be an incredibly loopy one. They go on with a whole lot of other loony ideas that are put forward quite seriously by a party in our democracy, and they really deserve the spotlight. We thought that the Democrats were the fairies at the bottom of the garden! They have nothing on the Greens.

I will look briefly at some of their other policies before I go back to the drugs policy in greater detail. The Greens propose social security reform which would allow unemployed people to receive pensions without the need to seek work. They are proposing legislating for shorter working weeks but retaining the existing pay structures. This would create an economic disaster. The Greens say that they are committed to the immediate cessation of the use of helicopters for the general detection of drug crops, because they believe it creates—wait for the reasons—a high level of noise pollution, involves potentially low-altitude manoeuvres and creates damage to agricultural crops. If you get the helicopter low, it will damage the wheat. And it will scare the livestock. It would not have anything to do with their supporters perhaps being growers of these crops? That might be the real motivation.

So we have a party with a number of very unusual ideas. I would like the parents of Australia to think very carefully about the loopy drugs policies. I mentioned a few of the other policies, but let us come back to the drugs policies. The Greens are trying to convince the parents of teenagers in New South Wales and across Australia that the message that it is wrong to do drugs will be heard, when the Greens are advocating selling drugs across the counter. Greens policies equate to not only economic disaster but social disaster.

I see, though, that the ALP in New South Wales seem to be taking these policies seriously by giving preferences. Where are the ethics of the Labor Party? They are giving preferences to this loopy party in Maitland— my area—and in other marginal seats. Both Mr Brogden and Mr Carr have denounced the Greens drug policy which proposes the controlled availability of heroin, marijuana and other drugs, but despite this denunciation it is Mr Carr who is proposing to give preferences to the Greens. John Brogden has come out and is now treating the Greens—on the basis of this drug policy—as the pariahs they really should be. He said that in no way and in no seat will the Liberal Party preference the Greens. We challenge the Labor Party to do the same, but, no, they will not. They are into grubby deals with the Greens and they will get into bed with a party that is absolutely advocating the use of recreational drugs.

This should scare the parents of New South Wales witless. If they get enough votes on Saturday, the Greens will work towards the decriminalisation of drugs, leading to the eventual legalisation of cannabis cultivation, and possession for personal use, while monitoring the effects of this—`monitoring', note—in relation to the health of young people. The word `monitoring' seems a relative term. How exactly do the Greens plan to monitor the effects of drugs—cannabis in particular—on young people? So far, they would be monitoring regulated available use of recreational drugs at appropriate venues. There is no word as yet as to how the Greens plan on being this omnipotent force when it comes to drug control in New South Wales. Make no mistake about it: the Greens, in relation to drugs, have a dangerously irresponsible policy.

Yesterday, the body of a young Newcastle man lay in a morgue after he was found dead in a Sydney hotel. It is believed the man died after the use of the recreational drug called fantasy. Fantasy is one of the drugs the Greens want to make available on the open market, from licensed outlets, to people over the age of 18. I am sure this is a comforting piece of policy for the family of that 35-year-old Newcastle man! If the Greens get the numbers on Saturday, I challenge Senator Brown and Senator Nettle: will you really support the regulation of a drug like fantasy? We are also amazed that the Greens would consider giving free heroin to heroin addicts—another one of their policies. What kind of message would we be sending to our children—that it is okay to take harmful and addictive drugs?

On Monday this week, the findings of a study by a British team of psychologists were revealed, relating the use of ecstasy to long-lasting brain damage that can in turn lead to depression. The psychologists found that people who had tried ecstasy only a few times had depression levels four times higher than those who had taken a range of other drugs but not ecstasy. This study has suggested that even small doses of ecstasy can destroy brain neurones that produce the chemical messenger serotonin, which is linked to mood.

There is now a mass of scientific research available pointing to the correlation between excessive drug use and mental illness. Evidence pointing to regular cannabis smoking by teenagers and its links to depression in young adults should surely mean that this drug should be taken very seriously as a danger to public health. This is not a minor issue in the Greens policy—legalisation of marijuana and its free availability is actually at the core of their policy.

In 2002, a seven-year Australian study of 1,600 teenagers proved that, when young people smoke cannabis, it creates a predisposition towards depression in later life. It was discovered that young women who smoke cannabis are twice as likely as non-smokers to suffer from depression or anxiety if they smoke cannabis on a weekly basis, and eight times more likely if they use it every day. In young men, the trends are similar. Cannabis can trigger more severe mental illness, such as schizophrenia and other psychoses.

We should be delaying and preventing young people's experiences with drugs, not encouraging them by sending out messages that it is okay in a controlled environment. That is exactly what the Greens are saying. Cannabis cannot be perceived as an innocent drug with no long-term effects. It has far-reaching implications for mental health. In an effort to supposedly minimise harm, the Greens drug policy would dramatically increase harm. I challenge the candidates for the Greens in New South Wales, Mr Cohen and Ms Hale—and Senator Brown and Senator Nettle—to try and justify these totally irresponsible policies that will create enormous harm to our society and particularly to our children. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: — This afternoon Senator Hill introduced a motion into the Senate setting out Iraq's serial defiance of United Nations resolutions and setting out Australia's position regarding a coalition to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction. There has been a debate in the chamber on that motion in which many opinions have been expressed, some passionately and some well reasoned. I have little to add to the reasoning in this debate, but, over the period since the United States first drew the world's attention to the danger of leaving Saddam Hussein to continue his possession of weapons of mass destruction, we have heard the expression, both in the community and in this chamber, of various opinions on how this matter should be dealt with. I would like to share a number of observations about these various opinions and comments, particularly with my Labor Senate colleagues. Many of them, unlike their Democrat and Green colleagues, still consider the term `irresponsible' one of insult rather than one of endearment.

speech.para: Over the last few months, we have seen much public expression of opinion, especially the expression of aversion to war against Iraq. We have seen marches, we have read opinion pieces and we have heard talkback radio. In these expressions of opinion we have seen demonstration with various degrees of civility. In my view, the public expression of opinion—especially the aversion to war—is a hallmark of a civilised and democratic society and is something which we should accept. Australia is certainly one of the foremost civilised and democratic societies in the world today.
