The important thing is that the expression and nature of this opinion need to be balanced, rational and considered. I have observed much of this expression of opinion. I have received more than 2,000 emails and letters from various people. Most of them express this aversion to war; that is fine. However, if you read through them you see that some of the bases on which they object to war are really quite questionable. One of the pronounced themes that runs through this is anti-Americanism. Anything that America proposes, they are against. Anything that America is concerned about must be a conspiracy for world domination. This anti-Americanism, unfortunately, seems to have also crept into Labor Party thinking.

For many years in Australia we have enjoyed a bipartisan foreign policy stance, particularly regarding our close relationship with the United States of America, with whom we share many of our values and much of our culture. Yet I can see that the Labor Party has actually been seduced by this unreasoned anti-Americanism. In a lot of the messages I also get the statement made in various forms, `I'm ashamed to be Australian because Australia is following America's example.' I have to say to the people who say this that I am not ashamed of being Australian, because I think that Australia is a great country and that Australian society is a great society. We are a caring and considerate society. We have values which we should be proud of. We treat other people and other nations in the way which we hope they will treat us. That is nothing to be ashamed of.

The other thing I found extremely strange about all these people who are anti-American is that they have adopted as their totemic hero the French President Chirac. This is the gentleman under whose administration the French tested atomic bombs in the Pacific, regardless of world opinion, at Mururoa Atoll, which France actually does not own— they hold it under colonial power. He is the person who gave the order to blow up the Rainbow Warrior. He is the person who recently shook the hand of and welcomed to a state dinner Mr Robert Mugabe, leader of Zimbabwe, when the rest of the world, particularly his European colleagues, hold Mr Mugabe in abhorrence. President Chirac— together with our own Senator Bob Brown— is a hero of the Saddam Hussein protection association. This is something which I find extremely difficult to understand.

When a number of senators spoke earlier, they drew a parallel between this war on terrorism—the proposal to disarm Iraq—and Vietnam. It is a very good parallel. Vietnam is a perfect example of where a democratic society loses resolve and direction, pulls back from the task they should have carried out and gives a country away to dictatorship—to one of the most corrupt governments you could find in the world today. However, I believe that the hysterical demand to leave Saddam Hussein alone draws a more relevant parallel with the appeasement era of the late 1930s and the fate of the League of Nations, from whose ashes the United Nations was built.

The Labor Party is taking a curious position on the question of Iraq. This afternoon, when speaking after Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government, Senator Faulkner, the Leader of the Opposition, proposed amending the motion to, amongst other things, insisting that Iraq be disarmed under the authority of the United Nations. The Labor Party's position is that the war on Iraq is both morally and legally wrong—it would be legally wrong without United Nations sanction and it would be morally wrong as well. However, if the United Nations were to vote for a war on Iraq, it would become legal internationally and the Labor Party would be very happy to go along with it, whether it was morally right or not. This is the curious position that the Labor Party has taken. I ask my Labor Party colleagues to really think, as Australian senators, about whether you could actually describe a war as morally wrong and then, if the United Nations sanctions it, carry through with it. The reality is that Saddam Hussein has defied the United Nations for 12 years. There have been 17 resolutions ordering Saddam Hussein to comply with the United Nations wish that he disarm, yet he has defied them all along. So there is already a perfect legal basis for it. Labor must choose where it stands on this.

One other argument that one runs across all of this is that there is no proven link between Iraq, al-Qaeda and terrorism. Yet the argument is that, if we go to war against Iraq, we will be in danger of terrorist attack. How can that be? If they are not linked, how can we be at risk? Where would the danger come from? The reality is that, if we leave Saddam Hussein alone, it will enable him to pursue his aim of dominating the Middle East. His ambition is to take over the Arabic-speaking part of Iran, to take away Kuwait and, finally, to destroy Israel. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise on the adjournment tonight to speak briefly about the Clarke review of veterans' entitlements, which was released by the government, almost three months late, on 13 February this year. By way of background, this review was an election promise by the government in response to pressure from a wide range of veteran interests who were either dissatisfied with the level of benefits they were receiving or wanting access to new benefits available to others under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

speech.para: The government, it seems, had three options leading up to the last election: firstly, it could agree to some or all of the claims in the same way it always had—that is, by making a political choice based on which group was most worthy; secondly, it could reject all claims out of hand; or, thirdly, it could buy some time by commissioning a review to examine the relative merits of all of the claims, by which time the election would have been passed, veterans would be satisfied with a large consultative process and life would go on as before, relatively unchanged. So the review was commissioned to stall veterans' demands, but with the stricture that there would be no additional expenditure. As veterans immediately recognised, this was an empty process.

Three eminent gentlemen were appointed to consult widely, as they did, and to come up with recommendations. The terms of reference were narrowly written but were broadly interpreted by the government to include anything whatsoever affecting veterans. For 15 months every ministerial letter dumped veterans' problems into Justice Clarke's basket. There were several interest groups which drove this government weakness. First, there was the T&PI Federation which, following a change of leadership, began campaigning for an increase in the special rate as they believed it had fallen behind the economic standard enjoyed by the rest of the community. Next there was a wide range of interests who simply wanted access to the gold card and who believed that their contribution to the defence effort was sufficient to justify their claims. These submissions in fact dominated the 3,000 plus who approached the review seeking additional benefits.

Then there were some who simply wanted their service upgraded, whether it be peacetime or operational service, the goal being access to the VEA. This is stimulated by the act's more beneficial compensation and health care as well as the benefits attached to qualifying service, namely the service pension at age 60 and the gold card. Primary among these groups were those who served in Japan in the British and Commonwealth Occupational Forces, known as BCOF; those ex-service personnel who were present at the sites of the atomic testing program in the early 1950s; veterans from British, Commonwealth and Allied forces resident in Australia; and former members of the Special Air Services.

Many others made submissions too, including war widows, organisations like Legacy on behalf of disabled children of veterans, civilians and ex-prisoners of war who were held in Korea and Europe. Briefly, the case for each of these groups was difficult, as it would have entailed overturning a longstanding policy of many and successive governments. It is probably fair to say that most of the submissions were based on notions of equity and fairness, which have never been features of this jurisdiction, or perceptions of risk and danger, which are indeed comparative, ill defined and inconsistently applied. Hence the view that I put forward very early that the review was nothing but a stalling device, that any government in power for six years should have known the answers and that overall it would be nothing but a cruel hoax. Predictably, this has been the reaction of most of the veteran community who have made their views known to date.

In the broad, reactions to the report's recommendations have been subdued. Most of those who made submissions will be disappointed, which was always the government's expectation. In many areas, the committee endorses the policy status quo. There have, however, been some recommendations for enhanced benefits. BCOF personnel have been recommended for qualifying service on the basis of a fresh and retrospective judgment of their history whereby, after 50 years, service in Japan was deemed to satisfy the test of `warlike' and, hence, qualifying service. Fifty years of government assertion that exposure to radiation or any other risk was minimal have been swept away. Likewise, after 40 years of government denial of risk, with only some new evidence and without a cancer and mortality study being completed, hazardous service under the VEA for ex-service personnel who were at atomic testing sites has been recommended—the first time ever for peacetime service. This is indeed a major precedent.

War widows too have had their arguments recognised. Ex-prisoners of war who were held in Korea succeeded in making their case too, but through the same flawed approach of impossible comparisons of privation. Ex-prisoners of war in Europe during World War II miss out on the $25,000 grant previously made only to ex-POWs who were held in Japan. Finally, there are some who served after World War II who benefit from a retrospective assessment of facts in having their operational service recommended for upgrade to allow the benefits of qualifying service to flow. All other arguments, however, were rejected by the review committee.

First among those rejected were those who wanted the gold card. The committee recommended against the extension of the gold card to any other group and went further, recommending that it be means tested. Effectively, this was an objection to the government's rationale for the most recent extension to those over 70 with qualifying service, regardless of need. Naturally, the government rejected that recommendation, as it was inconsistent with current policy. The most dissatisfied group was the TPIs, who saw their claim for an increase to the special rate unceremoniously dumped. Instead, the committee recommended the complete restructure of T&PI benefits in line with a fresh approach to policy which separates the non-economic aspect of the special rate—that is, compensation for pain and suffering—from the economic aspects, which are essentially income support for being unable to work.

As I have said, the origins of this review were, I am afraid, a stunt. From a policy point of view, there is very little of note, except for the dramatic changes recommended to the structure of the special rate. With respect to the many submissions seeking access to qualifying service under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the report seeks to establish a new framework against which any particular deployment can be assessed, following an in-depth analysis of the judgment of the courts in the Thompson case. The `incurred danger' rule flowing from this case was criticised, and recommendations were made to amend it to make greater provision for perceptions of danger. Notwithstanding the difficulties arising from the Thompson case, it is doubtful that the committee's recommendations will improve things at all—in fact, the criteria may become even more vague. The likelihood is that a fresh flow of reconsiderations will be sought by those previously rejected, in which case the government is unlikely to accept the recommendation.

As I have mentioned in the Senate before, retrospective assessments of past service against new impressions of risk and danger are difficult, as they lead to further perceptions of anomalies. As we can see in this report and in its predecessor by Justice Mohr, such judgements made on the facts against new criteria or changed values are not convincing. In the case of both the Mohr and Clarke reports, it has been said that the standard of qualifying service has been diluted. As referred to by Clarke, the Department of Defence is critically aware of this mess and is now in the final stages of drawing up a new matrix of criteria against which future and contemporary assessments of risk can be made for the purposes of the ministerial declaration of `warlike' and `non-warlike'.

This is long overdue, and it is interesting to note that Defence sees this as its responsibility, going to conditions of service, -rather than one for the Repatriation Commission, which is severely criticised in the Clarke report for its management of qualifying service in the past. With the consideration of numerous peacetime activities claimed to be as dangerous as those required for qualifying service, the committee takes the same approach but is not convincing in its assessment. In fact, it is quite contradictory. Many ex-service people will simply disagree with the distinction drawn in favour of some and against many other peacetime exercises. Again, the government could have predicted this dissension before it started.

The only other policy issue of note, as mentioned, concerns the special rate (Extension of time granted) of compensation for those unable to work due to the nature of their war related injury or illness. I have spoken to the T&PI Federation on this matter and detailed my views in a recent newsletter to the veteran community, so I will not go into detail here. Suffice it to say that, while the new policy formula is very rational and has some attractive features, it simply will not work. Basically, the Clarke committee model sets additional income for TPIs against a new benchmark of 75 per cent of male total average weekly earnings, MTAWE, plus other attractive benefits, but at the cost of their post-65 compensation and pension, which drops dramatically against the existing arrangements. As the new scheme is optional for all existing TPIs over 50, there will few takers. The trade-off, which for a single veteran with qualifying service is a rise of $111 before 65 but a reduction of $295 after 65, is not very attractive, to say the least.

In a nutshell, the proposal is dead and the T&PI Federation have clearly said so. They have now put the government on notice of continuing protest, including a national rally here at Parliament House on June 16. This is to some extent a pity, because there are some attractive features in Clarke's proposal both in policy terms and in the interests of veterans and their families. The model addresses full square the complaint that the special rate does not provide enough for modern families, prevents partners from working and is in fact a poverty trap with few incentives to escape.

Most importantly, the distinction between economic and non-economic compensation leads directly to the other important recommendation that the latter be exempt from the means test at Centrelink. This is a proposal that has been put to the Senate by way of amendments to the Social Security Act on a number of occasions already. We can only hope that the government might at least accept this as good policy, as we have on this side, and agree to the amendments as a matter of priority.

In conclusion, the Clarke report has been a predictable disappointment for veterans and is backfiring on the government, as it deserves to. It was always a cynical exercise. It is difficult to see what the government can do simply because, despite its own stricture about neutral cost, the committee has made numerous recommendations entailing hundreds of millions of dollars. Predictably the government will select a few spending proposals with the maximum of spin and then consign the report to history. If it ignores them again, veterans can confirm their conclusion that on veterans' affairs the Howard government is not fair dinkum.

talk.start.para: —It is quite ironic that I rise on this issue today, which is of course a very sad and dark day for all Australians. As a nation we face a war against Iraq outside the authority of the United Nations Security Council. This, I would suggest, is morally wrong. Mr Howard's war will make Australia less secure from terror rather than more secure. It is with this inconceivable notion in mind that I rise to speak tonight on not only the fear of the consequences of this war but also the certainty that it will overshadow the plight of the families and victims of the Bali bombings that occurred last year on 12 October. The Prime Minister in his efforts to convince Australians that Australia should go to war has taken the opportunity to exploit the tragedy in Bali. Mr Howard said:

quote.para: We lost 88 Australians in Bali because of the wilful act of international terrorism, and we all had to grapple with that.

speech.para: Despite this, he has presented no evidence to link al-Qaeda with Iraq, and the terrorist attacks on America and in Bali have not been in any way linked to Iraq. Yet the Prime Minister persists.

Adelaide magistrate, Mr Brian Deegan, the father of Bali bomb victim Josh Deegan, commented that linking the war against Iraq with the Bali tragedy was cynical and that linking the war against Iraq with the Bali bombing to justify an invasion on Iraq was wrong. Mr Deegan has been actively lobbying the federal government to do more for the victims and co-victims of the Bali bombing. In his efforts to gain compensation for the victims he met with the Hon. Alexander Downer and amongst the topics discussed was compensation for the Bali victims. Apparently this issue fell on deaf ears. It has been asserted that the Hon. Alexander Downer refused to consider compensation.

Currently no compensation scheme exists at the federal level. The Commonwealth says that this is a matter for the states. However, the federal government is failing to encourage a sense of equality for Australian victims between the states and territories. It is evident that the Prime Minister has taken the moral high ground when referring to the victims of the Bali bombings but has failed to take the same moral high ground by providing compensation to these victims and their families. John Howard's moral conundrums do not end there.

The Howard government has provided $10 million to assist United Nation's agencies and the International Committee of the Red Cross to prepare for a humanitarian relief operative in Iraq. The purpose of this money is to provide contingency planning to address possible humanitarian concerns of the Iraqi people. The Howard government is not yielding that its foreign policy is directly putting Australians at risk. Therefore, as an extension of this and to keep with a sense of moral consistency, compensation should be provided federally for Australian victims of terrorist attacks. Compensation should be provided for the victims of the Bali bombings.

In 1985 Australia, along with over 150 other countries, endorsed a United Nations resolution in favour of the Declaration of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime and Abuse of Power. Article 12 states:

quote.para: When compensation is not fully available from the offender or other sources, States should endeavour to provide financial compensation to:
(a) Victims who have sustained significant bodily injury or impairment of physical or mental health as a result of serious crimes;
(b) The family, in particular dependants of persons who have died or become physically or mentally incapacitated as a result of such victimization.

speech.para: Article 13 encourages `the establishment, strengthening and expansion of national funds for compensation to victims'. Since the mid-1980s the states and territories have been left with the task of giving effect to the UN declaration. In 1993 however, Australia's attorneys-general, including the federal Attorney, endorsed a national charter on victims' rights which acknowledges that where `compensation is not available from the offender the victim of crime involving sexual or other personal violence should have recourse to a criminal injuries compensation scheme provided by the state'. It is in this context that `state' means any self-governing group of people, such as a sovereign power like the Commonwealth as well as our states and territories.

The US federal government used its legislative power to force states to compensate their citizens who are injured or killed by a terrorist attack while visiting a foreign country. The US federal government also provided up to 40 per cent of the funds for state based criminal injuries compensation schemes.

In its interim report of 1980 titled Sentencing of federal offenders, the Australian Law Reform Commission commented on the establishment of a federal criminal injuries compensation scheme for victims of Commonwealth offences. Despite this report, the federal government has failed to provide support to the victims of the Bali bombings. Had this recommendation been pursued, we can only speculate what the implications would have been now that the federal government has enacted legislation to punish in Australian courts the perpetrators of murder overseas.

The Bali bombings were disastrous occurrences which affected civilians. The victims of this tragedy suffered horrific injuries—a large percentage have lost both legs and suffered significant burns to their bodies. With these injuries there will be ongoing costs and major medical costs for the rest of the victims' lives. The South Australian government have taken a commendable stance on this front by becoming the first state in Australia to offer compensation to the South Australian victims of the Bali bombings—tragic incidents which occurred outside the state borders. The South Australian Attorney-General's Department has invited South Australian victims of the Bali bombings to claim compensation from the state's victims of crime fund. This followed a decision after the federal government failed to provide compensation to the victims and to the families of the 88 Australians killed in the Bali bombings.

Under the state's Criminal Injuries Compensation Act, payments can range from $1,000 to $50,000. The Criminal Injuries Compensation Act was repealed on 1 January 2003, and the Victims of Crime Act came into operation. This new act has the same provision for ex gratia payments which are payable from the victims of crime fund. At least now, through the benevolence of the South Australian government, those injured in the Bali bombings might be entitled to some recompense for the pain and suffering they have endured, and their immediate families to some recompense for their grief. (Extension of time granted) To track down and even declare war on those who supposedly would terrorise the Australian people will not at the end of the day be of assistance to the victims of terrorism and other victims of crime. As a result of the announcement made today, my prayers go to the Australian troops in the gulf and to the many innocent adults and children living in Iraq.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to speak for 20 minutes in the adjournment debate.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —As a result of the actions of the Prime Minister today, this country now faces grim times, and I am concerned for the families whose loved ones are now at risk. As I have said in this place before, for centuries leaders have committed young men and women to fight for noble causes on their behalf. Leaders have said such wars are inevitable, necessary or just. And sometimes war is all of those things, but not in this case. Unilateral military action by the United States against Iraq is neither necessary nor just. The Prime Minister argues that such action is in Australia's national interest. It is not.

speech.para: Tomorrow I will address the outrage the Howard government has dragged this country into, but tonight I want to go to the actual and potential impact this conflict will have on regional economies in the short to medium term. It is clear that a by-product of the impending war is the current enthusiasm of the Bush administration to further pursue bilateral trade negotiations with Australia. I say `current' because these negotiations are not scheduled for conclusion until the end of next year. I think we will have outlived our political usefulness well before then. The clear linkage between our commitment to a war and these negotiations is a dangerous and explicit connection between Australia's security and trade policies.

talk.start.para: —It is not.

—The government now seeks to deny that linkage, as does Senator Macdonald, but there is evidence there for all to see. Let me use the words of the foreign minister, Mr Downer, in a speech entitled, `The Strategic Importance of a Free Trade Agreement to Australia-United States Relations'. The speech was delivered in Canberra on 29 August last year. Mr Downer said:

quote.para: An FTA would fulfil extensive commercial as well as long term strategic interests for Australia.

speech.para: Those are his words. So keen is President Bush for Mr Howard's unqualified support for a war with Iraq he has even managed to quieten the US beef lobby, if reports in today's press are to be believed. There is little doubt that the US beef lobby is aggressively opposed to any changes to the current quota arrangements. There is even less doubt that opposition from US beef producers is muted due to the impending conflict. It is difficult to see how this silence will last for another 21 months. At best it will last until the end of the conflict.

Senators would recall the question I asked of Senator Hill about what this country might offer up as part of these trade negotiations. Specifically, I asked him about claims by Mr Truss that Australia's quarantine system and our single desk for wheat were not up for grabs. I asked whether he was aware of advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee on 13 February:

quote.para: The government's consistent position in relation to the FTA negotiations with the United States has been that no sector or issue would be excluded from the scope of the FTA negotiations.

speech.para: I asked:

quote.para: Given these completely contradictory statements, who is telling the truth on this matter—the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry?

speech.para: Senator Hill told the Senate that, as he understood the situation:

quote.para: ... no sector has been explicitly excluded. However, we have interests that we would obviously wish to preserve during the negotiations.

speech.para: That means we are going to put our quarantine standards and export marketing arrangements on the table as part of these negotiations and then argue to take them off. The United States now has our quarantine system firmly in its sights. The Bush administration's special trade representative, Mr Robert Zoellick, wrote to the US Senate on 14 November last year. He said:

quote.para: We recognize that an FTA with Australia is of particular interest and concern to the U.S. agriculture community. Making progress on a number of issues of concern to U.S. agriculture will be essential for the successful conclusion of these negotiations.

speech.para: Mr Zoellick specifically identified our quarantine system as a target, again saying:

quote.para: ... several US agriculture interests have raised serious concerns about Australia's use of sanitary and phytosanitary measures as a means of restricting trade.

speech.para: The clear intention of the United States in relation to our quarantine regime is there to be seen. However, the final position of Australia's trade negotiators on this key issue is not. I am concerned, and a number of major rural industries are also concerned, that, while the principle might be preserved, the integrity of the process built around the principle will not.

I told the Senate recently that I had been advised that the government is placing pressure on Biosecurity Australia to release a draft import risk assessment for uncooked chicken meat to fit in with the trade negotiations with the United States. No-one rushed to this chamber to correct me so I think I can fairly assume that my advice was correct. This means that the government is prepared to set deadlines for key import risk assessments based not on a considered and proper scientific process but based on a political imperative. Most of us have an understanding of the threat to our domestic industries from introduced diseases. Australia is free from many of the diseases that afflict our international competitors. Taking shortcuts in an import risk assessment process is a dangerous move that may risk our disease-free status and put at risk billions of dollars in production, hundreds of thousands of rural and regional jobs and a trade advantage once lost never recovered.

As I told the Senate, I understand that the informal discussions between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and industry representatives have raised the outcome of a number of import risk assessment processes. In particular, import risk assessments concerning chicken meat, pig meat and citrus have been identified as matters that may be of interest to the US free trade negotiators. Any attempt to collapse the current process will compromise it. Again, it is clear that, from the government's point of view, a free trade agreement between Australia and the United States is this nation's key trade focus. It is also clear that there is now a confusion of economic and strategic motives and doublespeak from Howard government ministers about these free trade negotiations. This confusion of objectives is creating considerable uncertainty and concern, particularly within rural communities. This uncertainty and concern is, may I say, well placed. It is becoming increasingly likely that, if the government is able to negotiate an agreement, Australian farmers could pay for any gains.

We do not have to look beyond the recently released report by the respected economic consultant ACIL. The report, entitled Free trade agreements: a bridge too far, finds the economic impact of a US free trade agreement on Australian farmers is likely to be negative. This would especially be the case if domestic political considerations in the United States prevent genuine free trade in key industries such as sugar, dairy and meat.

I repeat my earlier point that the pre-conflict US enthusiasm for Australian interests is just that: pre-conflict. The ACIL report says that even modest gains for agriculture will require the US administration to unwind the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act—that is, the farm bill. It further finds that difficulties in negotiating agriculture with the United States, leading to the exclusion of Australia's farmers from any FTA, would damage our credibility about being serious on agricultural free trade—that is, our position in the very important Doha negotiations would be compromised.

The report also cites possible friction with Japan and China, saying a free trade deal could hurt beef and wool exports to those key markets. The Senate should be aware that, for the financial year 2000-01, Australian beef exports to Japan were valued at $1.3 billion, while China bought about $1.3 billion worth of Australian wool from Australian growers in the same year.

The WTO Doha Round negotiations have faded into the background as the Howard government has turned its full attention to the proposed free trade agreement with the United States. So skewed has the Howard government's focus become that the Minister for Trade, Mr Vaile, has signalled that he has just about given up on success through the WTO. According to Mr Vaile:

quote.para: ... we cannot discount the possibility that the WTO round will not deliver a result—in agriculture, or in any other sector for that matter.

speech.para: In Labor's view, the Doha Round should be the focus for the government's efforts. This round will be crucial for Australian exporters, particularly exporters of agricultural commodities. My colleague in the other place Dr Craig Emerson has made it clear that we on this side of the chamber believe Australia should put the World Trade Organisation negotiations first. If the government gives up on Doha, as Mr Vaile suggests it will, Australian farmers will pay the price.

Senators from rural and regional Australia and those with an interest in trade will know that Iraq has been a key market for Australian wheat for many years. It has been a major market for our wheat. Today, the United Nations announced that it had suspended its oil for food program, halting our wheat exports to Iraq. This aid program has been the vehicle through which Australia has been exporting wheat to this country, and the contract is worth around $800 million a year to growers. AWB Ltd now have two shiploads of wheat stranded in the Persian Gulf.

I note a story on the ABC at lunchtime today about increasing problems for exporters seeking to gain access to the Middle East. Ships are facing more precarious waters and massive insurance cost increases. As a consequence, shipping costs have also jumped dramatically. There is now an additional problem because of the introduction of what is called `the US manifest rule'. According to the United States, this rule has been introduced because of an increased threat of terrorism. It has slowed the movement of containers, reduced cash flow and increased costs. It is clear that the American led war has blocked Australian farmers' access to Iraq. I note the optimism of AWB Ltd that the suspension will be short lived, but I am afraid I do not share that optimism. My concern—and it clearly is a concern of AWB Ltd chief executive, Mr Lindberg—is that in a postwar Iraq our share of grain exports will be further cut because of US led aid programs. So far, the Howard government has done nothing to protect Australian farmers from such consequences of this unnecessary conflict.

Comments from the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, Mr Ian Macfarlane, on the Sunday program last weekend are enlightening indeed. It is important to remember that Mr Macfarlane is a former president of the Grains Council of Australia. Before entering politics formally, he was active in agripolitics for many years, and I suspect he knows the grain industry well. Mr MacFarlane told the Sunday program:

quote.para: When we went with the Americans into Vietnam, while they stole our wheat markets in different parts of the world, they did exactly the same thing in the Middle East when we went into conflicts with them there.

speech.para: So there is form for you. That is the view of a senior Howard cabinet minister about our past experiences with the United States at times of conflict. And I fear history will repeat itself when it comes to postwar Iraq.

We are about to be swamped by 24-hour saturation coverage of a war in which we should not be involved. There will be no coverage, I suspect, of key domestic issues, such as the ongoing plight of farmers and rural communities battling against the worst drought in 100 years. The lack of any media coverage does not mean the worst drought in 100 years has gone away. While many areas have enjoyed rain, many others have not, and the prospects for many farm families will deteriorate rapidly without rain by the middle of this year. The confused mix of drought assistance packages announced by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Truss, has actually compounded the anxiety that comes with drought.

The exceptional circumstances program has become a dog's breakfast. We have urban areas in and rural areas out; rainfall deficiency test results varying from a one in 25-year phenomenon to a one in 20-year phenomenon; some farmers subject to full EC criteria, including rainfall deficiency and income; and some with special tests of their own. It is not fair for some farmers to be denied full exceptional circumstances relief for no reason beyond the exercise of the prerogative by Minister Truss on any given day. Nor is it fair that some farmers are discouraged from applying for assistance because they cannot understand the rules. Income support to all those areas picked up by the 9 December drought package is scheduled to end on 9 May, just six weeks away. That package covered large areas of Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia and all of New South Wales. Without a successful application for exceptional circumstances funding, the income support in these areas will be turned off. So much forMr Truss's claim about the government being in it for the long term and the importance of the recovery phase.

It is our view that Australian farmers are going to be hit hard by this conflict. They will either lose access to key markets in the Middle East or face prohibitive costs in accessing those markets in the short term. They will also face problems in the medium term, as the US may give its domestic industries priority in the provision of aid into a postwar Iraq. The government's obsession with negotiating a free trade agreement with the United States is unlikely to deliver any real gains for Australian farmers, and the downgrading of the multilateral Doha Round by Mr Vaile will inevitably compound losses with any losses caused by Australian concessions made under the free trade agreement.

Finally, it is clear that the drought and the recovery from that drought where good rains have been received are off the Howard government's priority list. The announcement at the recent ABARE Outlook Conference of a summit to be held by Mr Truss some time in the future says it all. The Howard government may see the drought as yesterday's issue, but the Labor Party does not. This government has given up on drought and, as with the Howard war, farmers will carry much of the burden.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) In total, and for each region, how many assessments were conducted for access to the Veterans' Home Care (VHC) scheme for each month during the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03 to date.
(2) In total, and for each region, how many applications have been rejected each month.
(3) In total, and for each region, how many accepted veterans and widows have had services: (a) cancelled; and (b) reduced, in each month.
(4) What was the: (a) projected expenditure; and (b) actual expenditure, for the program for each quarter since its inception.
(5) How many clients currently receive: (a) one service; and (b) more than one service under the VHC scheme.
(6) (a) How many clients have transferred from the Home and Community Care (HACC) Program to the VHC scheme; and (b) how many veterans who may be eligible for VHC remain in the HACC program.
(7) (a) How many service providers have had their contracts: (i) suspended, and (ii) terminated; and (b) how many service providers have withdrawn.

(8) What guidelines exist for agencies determining whether house maintenance can be made available under the VHC scheme or whether it ought to be provided only under the Home Maintenance Helpline service.
(9) (a) What are the current funding levels for each region; and (b) what were the funding levels in the 2001-02 financial year.
(10) If there were reductions in funding for the 2002-03 financial year, what were the reasons.
(11) In how many regions have home maintenance and gardening hourly allowances been: (a) reduced; and (b) eliminated in whole or in part.
(12) For the 2002-03 financial year to date, by region, how many applicants have been denied access to VHC and referred to HACC.
(13) For each region: (a) what proportion of: (i) 6-monthly, and (ii) annual, reassessments have been conducted on time; and (b) how many have not been done at all.
(14) For each region, how many clients have had services reduced without a reassessment during the 2002-03 financial year to date.
(15) Have criteria for assessment been altered since the program's inception; if so, how.
(16) How many clients are currently on waiting lists in each region.
(17) (a) How many VHC clients have transferred to HACC; and (b) what financial adjustments between programs have been made.
(18) (a) How many clients in total have transferred from HACC; and (b) what adjustments have been made as a result of VHC funding.

(19) For each quarter since the program's inception, what proportion of services have been for: (a) domestic assistance; (b) personal care; (c) home and garden maintenance; (d) in-home respite; (e) residential respite; and (f) emergency respite.

(20) How many veteran clients of the department received: (a) in-house respite; (b) residential respite; and (c) emergency respite, under the general Commonwealth respite programs for each quarter in the 2001-02 financial year and the 2002-03 financial year to date, as opposed to receiving those services funded under the VHC scheme.
(21) Has an interim report on the evaluation of VHC been received; if so: (a) what are its findings and recommendations; and (b) can a copy be provided.
(22) For each region, in how many instances have agencies declined to: (a) make assessments; and (b) provide services, for whatever reason, including remoteness.
(23) How many veteran clients of the department received personal care services from programs other than VHC in each quarter of the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03 to date.

(24) How many veteran clients of the department availed themselves of services under the Home Maintenance Helpline service for each quarter of the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03 to date.

(25) Given the original estimate of savings in the health program as a result of this program, what is the estimated reduction of those savings flowing from reductions of services below those assessed.

(26) (a) What were the average hours approved for each service in the VHC scheme as at: (i) 31 December 2001, (ii) 30 June 2002, and (iii) 30 September 2002; and (b) how many clients were in receipt of each service at those times.
(27) (a) What is the current fee paid to each agency for each assessment made; and (b) what other funding is provided to agencies for administrative overheads.

(28) (a) What is the current scale of charges for each of the services provided under the VHC scheme by providers managed by agencies; and (b) what is the equivalent scale for other programs such as respite and HACC.
(29) As at 30 September 2002, how many agencies have overspent pro rata on their allocated budget.
(30) How many agencies have reduced staff as a result of the reduced allocations.

quote.para: (3) (a) Nil.

(b) Some veterans in all regions have had services reduced in line with reassessment of need. Some reductions were part of a reassessment process, resulting in new or different services. Some relate to planned reductions or cessation of hours in post-discharge cases and others resulted when veterans moved to other regions and had different needs in their new domicile.
(4) (a) and (b) The projected expenditure and actual expenditure for the program for each quarter since January 2001 are as follows:

(5) (a) and (b) The number of veterans currently receiving one service is 30,766 and more than one service, 10,537. This information relates to actual services provided and is based on service provision data for quarter 4 of 2001/2002. As there is a lag between when data for service provision is generally available, it is only reliable some months after the services were provided, hence quarter 4 of 2001/2002.
(6) (a) Since January 2001 to 31 October 2002, 17,547 veterans have transferred from the Home and Community Care (HACC) program to Veterans' Home Care (VHC) program.

(b) This is unknown because the HACC Minimum Data Set classifies a veteran as anyone with a DVA pension. It does not identify those veterans with Gold or White Cards who may be eligible to transfer to VHC.
(7) (a) (i) and (ii) Nil, since the VHC program commenced in January 2001.
(b) Of nearly 300 service providers about 10 have left the program of their own volition, for example, when their organisation has been taken over by another provider.

(8) Home and garden maintenance under VHC focuses on minimising environmental health and safety hazards that may impact on the veteran and includes tasks that do not require the skills of a qualified trades person, such as replacing light bulbs, one-off garden clean ups etc. Home and garden maintenance is limited to 15 hours of service per year.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs Veterans' Home Maintenance Helpline is a totally separate program to VHC that provides property maintenance advice and referral to trades people where necessary. It can also arrange home inspections to identify current or future maintenance problems. The Helpline advice is free but users are required to pay for the work done by tradespeople, including call out costs. There may be instances where veterans are referred to the Helpline but such referrals are not routinely recorded.
(9) (a) and (b) The VHC regional budgets for 2002/2003 and the regional expenditure for VHC services provided in 2001/2002 are provided in the below tables.

* This figure relates to expenditure for VHC services provided in 2001/2002. It does not include expenditure for services provided under arrangements with State Governments or expenditure for assessments.

(10) There has been a reduction of $800,000 in line with forward estimates as published in Portfolio Budget Statements. However, an additional $6m has been allocated to providers, reflecting the fact that some VHC services are, in effect, elements of respite care and community nursing and should be funded from these areas.

(11) (a) and (b) There have been no reductions in relation to any particular service type. Agencies undertake assessments based on assessed need and allocate hours for personal care, domestic assistance, home and garden maintenance and respite care based on that assessment. There are no fixed hourly allocations, however respite hours are capped at 196 hours per financial year by the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and a limit of 15 hours per year has been set for home and garden maintenance through the VHC guidelines.
(12) No veteran has been denied access to services. Every eligible veteran is given an assessment.
*Care needs exceeded what can be provided for under VHC and therefore directed to HACC, CACP, Linkages etc.
**High need clients already in case management programs.
*Referred to Home Assist Secure for non essential / safety services.
*9 comes from one agency that covers both North and South West Metro.
*Self referred to HACC

* It should be noted that these figures have been based on the reviews being completed within the strict 6 or 12 month timeframe. Therefore, it does not take account of reviews undertaken within a week or two of that date because of particular agency practice such as workflow management, the number of new assessments taking place etc.

(14) Nil. Agencies are instructed to review each veteran at intervals of 6 to 9 months or where the veteran's circumstances change, or at the veteran's request. A new approval must be recorded on the VHC system if any additional or different services are required.

(16) Data on this is not available. There are a number of veterans who are waiting for assessment and the timing of the assessment is dependent on the workload of the agency at the time of the veteran's request. There are a number of veterans who have been assessed and are awaiting commencement of services. There are also those veterans awaiting delivery of approved services that will be provided on an infrequent basis, such as home and garden maintenance or non-urgent home and garden maintenance and domestic assistance. These veterans are not considered to be on waiting lists. Nor are they inclusive of veterans waiting for reviews.
Where there is no assessed need for services veterans are encouraged to contact the assessment agency if their circumstances change and they require services.

(17) (a) If any, this would be a very small number and it is not common practice. However, there appears to be confusion amongst some agencies regarding the process of referring veterans to HACC funded programs, for example, veterans transferred to Community Aged Care Packages (CACP) that are often administered by a HACC agency. This does not constitute referral back to HACC program proper. Veterans currently on Linkages or Community Options Packages are in a similar position.
(b) Nil. However, veterans on these types of packages may be in receipt of other DVA assistance, eg RAP or community nursing.
(18) (a) 17,547 veterans have transferred from HACC.
(b) Nil.

quote.para: (20) (a), (b) and (c) The Department of Health and Ageing have advised that:

· currently data on the number of veteran and war widow clients receiving (a) in-house or (c) emergency respite are not available. In future years, for clients referred from Commonwealth Carer Respite Centres, this information will be available through the National Respite for Carers Program Minimum Data Set and Reporting System, which is in the early implementation stage;

· in reference to (b) residential respite, the average number (per quarter) of residential respite residents who have been subsidised for the five quarters from 1 July 2001 to 30 September 2002 by the Department of Veterans' Affairs was 456; and

· for 2001-02, within the Home and Community Care (HACC) Program, some 554 “instances of service” were provided as respite care for Veterans' Affairs pensioners. The HACC data collection does not collect data on emergency respite.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs has advised that the number of veterans and war widows who received in-home or emergency respite through VHC in each quarter of 2001-02, and 2002-03 financial year to date, are as follows:

*Note: This data is correct as of 25 November 2002. Since numbers of veterans receiving service is derived from the claims submitted by the service providers, the data is only as up to date as the claims.

(21) (a) and (b) The University of New South Wales is evaluating the VHC program for DVA. To date, a number of interim and work in progress reports have been provided to the Department, the most recent in August 2002. The key finding of this report are:
· Overall, 96% of the veterans rated VHC as either “very important” (82%) or “quite important” (14%) in enabling them to live independently.
· The poorer the veteran's health, the more important VHC is in the veteran being able to live independently.
· There is a small (but statistically significant) lowering of the mortality rate for those receiving VHC.
· The analysis indicates that these increases in health-related expenditure occur prior to joining VHC, and start to trend downwards post VHC.
- However, these results are preliminary only. More data and more analysis are needed, as it is still too early in the program to draw any firm conclusions.
A copy of the August 2002 report will be provided separately to the honourable senator.
(22) (a) and (b) No one has been denied an assessment. As agencies are paid on the basis of each assessment undertaken, it is unlikely that they would deny themselves revenue in this manner.

(23) (a) and (b) The community nursing program may provide personal care as part of technical and general nursing care services. However, veterans whose primary support is personal care are grouped under items reimbursed as activities of daily living. It should be noted that data relates to claims made for services provided in that quarter. Providers have six months to lodge a claim and, as such, data in 2002-03 Q1 is partially incomplete.

(25) The anticipated savings in the health program resulting from VHC will not flow from the VHC program itself, but from other DVA health programs. These savings are not being eroded by the perceived cuts to current VHC service levels. The redistribution of funding to regional budgets will allow services to be provided to a greater number of veterans in this program which is targeted at those with low level needs.

quote.para: (27) (a) and (b) VHC has a standard fee of $100 per annum which is paid to agencies for assessment and coordination services in relation to each veteran. Some agencies received higher fees in relation or remoteness or other issues. The contracted fee is inclusive of administrative overheads.

entry.para: $25 per hour$15 per hour No copayment applies

quote.para: (28) (b) The Department of Health and Ageing have advised that:
· the standard daily respite fee in Commonwealth approved aged care homes is up to $25.08 (as at September 2002);

· under the National Respite for Carers Program, funds are provided to organisations to assist them to purchase carer respite services (directly or indirectly) from HACC service providers or HACC associated providers. User charges are therefore determined by each provider; and

· a comparison of the fees paid by clients receiving HACC respite services and clients under the VHC program cannot be provided. Under the HACC Amending Agreement, State and Territory Governments have responsibility for the day-to-day administration of the program, including the collection of data relating to fees.
(29) Because of the delay in providers submitting claims for payment, accurate figures for expenditure for the first quarter of this financial year cannot be provided at this stage.

(30) Any reductions to funding available for service provision would not relate to payments to agencies for veterans' assessments, hence such reductions would not result in agency staffing reductions.

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Patentability of Genetic Material and Technologies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 884)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has the department participated in an inter-departmental committee that drafted a scoping paper on the patentability of genetic material and genetic technologies; if so, can a copy of the scoping paper be provided; if not, why not.
(2) Which departments were represented on the inter-departmental committee.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, the Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) did participate in an inter-departmental committee of which the purpose was to draft terms of reference for the patentability of genetic material and genetic technologies. A part of that process included the drafting of a scoping paper.
A copy of the scoping paper cannot be provided. The scoping paper was only ever a draft and was not agreed and finalised by inter-departmental committee member agencies.
(2) The following were represented on the Inter-Departmental Committee:
Attorney-General's Department;
Biotechnology Australia;
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation;
Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry;
Department of Education, Science and Training;
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade;
Department of Health and Ageing;
Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources;
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet;
Department of the Environment and Heritage; and
IP Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Was a review of interest rate subsidies as a form of farm business assistance scheduled to commence in January 2002.
(2) Did the Minister delay the commencement of the review, if so, why was the review delayed.
(3) Has the review commenced: if so: (a) when did it commence; (b) who is conducting the review; (c) what will be its terms of reference; and (d) when is it expected to be completed.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The review of interest rate subsidies was scheduled to be conducted during 2001/02.

(2) The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has requested that the Interest Rate Subsidy (IRS) Review commence after the Exceptional Circumstances (EC) Reform process changes are made. The commencement of the interest rate subsidy review has been hindered due to the delays in securing the State and Territories agreement to the EC Reforms and uncertainty of their ongoing contribution toward EC business support.
(3) See answer to question 2.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service: Export Documentation Program Review
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 940)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has the Export Documentation Program been reviewed: if so when did the review commence and conclude.
(2) Who conducted the review.
(3) What recommendations does the review make.
(4) Can a copy of the review be provided: if not why not.
(5) Has the Minister adopted the recommendations: if not why not.
(6) (a) What additional uptake of the program is expected in the 2002-03 financial year; and (b) can details be provided, by industry sector.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) commissioned a review of this Program, for its own internal management purposes. The Review commenced on 10 December 2001 and concluded on 15 March 2002.
(2) MinterEllison Consulting (Canberra) Pty Ltd.

(3) The Review has 9 recommendations, which AQIS has either addressed or is currently addressing. Refer to the attached copy of “Report to Department of Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry Australia Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service for Post Implementation Review of EXDOC Extension of Non-meat 22 March 2002”.
(4) A copy of the above Report is available from the Senate Table Office.
(5) The Review was commissioned by AQIS as input into its internal management operations. AQIS has accepted the recommendations and is addressing them. The Minister has been briefed.

(6) AQIS, with the assistance of industry is pursuing full uptake by all exporters, with 100% uptake expected for dairy and fish exports; and progressive movement towards full adoption for horticulture and grain exports. The current uptake, by commodity group, is as follows:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 4 December 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the Minister's statement, `Sheep exports from Portland to resume if tough new conditions are met', issued on 31 October 2002:
(1) What recommendations did the Independent Reference Group make to the Minister.
(2) Have any of these recommendations failed to be incorporated into the new action plan for live animal exports.
(3) (a) Who comprised the joint industry/Government working group that developed the action plan; and (b) when was this working group formed.
(4) On how many occasions has this working group met.
(5) Has the working group been disbanded; if so, when did this occur; if not, what tasks is the working group now undertaking.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Independence Reference Group (IRG) report and the action plan were tabled on 12 December 2002. The IRG is of the view that the action plan is broadly consistent with the thrust of most of the recommendations in the original IRG report of February 2000 and also with the recommendations in the Report arising from the 2-3 October 2002 IRG meeting.

(3) (a) The joint industry/Government working group comprised representatives of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS), Australian Livestock Exporters Council (ALEC), Livecorp, Meat and Livestock Australia (MLA) and Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA). The names of individual representatives are listed in the action plan tabled on 12 December 2002. (b) The Minister agreed to form the working group on 14 October 2002.
(4) The working group met once, on 16-18 October 2002.

(5) The working group has completed its work and there are no plans for it to reconvene. An Industry Consultative Committee has been formed as recommended by the IRG. This Committee includes many of the members of the working group and also includes representation from the peak animal welfare consultative body and livestock producers. The first meeting of the Committee was on 19 December 2002 and it is envisaged that meetings will take place every two months whilst the recommendations of the IRG and working group are implemented.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 4 December 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 725 (Senate Hansard, 2 December 2002, p.6612) concerning live animal exports:

(1) Did the Chief Veterinary Officer recommend to the Secretary of the department that the livestock vessel Al Kuwait should be permitted to depart from Portland; if so, did the Chief Veterinary Officer recommend any conditions that were not subsequently applied to its departure; if not, why did the secretary disregard the recommendation of the Chief Veterinary Officer and revoke a direction that an export permit not be granted to the exporter.
(2) (a) How many sheep, if any, died onboard the Al Kuwait during the voyage that commenced in Portland on 29 September 2002; and (b) what was the principle identified cause of death.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, and all recommended conditions were applied.
(2) (a) 857 deaths out of a total consignment of 99,469 (0.89%). (b) Enteritis.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 2002:

quote.para: With reference to paragraph 6.22 in the Australian National Audit Office report no. 6 into fraud control in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, tabled in the Senate on 29 August 2002 and the estimate in the department's Fraud Control Plan that up to $15 million may be at risk to fraud in the medical accounts treatment processing system:
(1) (a) What specific items of medical services were included in that estimate; and (b) what was the estimate against each item.

(2) For each of the past 3 years, what amounts have been recovered, by state, from: (a) providers of medical services, by type; (b) providers of community nursing; (c) providers of other home care and domestic services; and (d) other providers of health-related services.
(3) What resources are specifically allocated in each state office to fraud control and management in the health area.
(4) For each state in the past year, how many health providers have been interviewed or counselled with respect to claims lodged for payment.
(5) In each of the past 5 years, how many providers of health services have been prosecuted for fraudulent claims.
(6) In each of the past 5 years, how many veterans in relation to fraudulent travel claims have been: (a) investigated; and (b) prosecuted.
(7) In each of the past 5 years how many transport contractors in relation to fraudulent claims have been: (a) investigated; and (b) prosecuted.
(8) With reference to state offices, what instructions exist for the implementation of the fraud control plan.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) and (b) The estimate of $15 million was a global estimate only. There is no break-up of that estimate against individual classes of providers and/or medical items. This estimated level of possible fraud against the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) was set by reference to the 1997 Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) audit report, titled `Medifraud and Inappropriate Practice', which was published after a review of the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme payments. The estimate was based on the Source Based Audits conducted on payments made by the HIC.
ANAO acknowledged that the estimate was approximate because of the small size of the sample used to derive the estimates.

DVA's Fraud Control Plan adopted the ANAO estimate as its indicator of the level of fraud because of the similarity of activities between the agencies, and as it is the only estimate currently available in this area of activity.
(2) (a), (b), (c) and (d) Recoveries by State and Provider Type for 1999/2000 and 2001/2002 are set out below. No recoveries occurred in 2000/2001.

(3) New South Wales currently has seven staff (6.5 FTE) assigned to performance monitoring and evaluation, while Queensland (1.5 FTE) and West Australia both have two staff assigned to monitoring and review activities. Neither Tasmania nor South Australia has staff dedicated to this role and both are covered by National Office activity and supported by the National Fraud Control Unit that assists in investigation work.
The Victorian State Office does not have staff dedicated to monitoring and review activities, but is assisted by the National Fraud Control Unit which is located in the same building in Melbourne.
(4) The number of providers interviewed or counselled from 1 January to 15 December 2002 is as follows:

entry.para: Number of Providers interviewed or counselled

quote.para: (5) The number of providers prosecuted in the past five years, 1 July 1997 to 30 June 2002, is as follows:
(6) (a) and (b) The number of veterans investigated and prosecuted in relation to fraudulent travel claims are as follows:
(7) (a) and (b) The number of transport contractors investigated and prosecuted in relation to fraudulent claims are as follows:

(8) Under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997, each agency is required to prepare a fraud control plan. Until May 2002, the agencies were required under the then `Fraud Control Policy of the Commonwealth' to obtain the endorsement of their draft plans from the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board.

In May 2002 the `Commonwealth Fraud Control Guidelines' were introduced and made the external approval of fraud control plans no longer necessary, although agencies are still required to have a current plan in place. The plans must contain a fraud risk assessment and a fraud control action plan which addresses all activities which the agencies consider to present a high risk after appropriate controls have been established.

The Fraud Control Plan is accessible to all staff on the DVA intranet. Its purpose and location is being brought to the attention of all staff during the fraud and ethics training that the National Fraud Control Unit is presenting at all State offices and National Office in late 2002 and early 2003. Over 970 staff in five State Offices have attended this training in 2002.
The Fraud Control Plan incorporates a description of the policies, procedures and practices which have been in place for many years, such as IT access control procedures.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 December 2002:

quote.para: If the Australian Government's position is just and legal, why has the Australian Government repudiated the International Court of Justice as an arbitrator in determining sea and seabed boundaries between Australia and East Timor.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Government believes that maritime boundaries should be settled by negotiation, not litigation - as has been the case for all of Australia's existing maritime boundaries with several nearby States. A negotiated outcome by definition is acceptable to both sides, whereas litigation can lead to a result satisfactory to neither.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 12 December 2002:

quote.para: (1) Can the following information be provided in the same format as Table 1 on page 7 of the discussion paper `Setting Firm Foundations', concerning university finance, list the distribution of HECS debts: The number of HECS debtors in each band of debt, arranged by the year in which they most recently incurred a HECS debt.

(2) (a) What is the basis of the projections contained in Table 2.6 on page 82 of the Higher Education Report for the 2002-04 Triennium; (b) what are the projections through to 2010; and (c) what proportion of each category in Table 2.6 is attributable to: (i) past students; (ii) existing students; and (iii) future students.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The answer to this question is provided at Attachment A.

The honourable member should note that, given that the data required to answer this question has been tabulated according to the most recent year in which a HECS debt was incurred, the figures for 2002 are considerably higher than for previous years. This is because the 2002 figures include both continuing students (who may be still undertaking their second, third or fourth years of study) and commencing students. Other years only include students who incurred no further HECS debt after that year, that is they either completed their studies or withdrew from their course and have not undertaken any further HECS-liable study since that time. The 2002 figures also include new debts incurred through the Postgraduate Education Loans Scheme (PELS) which are collected through the taxation system as accumulated HECS debts.

(2) The HECS forward estimates produced by the Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST) form the basis of the table referred to in part (2) of the honourable Senator's question. The data inputs that drive the forward estimates are as follows:
· HECS band rates; HECS non-differential rate;
· HECS-liable student load;
· HECS liabilities amounts - including up-front payments, payments to universities for student loans and the 25 per cent discount for up-front payment;
· proportion of HECS students by HECS band and payment option;
· Bridging for Overseas Trained Professionals Loans Scheme (BOTPLS) loan amounts;
· Postgraduate Education Loan Scheme (PELS) loan amounts;
· Open Learning Deferred Payments Scheme (OLDPS) loan amounts; OLDPS basic charge; number of OLDPS units;
· voluntary and compulsory (PAYG) repayments of loans;
· 15 percent discount on voluntary repayments;
· HECS doubtful debt percentage;
· Consumer Price Index (CPI);
· Higher Education Operating Grant Index; and
· write-downs due to the death of debtors, remission of HECS debts, and refunds of voluntary repayments.

Table 2.6 on page 82 of the Higher Education Funding Report for the 2002-04 Triennium provides a summary of HECS liabilities, payments and accumulated debt for the financial years from 1989-90 to 2004-05. The table has been extended below to show financial projections through to 2006 in accordance with the normal Budget Forward Estimates requirements. Projections are not normally prepared for periods beyond the Budget Forward Estimates period as they are considered to be potentially unreliable. Information sought on what proportion of each category in Table 2.6 can be attributed to past, present and future students is unavailable as the data inputs used for the HECS forward estimates is not collected on this basis and therefore can not be split to determine these proportions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 January 2003:

quote.para: (1) (a) Do plantation growers in Tasmania obtain a financial advantage compared with those in other states from being able to clear native vegetation to establish plantations; (b) has this benefit been quantified; and (c) how much is it.
(2) (a) Why is it that native forests can be cleared in Tasmania but not in any other state; (b) what is the environmental and economic justification.
(3) Have other plantation growers complained about the situation in Tasmania; if so, who and when.

(4) (a) Is the Minister aware that 42 000 hectares of Tasmanian native forest on public and private land was cleared for plantations in the 2000-01 financial year and that Gunns Ltd alone has around 70 000 hectares of native forest on its own land which it intends to clear for plantations; and (b) what action will be taken to stop this destruction.
(5) What area of plantations was established under managed investment schemes for each state in each of the following financial years: (a) 2000-01; (b) 2001-02.

(6) (a) Does the Government have any policy against using tax concessions to encourage the clearing of native vegetation; and (b) is the 13-month prepayment provision for plantations such a concession.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 17 January 2003:

quote.para: Currently, Phosphate Resource Ltd (PRL) pays $1.50 per ton for phosphate as a rehabilitation levy on Christmas Island, a levy that has been collected by the department but administered by Environment Australia (EA):

(1) Is it a fact that the Minister has ended that arrangement; that the monies from the levy imposed on PRL no longer goes to Environment Australia, and Environment Australia is no longer responsible for administering the fund.
(2) Why was this arrangement terminated.
(3) Did EA support the termination of the arrangement.
(4) Is there any evidence that EA was not carrying out its obligations in relation to the levy.
(5) Is there any evidence that EA was failing to protect the Christmas Island environment.

(6) Have tenders been sought in order to find another organisation to manage the levy; if so: (a) who has been granted the contract; (b) who tendered for the contract; (c) what are the terms of the contract; (d) what expertise does the contractor bring to the Christmas Island environment; and (e) how will the monies be spent, including percentages spent on rehabilitation, environmental work and administration.
(7) Who will oversee the program.
(8) Has the Minister received any correspondence from (PRL) indicating displeasure with EA's work on Christmas Island.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Over time the administration of the mine lease, under which the conservation levy is paid, became split over two portfolios. In order to streamline the administration of the mine lease the Government decided to redirect the payment to the portfolio agency with responsibility for the mine lease; Transport and Regional Services.

(3) Yes. Environment Australia is firmly committed to working closely with the Department of Transport and Regional Services to achieve the best possible rehabilitation outcomes within the context of whatever new arrangements are established.

(6) It is proposed to conduct a tender process to under take the rehabilitation work. Tenders have not yet been let. Details of the tender are currently being finalised with various stakeholders including Parks Australia. It is anticipated that the tender will be released in early 2003 with the successful tenderer expected to commence work by 1 July 2003.
(7) The Department of Transport and Regional Services will oversee the program.

(3) What mechanisms are in place to alert the Minister to breaches of the RFA such as this.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) No. I am advised that the road has been designed to avoid potential damage to the reserve's values. I am also advised that its construction is in accordance with a Forest Practices Plan and is in accordance with the RFA.
(2) See (1) above.

(3) In the first instance, allegations of breaches of the RFA should be reported to the Tasmanian Government. Where a matter is brought to the Commonwealth's attention, Commonwealth officials investigate in consultation with Tasmanian officials. Matters that are more serious in nature will be brought to my attention by my department.

The Group was established on 20/8/1998 and dissolved on 17/9/2002.
