talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 24 January 2003:

quote.para: (1) Will the Minister categorically rule out supporting the introduction of bumblebees to mainland Australia.
(2) What action will be taken to prevent the deliberate or accidental introduction of bumblebees to mainland Australia.
(3) What action has been taken and will be taken to control their spread and reduce their impacts in Tasmania.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Commonwealth Government regulates the import of live animals under Part 13A the Environment Protection Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) and the Quarantine Act 1908. Bumblebees (Bombus terrestris) are not included on the `List of Specimens Taken to Be Suitable for Live Import' established under the EPBC Act and import cannot legally occur without an amendment to the list. The list will not be amended to include bumblebees unless the impacts on the Australian environment of the proposed import have been assessed. The assessment process is set out in the EPBC Act. The Commonwealth Government has not received an application for amending the list to include bumblebees.
Any proposed action to transfer bumblebees from Tasmania, where they were introduced illegally or accidentally in 1992, to mainland Australia would be subject to Chapter 4 of the EPBC Act.
(3) The Tasmanian Government has the primary responsibility for managing feral species in Tasmania.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Scientific Committee is considering a nomination to list bumblebees as a key threatening process under the EPBC Act. The assessment is the first step to addressing the impact of a particular threat under Commonwealth law. If the decision is made to list bumblebees as a key threatening process, a Threat Abatement Plan may be put into place if it is proven to be “a feasible, effective and efficient way” to abate the threatening process. I am aware of two independent studies on the impact of bumblebees in Tasmania and the results of these studies will be taken into account by the Committee in its assessment. I will take the Committee's advice into account in making my decision on whether to list bumblebees as a key threatening process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

quote.para: With reference to the joint United States of America (US) and Australian naval defence exercises carried out off Western Australia in January 2003:

(1) Can the Minister confirm that the USS Abraham Lincoln carried out ordnance and bombing training on a day of a total fire ban, resulting in two fires in the Lancelin Defence Training Area; if so: (a) who was responsible; (b) what damage was incurred; and (c) what action is being taken to investigate the matter.

(2) Did the Australian Navy or the US Navy engage in any active sonar testing, including low-range frequency or mid-range frequency active sonar testing, in any of the naval exercises; if so, specifically what testing was conducted.

(3) Has the Australian Navy an active sonar testing program; if so (a) what is the nature of the tests; and (b) what research has been conducted on the impacts of the tests on marine species, including juvenile fish and mammals such as whales.
(4) Has the Australian Navy informed Environment Australia and its state government counterparts of the findings of that research; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The US Navy (USN) was granted approval by the Minister for Defence on 10 Jan 03 to access Lancelin Defence Training Area (LDTA) for continuation training of naval pilots attached to the USS Abraham Lincoln. No record has been found of a State or local government `total fire ban' being issued for the period of concern. However, Total Fire Bans do not preclude use of LDTA. One fire ignited within LDTA and was extinguished on 14 January. This fire re-ignited on 15 January and was contained and extinguished well within the boundaries of the training area. No further fires occurred during subsequent practice bombing.
(a) The cause of the fire is not known though it may have been due to one of the practice bombs (containing no explosive ordnance) released during the initial USN flights.
(b) Minimal. The fire was contained within LDTA.
(c) The fire incident was fully investigated. Fire risk assessment including ordnance composition were revised, resulting in no further incidents.
(2) No US/Australian naval exercises were carried out off Western Australia in January 2003. No active sonar testing was conducted, apart from routine ship systems operational checks.
(3) Yes.

(a) Royal Australian Navy (RAN) vessels conduct Daily Systems Operability Tests of all onboard systems, which include a check of sonar system functionality. Such tests are conducted in accordance with promulgated mitigation procedures. RAN vessels occasionally participate in Defence active sonar testing and trials sponsored by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) or the Defence Material Organisation. These trials include investigations of new sonar systems for possible Defence acquisition, and performance/upgrade investigations of existing ship systems. All such trials and experiments are assessed through an Environmental Clearance Certificate, to ensure that any potential environmental impacts are minimised in accordance with the Defence Environmental Policy. Where sufficient uncertainty exists regarding the level of environmental impact, the activity is referred to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage for consideration under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. The RAN does not operate, nor does it have any intention to operate, any low frequency active (LFA) sonar systems such as the SURTASS LFA tested by the US Navy in the North Pacific.

(b) DSTO has an active program of research into whale distribution and the impact of noise from human activities, including the use of military active sonar, on marine animals. Current Defence research expenditure on this matter amounts to more than $2 million over the next three years, and involves extensive collaboration with universities, museums and whale research organisations in Australia.

(4) Yes. The results of research into effects of underwater noise on the marine environment are widely published and freely available. Defence engages regularly with Environment Australia and State Government counterparts.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) Was Australia requested to contribute funds to an appeal by the United Nations in December 2002 for US$37 million to prepare for a possible humanitarian crisis in Iraq.
(2) (a) What contribution has Australia made to prepositioning humanitarian aid in case of a war in Iraq; and (b) how much has it contributed to the $37 million requested
(3) What does the Minister estimate the humanitarian requirements for Iraq to be in the case of war
(4) (a) What humanitarian aid will Australia provide in case of a war in Iraq; (b) what will be the value; (c) what form will the aid take; and (d) how will it be delivered

(5) (a) What communications has the Minister had with the United States of America and Britain relating to humanitarian issues in the event of war; (b) when were these discussions; and (c) what was the substance of these discussions.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer:

quote.para: (1) Australia and other donors were informed in December 2002 of the UN's initial financial needs of USD 37 million for planning and preparedness on Iraq.

(2) (a) Australia is providing $10 million to assist UN agencies and the ICRC to prepare for humanitarian relief (b) $8 million of this has been allocated for UN preparatory efforts ($6 million for the UN's Central Emergency Revolving Fund, which assists UN agencies with emergency relief and humanitarian operations, and $2 million to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs). $2 million is being provided to ICRC. Australia is also assisting UN agencies to identify suitably qualified Australians who can play a role in the planning and delivery of humanitarian relief.
(3) It is difficult to estimate humanitarian requirements in the case of a conflict with any degree of precision, as these would depend on its nature and duration.

(4) (a) and (b) The volume and type of Australian assistance would need to be considered by the Government in light of the circumstances at the time and would depend on the nature and duration of any conflict and the humanitarian needs on the ground. (c-d)UN and international relief agencies and many NGOs have well established processes for dealing with crises. We would look to these channels as our primary mechanisms for delivering assistance. Australia would also consider what specific expertise it could offer to assist with relief efforts.

(5) I and Australian Government officials have held a number of discussions with the UN and the US over recent weeks in relation to humanitarian issues in the event of a conflict. These have focussed on ensuring arrangements and resources are in place to respond to humanitarian needs quickly and effectively, should they arise.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) Have Australia's defence personnel been informed about the risks of operating in areas of Iraq contaminated as a result of the use, by the United States of America and Britain, of ammunition containing depleted uranium during the previous Gulf War.
(2) In the event of war, will the Minister guarantee that Australian soldiers will not be deployed in those areas where there is contamination.
(3) Will Australian troops be: (a) working alongside other allied forces using ammunition containing depleted uranium; or (b) using it themselves.
(4) Which, if any, alternatives to ammunition containing depleted uranium are now used or being developed.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Before agreeing to any military deployment, the Government carefully considers the range of potential risks and threats in the Area of Operations (AO) and ensures that all personnel deploying are properly trained and equipped for this environment. Such an assessment has been undertaken for forces pre-deployed to the Middle East as part of Operation Bastille and personnel suitably briefed.

In August 2001, the Expert Committee to Examine Balkan Veteran Exposure to Depleted Uranium provided a report on behalf of the-then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, titled Review of Scientific Literature on the Health Effects of Exposure to Depleted Uranium. This report concluded that, on the basis of the available sound medical-scientific evidence and under realistic assumptions of exposure and dose, depleted uranium could not produce any health effects in Australian troops serving with NATO forces in the Balkan conflict.

The Defence Health Service subsequently revised its health bulletin regarding depleted uranium health screening policy in December 2001. On the basis of the Expert Committee's independent review of relevant evidence on this subject, the Defence Health Service agreed that depleted uranium posed no adverse risk of health effects for Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel performing duties that would potentially lead to depleted uranium exposure, and determined that the ADF policy no longer required health screening for depleted uranium exposure.

In the event that the Government agreed an Australian force contribution to any potential coalition military action against Iraq, there is no evidence to indicate that ammunition containing depleted uranium would pose an adverse health risk to ADF personnel if operating in Iraq.

(2) The Government has made no decision to be involved in any potential military action against Iraq and the Government's focus remains the disarmament of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction through peaceful means. Any decision regarding potential Australian involvement in coalition military action would be a decision for Government at an appropriate time based on our national interests.

In the event that the Government to contribute to any possible military action, as there is no evidence to indicate that ammunition containing depleted uranium would pose an adverse health risk, there would be no need for restrictions based on this criterion.

(3) (a) As no decision has been made regarding military action against Iraq, the Government is not going to speculate on the makeup of any potential allied force, or the kinds of ammunition which might be utilised in the event of such action.
(b) No.
(4) The ADF uses ammunition with a tungsten penetrator as the alternative to ammunition containing depleted uranium, and has done so progressively since 1986.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 17 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) Is the department currently conducting, or has it commissioned, research into methods of controlling Diabolical Weed.
(2) In the event that the department has commissioned research into methods of controlling Diabolical Weed: who is conducting the research.
(3) What methods of Diabolical Weed pest control are being researched.

(4) In the event that the department is currently conducting research, or has commissioned research, into methods of controlling Diabolical Weed: (a) when did the research start; and (b) when will such research be completed.
(5) How much funding has the Commonwealth budgeted for this research.
(6) What amount of funding has the Commonwealth expended to date on this research.
(7) Can details be provided of the specific objectives of such research.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: Neither my Department nor I know of any specific plant that is commonly called Diabolical Weed. Since common names for plants do not have any official status and can on occasion be obscure, I would be better placed to provide a response to Senator O'Brien's question if he provides a botanical name for the plant.
